column12: Difficult to reach an answer as the two options are only slightly different in the way they are phrased, whether the evidence of the child's competency needs to be proven before being called on as a witness or whether the child can be accepted as a witness on the assumption alone. From the research it seems every state has different laws when it comes to this and a child's age is irrelevant in the context of whether he will make a good witness or not. Some papers from the 1980s do state that the attorney asking for a child to be a witness must be prepared with evidence for the competency prior to going in front of the judge, however I was not able to find anything more recent suggesting the same thing which is why I put down only 55%.

column12: Patient appears to suffer from deep vein thrombosis for which the venous duplex scan seems to be preferred over the CT. Vitals of the patient are ok except for a low fever which can appear in DVT. Blood pressure looks normal despite mentioning he suffers from hypertension, DVT apparently can cause lower blood pressure so this can be a reason why it looks normal. The other diagnosis could've been cellulitis as I found with DVT, the pedis pulses are likely not present in the affected leg, an issue that is not present here. Even with cellulitis, the CT angiogram doesn't seem to be warranted, especially since the patient is undergoing chemotherapy and suffers with hypertension. The duplex scan seems to be the second line therapy for this and gives accurate diagnoses without being invasive.

column12: Difficult to reach a conclusion because some factors are not very clear in the way the question was asked and the answer was written. First of all, the neighbour 'also recognized that the woman had recently undergone surgery and appeared to be "out of sorts" due to her medication', it does not mention whether this was something he said to the woman or her adult child or just something he thought and therefore cannot know for sure if it can be enforced he was aware of her mental capacity at the time. Secondly, the answer for option B states the 'evident incapacity' of the woman. From what I read, mental incapacity of someone to make decisions/contracts by law cannot be 'evident' and needs to be proven, this process differs from state to state and can be done by people close to the person in question of by professionals depending on how important the reason behind it is. Answer A is wrong strictly by considering that oral contracts are enforceable even if difficult to prove. Answer B is not strictly correct as a person cannot be considered evidently incapacitated but it's more likely in this situation. I would be more inclined to answer B if it stated somewhere along the lines of 'the contract can be voided if the woman is proven to be incapacitated'. In conclusion, both reasons for why the contract was voided need to be proven but it's likely the incapacitation of the woman will be the reason

column12: Very difficult question, while the contract does state invoice must be issued while the employee is actively part of the company, there is legal precedent to being given the commission as in the case of Medex v. McCabe it was ruled that the commission was earned during employment and therefore it must be given to the former employee. Also, there is no strict definition that an active employee is contractually paid so the former employee in question could argue that being involved in aiding the clients for the following 6 months is considered an active employee. That with the legal precedent of Medex v. McCabe makes me sway towards A. But could very likely be B, took longer researching this question as it was tough to reach a conclusion

Then I searched about " hearsay statement as a evidence in US court, different cases" which gave me several exceptions that included 1. Excited utterances 2.Dying declarations 3. First I looked for united states law of evidence, defendants past record. From the google search engine I visited 2 to 3 website to get the insights on using defendant past record as an evidence against him/her. 

From website www.law.cornell.edu, I read "Rule 609. Impeachment by Evidence of a Criminal Conviction" From this rule I was unable to draw any conclusion.

From website www.nolo.com, i read about "Evidence of Prior Convictions: Admissible Against Defendants Who Testify?." I got to know that "Generally, prosecutors can't use evidence of prior convictions to prove a defendant's guilt or tendency to commit crimes, but they can sometimes use them to question the truthfulness or credibility of the defendant's testimony."

Then I moved on the website: www.law.cornell.edu, and delved into the details of "Rule 404. Character Evidence; Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts" Rule 404(b) states that: 
(b) Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts.
(1) Prohibited Uses. Evidence of any other crime, wrong, or act is not admissible to prove a person’s character in order to show that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character.
(2) Permitted Uses. This evidence may be admissible for another purpose, such as proving motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake, or lack of accident.

From this I drew the conclusion that evidence of the defendant's involvement in the prior scheme be admitted to establish the lack of mistake. (option B)

column12:
First I wanted to know more about quitclaim so I searched for: what is quitclaim deed.
After knowing about quitclaim deed I searched for "United states law regarding false quitclaim deed." I visited several website to entertain my query.

From www.schorr-law.com, Where there is ownership fraud or fraud in the execution of a quitclaim deed, typically the property owner must go to Court and seek the Court’s assistance in setting the forged deed aside. Unfortunately, property owners often remain in the dark for considerable periods of time before they realize that a fraudulent document has been recorded. A quitclaim deed conveys title from a “grantor” to a “grantee.” Contrary to this, a grantor has no legal liability if the title is flawed in some way. If found guilty, the forger will suffer whatever penalty your state mandates for the crime.

After that I searched for: "what happens to contract if quitclaim deed is forged or false Unites states law"
From www.easlerlaw.com, I read:
"A quitclaim deed transfers the actual ownership stake seller has in the land only and not the stake they claim they have. This presents a challenge in remedying a transfer involving fraud. If the seller of a property is merely offering to give up any rights they have in the property, but makes no promises as to quality of title and the seller didn’t actually own the property, then the purchaser has a difficult battle to recover what she paid. The buyer must prove not only that she didn’t receive what she bargained for, she must also prove that the seller met the element of intent in fraud, rather than mere ignorance as to the state of title."

"If the purchaser uncovers information that warrants cancellation of the contract, the purchaser, assuming she is under no fraud or duress, can still elect to ratify the contract.] This is true for property conveyances as well. To ratify the contract, the purchaser need only act in such a manner that recognizes the contract as subsisting, or in a manner inconsistent with the intent of avoiding it. Individuals electing to ratify a contract cannot later attempt to have it rescinded."

From this I came to conclusion of selecting Option B

Firstly I searched for "abduction and flexion of shoulder" which gave me results saying : Abduction (upper limb away from midline in coronal plane), Flexion (upper limb forwards in sagittal plane). I also looked for images for better understanding.

From the result of search engine I further visited website that included details regarding these movements and the muscles they engage. For abduction: 
1. The first 0-15 degrees of abduction is produced by the supraspinatus.
2. The middle fibres of the deltoid are responsible for the next 15-90 degrees.
3. Past 90 degrees, the scapula needs to be rotated to achieve abduction – that is carried out by the trapezius and serratus anterior.
For flexion: ectoralis major, anterior deltoid and coracobrachialis. Biceps brachii weakly assists in forward flexion.

After that i searched for: "what muscles are responsible for shoulder abduction and flexion" and got the same results as stated above.

My final conclusion is that the only muscle the doctor is trying to asses is not only supraspinatus but also deltoid, trapezius and serratus anterior. Since the option only included supraspinatus so I further increased my probability to 90%.

column12:
After clearing my doubts regarding "Miranda Rights" and "Hearsay", I moved on to find about: "legal implications of accused remaining silent after out of court accusation by a partner in crime US law." and visited several websites which gave me following results:

1. The Supreme Court’s decision in Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966), which gave us the well-known Miranda warnings, requires police to cease any and all interrogation once a person has invoked the right to an attorney, and it holds that any statements made afterwards are inadmissible in court. This only applies, however, after police have advised the person of their Miranda rights, which they are only obligated to do once they have placed that person under arrest.

2. On the theory that an innocent man would loudly deny a serious charge, the rule holds that a suspect silent in the face of an accusation has tacitly admitted the crime. And such silence can later be introduced at his trial as an indicator of guilt.

3. As per published paper titled as "Treatment of silence as misrepresentation in contracts: A critical comparative analysis of common law and Islamic jurisprudence" by Ridoan Karim, Imtiaz Mohammad Sifat in International Journal of Law and Management states that "While common law does not treat silence as conscious misrepresentation, silence does not constitute affirmative will.

I was unable to reach the final conclusion for the fact that the silence can be used as admitting a guilt and at the same time can be considered as invoking the Miranda Rights.
I chose to go with option B as it looks more appropriate after search.

column12:
First I looked for exceptions to hearsay US law and found out that. A record or statement of a public office if:
(A) it sets out:
(i) the office’s activities;
(ii) a matter observed while under a legal duty to report, but not including, in a criminal case, a matter observed by law-enforcement personnel.

Then I looked for hearsay statement exception made under the scope of relationship or employment US law and got to know from a GUIDE TO NEW YORK EVIDENCE 
ARTICLE 8: HEARSAY that
 "The other exception set forth in paragraph (b) creates an exception for 
statements of a party's agent or employee made by the agent or employee in the 
scope of such relationship. The exception has two operative elements: (1) the 
statement relates to or concerns a matter within the scope of the agency or 
employment relationship; and (2) the statement was made during the existence of 
that relationship. As to the first element, the relational phrase—"within the scope of 
that relationship"—is identical to that phrase in Federal Rules of Evidence rule 801 
(d) (2) (D). Commentators have noted that relationship phrase "is broad in its scope" 
(Mueller & Kirkpatrick, Federal Evidence § 8:55 [4th ed]). Consistent with that 
observation, the federal courts have given the phrase a liberal construction, requiring 
only that the statement have some connection to the agent's or employee's specific 
job duties (id.). With respect to the second element, the temporal requirement—
"during the existence of that relationship"—is likewise derived from Federal Rules 
of Evidence rule 801 (d) (2) (D). Federal courts uniformly hold the statement must 
be made while the agent or employee was employed, not before the person was 
hired, or after the person quit or was fired."

Keeping in view the above findings I concluded that the statement given by a security officer is an expectation to hearsay rule to which I have high probability to Option A (Permissible as a declaration made by a representative of an opposing party)

column12:
After searching for exception to the hearsay rule US law, I found out many exceptions related to hearsay rule but the exception of my concern was dying declaration. Therefore I further search for hearsay exception US law dying declaration and found out that:

A dying declaration is defined as a statement made by a declarant, who is unavailable to testify in court (typically because of the declarant's death), who made the statement under a belief of certain or impending death. The statement must also relate to what the declarant believed to be the cause or circumstances of the declarant's impending death.

Additionally, a dying declaration is a type of hearsay which is an out-of-court statement.
However, unlike typical hearsay, a dying declaration is admissible in court.
As such, a dying declaration is as an exception to the hearsay rule.
The exception is listed in Section 804(b)(2) of the Federal Rules of Evidence.
Other general rules of admissibility also apply, such as the requirement that the declaration must be based on the declarant's actual knowledge.
The dying declaration may be used in civil law cases and criminal law cases.

And Section 804(b)(2) of the Federal Rules of Evidence states that "n a prosecution for homicide or in a civil case, a statement that the declarant, while believing the declarant’s death to be imminent, made about its cause or circumstances"

Keeping in view the above rules of evidence I gave high probability to option A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues)

column12:
After searching for: angiography of the lower extremities purpose, I found out "Lower extremity angiography is a test that uses X-rays and contrast dye to see the arteries that carry blood to the legs. It’s used to look for narrowed or blocked areas in leg arteries that can cause leg pain when walking. It’s most often used to diagnose a common condition among older adults called peripheral artery disease (PAD). PAD is caused by hardening of the arteries in the pelvis or legs. It can cause leg cramps, pain, and fatigue in the leg or hip muscles when walking or climbing stairs. It’s important to diagnose and treat narrowing or blockages in the leg arteries. Complete loss of blood flow to the legs can lead to tissue death (gangrene) and amputation."

After looking for: experiences nocturnal pain in toe management angiography, I found out that "Healthcare providers can use two different systems — Fontaine and Rutherford — to assign a stage to your PAD. The Fontaine stages, which are simpler, are:

I: Asymptomatic (without symptoms).
II: Mild claudication (leg pain during exercise). [valid in case of given question]
II: Moderate to severe claudication.
III: Ischemic rest pain (pain in your legs when you’re at rest). [valid in case of given question]
IV: Ulcers or gangrene. [valid in case of given question]

Regardless of your sex, you’re at risk of developing peripheral arterial disease when you have one or more of these risk factors:

1. Using tobacco products (the most potent risk factor).
2. Having diabetes.
3. Being age 50 and older.
4. Having high blood pressure (hypertension).
5. Having high cholesterol (hyperlipidemia).

All these above risk factors are valid for the patient case given in the question, that's why I gave high probability to option (A)

column12:
I started my search with "cause of a  patient experience abdominal pain, vomiting, distended abdomen, and dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels on imaging"  and got to know that all these are signs of bowel obstruction, or small bowel obstruction (SBO).

Small bowel obstruction (SBO) is a common reason for elderly patients to be admitted to hospital under the care of general surgery. Small bowel obstruction may be diagnosed with a physical examination alone, but often further diagnostics are required for surgical evaluation and management. While traditionally, a physical examination was used to diagnose small bowel obstruction, the invention of computed tomography (CT) has dramatically improved the accuracy and characterization of this disease. Radiographs are often used as a supplementary imaging modality; however, ultrasound is more sensitive and specific than radiographs. Additionally, ultrasound does not result in radiation exposure and has the benefit of rapid and serial examinations.

Treatment  requires time and supportive management. Bowel rest, intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, and nasogastric (NG) decompression are important steps.

I concluded (B) as my final answer and gave highest probability to it.

First I looked for the accuracy of infrared imaging technology and found out that "Due to the limitations of the external environment and the infrared thermal imager's own materials, the accuracy of temperature measurement is low. Due to the influence of various noises, the image collected by the infrared thermal imager needs to be processed to improve the accuracy. Infrared cameras don't just let you see differences in heat, they let you measure those differences, which means the accuracy and consistency of the measurements is a very important factor when determining the value of a camera.

After that I looked for what are the basic requirements for the admissibility of photographs as evidence in US court?
Types of Video and Photo Evidence That May Be Admissible
There are many ways to capture and present admissible visual evidence for court. Here are some of the most common examples. 

1. Surveillance Footage
Typically, this includes recordings from security cameras installed in public places, businesses, residences, and other locations. Surveillance footage can capture events such as accidents, crimes, or suspicious activities, providing highly reliable visual evidence.
2. Body Camera Footage
3. Expert Testimony with Visual Aids

The principal requirements to admit a photograph (digital or film-based) into evidence are relevance and authentication. Unless the photograph is admitted by the stipulation of both parties, the party attempting to admit the photograph into evidence must be prepared to offer testimony that the photograph is an accurate representation of the scene. This usually means someone must testify that the photograph accurately portrays the scene as viewed by that witness.

Keeping in view that how to photos are admissible in court and what are the requirement to prove their accuracy, relevance and authenticity, I have high probability to option B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph)

column10: After my research: A (The salesman will triumph, as he had committed to the client to aid in the operation of the equipment.): 15%; B (The manufacturer will prevail, due to the fact that at the time the client was invoiced for the supercomputer, the salesman was no longer an employee of the manufacturer.): 85%
column12:
First I looked for employee contract qualifying for commission claim US law and found out that "The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) does not require employers to pay commissions. However, earned commissions are considered wages for workers who earn the sale. If the payment of commissions is part of your employment contract, your employer has to follow through with the agreement.
According to the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL), commissions are money paid to workers after completing work tasks — typically product sales. A commission can be the sole form of compensation or as a bonus to encourage results."

If you are an employee paid by sales commissions, you should have a written agreement that details commission pay. This should include when the commission is earned and the percentage or amount of the sales commission. Make sure terms are clearly stated in your written contract. This includes performance requirements or quotas to earn the commission. A contract that does not clearly define terms and conditions is more likely to lead to legal disputes. When you take a position that pays commissions, you should be aware of your legal right to collect unpaid sales commissions. Employee rights may differ according to your jurisdiction.

What if There Is No Contract?
It can be more difficult to collect on a commission when you don’t have written evidence. Where no employment contract exists, you’ll need other evidence to determine the correct amount of commission that you should receive. The same applies when the contract terms are unclear. Evidence can include other writing, emails, text messages, or witness statements.

Understanding your rights is the first step in addressing unpaid commissions effectively.
1. Commission agreement: Your commission agreement is your contract with your employer, specifying how you earn and calculate your and when they should be paid.
2. Work done, pay due: If you have met the terms set in your agreement, you are entitled to your commissions, regardless of whether the client paid your employer.
3. Timely payment: In Florida, commissions must be paid promptly, either according to the agreed-upon schedule or industry norms.
4. Protection from retaliation: Asserting your rights should not result in retaliation from your employer.

Your commission agreement serves as your legal framework, entitling you to the earnings you have rightfully accrued. Your rights are your protection. The law upholds them, so you should have no fear of consequences.

Keeping in view the above considerations I gave high probability to option (B)

column10: After my research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 15%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 85%
column12:
First I looked for cross examination of expert witness in US court of law and found out: Cross-examination: The expert witness may be called upon to retrace his steps, explain and justify his position, and harmonize his views in the case with prior writings, depositions or trial testimony from other matters/cases.
Cross-examination can present an opportunity to solidify and drive home the expert's conclusions and opinions previously stated during direct examination. Witnesses should be honest and should rely on their technical expertise and the scientific method, on which their testimony is based.
Notwithstanding the importance of qualifications, this is an area of cross-examination that should be approached cautiously and respectfully. Unless you are confident that the expert witness’s overall credibility will be diminished because of serious deficiencies in his or her qualifications, an aggressive attack may backfire and create sympathy for the expert.

After that I searched for Federal Rules of Evidence (FRE)  Rule 608(b), as AI gave reference of this Rule and found out that"

(a) Reputation or Opinion Evidence. A witness’s credibility may be attacked or supported by testimony about the witness’s reputation for having a character for truthfulness or untruthfulness, or by testimony in the form of an opinion about that character. But evidence of truthful character is admissible only after the witness’s character for truthfulness has been attacked.
(b) Specific Instances of Conduct. Except for a criminal conviction under Rule 609, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness’s conduct in order to attack or support the witness’s character for truthfulness. But the court may, on cross-examination, allow them to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:
(1) the witness; or
(2) another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about.
By testifying on another matter, a witness does not waive any privilege against self-incrimination for testimony that relates only to the witness’s character for truthfulness."

Keeping in view the above finding I gave high probability to option (B)
Admitted, but only if it's obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.

column10: After my research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 20%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 80%
column12:
I started the search by looking for immediate treatment after burns and immediate treatment after 43% body burns. Found out that Burns and scalds are damage to the skin usually caused by heat. Both are treated in the same way. A burn is caused by dry heat – by an iron or fire, for example. A scald is caused by something wet, such as hot water or steam.
Depending on how serious a burn is, it may be possible to treat it at home.

For minor burns, keep the burn clean and do not burst any blisters that form.
More serious burns require professional medical attention.
You should go to a hospital A&E department for:
1. all chemical and electrical burns
2. large or deep burns – any burn bigger than the injured person's hand
burns that cause white or charred skin – any size
3. burns on the face, neck, hands, feet, any joints or genitals

There are 4 main types of burn, which tend to have a different appearance and different symptoms:
1. superficial epidermal burn 
2. superficial dermal burn
3. deep dermal or partial thickness burn
4. full thickness burn

For burns classified as severe (> 20% TBSA), fluid resuscitation should be initiated to maintain urine output > 0.5 mL/kg/hour.  One commonly used fluid resuscitation formula is the Parkland formula. The total amount of fluid to be given during the initial 24 hours = 4 ml of LR × patient’s weight (kg) × % TBSA.  Half the calculated amount is administered during the first eight hours, beginning when the patient is initially burned. For example, if a 70 kg patient has a 30% TBSA partial thickness burn, they will need 8400 mL Lactated Ringer solution in the first 24 hours with 4200 mL of that total in the first 8 hours [(4 mL) × (70 kg) × (30% TBSA) = 8,400 mL LR]. Remember that the fluid resuscitation formula for burns is only an estimate, and the patient may need more or less fluid based on vital signs, urine output, other injuries, or other medical conditions.

Keeping in view the above given treatment, I gave high probability to option B (Administration of intravenous fluids)

column10: After my research: A (disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception.): 65%; B (dismissed, because its potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value.): 35%
column12:
At first, I want to know the meaning and difference between the two options, so I looked for:
potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value meaning. I found out that "If the probative value of evidence is substantially outweighed by the dangers of unfair prejudice, confusing the issues, misleading the jury, undue delay, wasting time, or needlessly presenting cumulative evidence then this evidence might be excluded."

After that I searched for: hearsay in court and its exceptions US law to find out that whether the hearsay statement given by a person to police officer falls under any exception or not. following are the details of one of the exception  "Excited utterances: Statements relating to startling events or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition. This is the exception that may apply to the 'police officer' scenario described below. The victim's cries of help were made under the stress of a startling event, and the victim is still under the stress of the event, as is evidenced by the victim's crying and visible shaking. An excited utterance does not have to be made at the same time of the startling event. A statement made minutes, hours or even days after the startling event can be excited utterances, so long as the declarant is still under the stress of the startling event. However, the more time that elapses between a startling event and the declarant's statement, the more the statements will be looked upon with disfavor."

In determining whether or not to allow evidence its probative value is measured against the potential prejudicial effect. To be admitted, the evidence must have greater probative value. The probative vs prejudicial analysis is constantly occurring during criminal trials. That does not mean it is difficult for evidence to be admitted. Judges and courts typically weigh more favourably on the side of admission of evidence. The prejudicial effect must be significant to be dismissed, and even then is sometimes allowed with certain restrictions. The balance is not always consistent across the board. Some evidence is more probative on one count and more prejudicial on another. Where this occurs the court may limit the jury’s use of the evidence rather than exclude it outright. 

Since I have to choose one option so keeping in mind above given reasons, I made a conclusion that the admissibility of the officer's testimony about the driver's statement should be disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception (option A)

column12:
First I looked for breach of retirement contract by a company US law and found out the following points
1. A breach of contract occurs when one party in a binding agreement fails to deliver according to the terms of the agreement.
2. A breach of contract can happen in both a written contract and an oral contract.
3. The parties involved in a breach of contract may resolve the issue among themselves or in a court of law.
4. There are different types of contract breaches, including a minor or material breach and an actual or anticipatory breach.
5. A breach of contract is not considered a crime or even tort and rarely results in extra monetary compensation

After this I searched for: employee retirement contract legal implications US law and found out that:
An employment relationship in the United States is presumed to be “at-will,” i.e., terminable by either party, with or without cause or notice. Indeed, a majority of employees in the United States are employed on an “at-will” basis, without a written employment contract, and only with a written offer of employment that outlines the basic terms and conditions of their employment.

Highly-skilled and compensated employees (e.g., high-level executives) are traditionally employed pursuant to written employment contracts. These contracts specify the basic terms and conditions of employment, such as position, job responsibilities, salary, compensation, incentive pay, and stock options. These also define what conduct will justify termination for cause and provide for severance pay in case of termination without cause.

Whether the employment relationship is “at-will” or pursuant to a written employment contract, parties are free to negotiate and set the terms and conditions of their relationship, so long as none of the provisions violate any federal, state or local law, rules or regulations governing the employment relationship (e.g., the pay practices established in the Fair Labour Standards Act, the prohibition of discrimination under the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the like).

Keeping in view the above reasons  If the executive were to file a lawsuit against the corporation for breach of contract, based on US law, he would likely Prevail, since his decision to retire and purchase the recreational vehicle was made in reasonable reliance on the corporation's guarantee of a lifetime pension. (option A)

column12:
After searching for infant born with subcostal retractions and moderate perioral cyanosis, I found out that: One of the most important physical findings to be able to recognize in a newborn is the presence of retractions. Sepsis, pulmonary pathology, cardiac disease, metabolic disorders, polycythemia, cold stress, and others can all cause retractions -- it is a sign of a newborn in distress.

To compare the treatment and management of both options Firstly, I searched for: x ray finding showing Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema, management treatment. I found out that: The patterns of lung damage associated with various interstitial lung diseases are often identifiable on chest x-rays. Chest x-rays may also be used to track the progression of interstitial lung disease. Many people diagnosed with interstitial lung diseases are initially treated with a corticosteroid (prednisone), sometimes in combination with other drugs that suppress the immune system. Depending on the cause of the interstitial lung disease, this combination may slow or even stabilize disease progression. 
Oxygen is the usually the first treatment. If oxygen isn't available, a portable hyperbaric chamber can imitate going down to a lower elevation until it's possible to move to a lower elevation.
1. Immediately going down to a lower elevation.
2. Stopping exercise and staying warm. 
3. Medication.

When treating duodenal atresia, the newborn may need to have a nasogastric tube placed in their stomach to remove any contents. In order to resolve the obstruction, a pediatric surgeon must perform surgical repair of the intestine.

Keeping above findings in view I came to conclusion that Double bubble sign definitely requires a surgery while findings given at option A can be treated with medication. Therefore , I gave high probability to option A

column12:
After looking for patient's symptoms of left arm fatigue, dizziness, and vertigo, along with the physical examination findings of reduced brachial and radial pulses on the left side and a bruit over the left clavicle, suggest a vascular problem, I found out that: "Subclavian steal syndrome is a relatively benign condition. As it is a marker of atherosclerosis, it can indicate the risk for future events like myocardial ischemia or stroke. Hence, secondary preventive measures in patients can help in a good prognosis. Symptomatic patients who undergo surgical intervention with angioplasty and stenting or open surgical bypass, also have a good prognosis. Most patients (over 95%) have sustained resolution of ischemic symptoms and do not require reintervention of the target vessel."

Several factors including 
(1) the focal nature of the atherosclerotic plaque,
(2) the high-flow state of the supra-aortic vessels,
(3) the significant reduction in morbidity compared
with a major transthoracic reconstruction make percutaneous angioplasty (PTA) and stenting a particularly suitable alternative to surgery and explain why endovascular
treatments have emerged as the first line of therapy in many centers.

I also found a related question on google in people may ask section
What is done for a blockage to the left subclavian artery?
Medicine for high blood pressure. Medication for vasculitis, if that's the cause. Angioplasty, possibly with a stent, to open the artery. Bypass surgery (in rare cases) to improve blood flow by using another artery to go around the blocked one.

After my research, I gave high probability to option (B)

This is true here as the co-passenger may not know if every single person at the event was drinking or what quantities they were drinking. Something is also hearsay if someone is exaggerating. In this case, the co-passenger could have been exaggerating the amounts of drinks, there is no knowing so it is unreliable. This research made me lean toward answer A. Then I looked up when evidence is inadmissible in the US. This wasn't too helpful as it was quite complicated but it was basically things that were irrelevant. column12: In the end after my research, one thing kept coming back to me on every site I went on: Rule 601. Competency to Testify in General: Every person is competent to be a witness unless these rules provide otherwise and age is not a consideration. There is no rule about providing compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witness's capacity to testify. There is. no must, however the rule changes a little state to state and in this case, we do not have state-specific information, thus I will take the general guidance, which I did not find to require any evidence to prove witness' capacity, unless was required in special circumstance (not age) or was demanded by the defence by proving the witness to be not competent. So I beg to differ with AI and am going for answer A

I would be very uncomfortable taking 14 days to wait further - maybe 3 or 4 but that wasn't an option so I would go for a CT scan.

column6: Before research: A (Undue influence.): 60%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 40%
column7: Pressure was exterted. I wrongly though that "consideration" meant enough time to think about it.
column10: After research: A (Undue influence.): 95%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 5%
column12:
Undue influence is when a party to a contract has external pressure applied that undermines their free will. This could be because the persuader has a special position of trust and that one party is vulnerable. Both of these probably apply in this example.
Insufficient consideration is not to do with time to consider but to do with whether both sides gain from the contract. In this instance, the daughter gains the house, the mother gains $100,000. Whether it is a bad deal or not is irrelevant.

column6: Before research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 45%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 55%

column10: After research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 35%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 65%
column12:
An endotracheal tube (ETT) is used to aid breathing. I discovered that this is a relevant treatment pathway for initial burns treatment, even when there are few obvious symptoms. The patient's breathing rate of 23 is also slightly elevated and he has a circumferential burn on the neck which is a risk factor for breathing issues in burns patients. The occasional premature ventricular contractions don't appear to be relevant to ETT treatment and are perhaps caused by shock.
However, IV is also a relevant initial treatment for severe burns patients (over 20% burns) and is importants to reduce long-term damage as far as I can tell. As the patient, was not showing signs of respiratory distress, I think IV is probably a marginally better first treatment.

I researched various medical terms from the question. I also determined that the patient had a normal WBC count, a slightly elevated BP and heart rate, no fever, and air in the bowel. This probably meant that the patient had a bowel obstruction. He had no infection so there appeared little immediate need for the anti-bacterial drug mentioned in A. I could also find little mention of the drug in relation to small bowel obstruction.
There was, however, much mention of option B and this was supposed to help reduce vomiting, which the patient had. The tube would help to clear the trapped air, as far as I could tell, presumably as a prelude to removing the obstruction, perhaps by surgery.

column12:
I am really unsure as to the answer. The diagnosis is almost certainly a varicocele. These usually appear on the left side with a bag of worms feel and disappear when the patient lies down. Ones that occur for the first time after the age of 40 on the right side may be caused by a tumour. However, the patient is not experiencing pain and the mass is compressible, which leads me to think it is probably not linked to a tumour.
That said, a scan may be the best course to confirm. However, usually an ultrasound would probably be recommended, rather than a CT scan, as they don't expose the patient to radiation and are cheaper. That isn't an option here, otherwise I would have gone for that.

column12: My research helped me understand that the evidence is admissible as an admission by a party-opponent because it was presented by the Plaintiff's estate through evidence in the form of a verified transcript of testimony from the criminal trial by the security officer. Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, a statement by an employee concerning matters related to his employment, made during such employment, is not hearsay and may be admitted against the employer. Therefore, in the civil proceedings, the declaration by the security officer relating to instructions he had received from the defendant's security director is admissible.

The dealer's failure to disclose the prior accident, when combined with actual reliance by the buyer on false assurances by the seller, shall be sufficient ground for rescission of the transaction and for seeking remedies available under the law.

column7: A hunch not based in any way on any special knowledge of US law.
column10: After my research: A (Prevail, since his decision to retire and purchase the recreational vehicle was made in reasonable reliance on the corporationâ€™s guarantee of a lifetime pension.): 60%; B (Not succeed, since the corporationâ€™s assurance of a lifetime pension was an unenforceable promise of a gift.): 40%
column12:
This trial was odd in that my online research made me more sceptical about the AI answer of (A).
I am not familiar with US law.  On first reading I had a hunch not based on  any special knowledge that the correct answer was (B) which I put at 60% confidence.  
I read the AI explanation which influenced me to swing the other way to 60% for (A).  This was a very low confidence score given the AI is usually correct. I was not greatly confident with the AI abilities in this particular question because it looked like something an AI might get confused over.   
  In honesty in my 20 minute search I struggled to find anything useful to answer the question unequivocally.  I began my online research getting definitions for unfamiliar terms. Tapping into google 'at will...’  then google filled in the rest for me and provided me with a definition which suggested 'at-will'  was rather like the Zero Hours Contract in England which certainly did not confer any special rights to pensions. This sent my confidence level a little more towards (B) -not succeed. 
  I started to try and find some examples of case law that were relatable to  'at will employment agreement' + 'pension agreement'+ pension dispute. The plus acts as a logical AND in Google search. There were plenty of examples of at-will pension cases getting thrown out in favour of the reneging company but I didn’t not find one similar enough that had a written promise.    
  I found a journal (bsi.gov/opub/mlr/2001/01art1full.pdf)  that was discussing implied contract rights for people in at-will employment but did not find anything useful.  My technique for checking journals when I am in time pressure is to read the abstract, introduction and  conclusion.  There was not enough time to read the entire document.  With this faster technique I can  usually get what I need if there is anything useful there.

With ‘signed decree’+‘breach of promise’+’US law’,  I tried to get closer to the case I was researching. I saw many examples of ‘breach of promise’ which is what this case appeared to be to me.  In many jurisdictions ‘breach of promise’ had been abolished which pushed my confidence levels more towards (B). After this I rolled back briefly to make sure my understanding of ‘decree’ was good.
I then tried another phase ‘corporation reneging on pension degree’. I noticed that there was a mention of a ‘Pension Protection Fund’ if the company went bust. This may had saved the person who lost their pension but there was no mention of it in the AI explanation or the question. It wasn’t valid because it was Uk law so I added +’US law’ again to target North America.

Another issue was brought to light against (A) in that some jurisdictions have pension pots to fall back if a company goes down and some don’t.  It would have given a clearer picture if I had known the jurisdiction.  The jurisdiction may impact whether the ex-employee gets paid or not. Also as mentioned previously some jurisdiction don’t acknowledge breach of promise so the picture is getting more confused without this knowledge. 

 I continued my searches and saw more examples of companies successfully reneging on pension commitments.

I found  a site (pbgc.gov/about/pg/other/how-pension-plans-ends) with some conditions that allow companies to legally renege on their commitments which involved paying off the ex-employer. This would support (A) because of the payoff.

After I had finished the 20 minutes online research I was even less confident that the AI was correct and brought the slider towards less confidence than first reading the AI explanation at 60% (A).

column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Prevail, since his decision to retire and purchase the recreational vehicle was made in reasonable reliance on the corporationâ€™s guarantee of a lifetime pension.): 75%; B (Not succeed, since the corporationâ€™s assurance of a lifetime pension was an unenforceable promise of a gift.): 25%

column10: After my research: A (Yes, because the release of a contractual obligation must be documented in writing): 4%; B (Yes, because there was no consideration provided for the removal of the construction companyâ€™s duty to install the pavement.): 96%
column12:
Over the 11 questions I had done this was the one I felt was most likely to be wrong for the AI.  

I initially put the slider to 60% towards (B) as a hunch, I had no special knowledge regarding this trial.

 When I read the AI answer I spotted a possible glitch based on the AI description of ‘consideration’.  The AI reasoning against (B) was that there had been a consideration of £200,000.  In my view this did not amount to anything because there was no change in the original price. So this was something I would target with my online investigation. 

I put the slider to 75% towards (B) and started the online searches. 

I went straight for 'consideration' in US law.  I felt this was key. I had already accepted that the AI had a reasonable argument regarding (A) but I suspected the AI had fallen down in judging that it was more reasonable than (B). 

I got some general definitions of the legal meaning of 'consideration' supplied by Google from authoritative websites. Went into Cornell Law School (law.cornell/wex/consideration...) to consolidate my understanding of 'consideration' in US law.

I returned to the search results and started going through the 'People Also Ask' part of Google search.  In the 'five rules of consideration' I found  'An existing contractual duty will not amount to valid consideration.'   I felt my views regarding the AI answer against (B) were vindicated.  The contractor accepted £200,00 which did not amount to a 'consideration' because it was still the same as before.

Around 13.5 minutes in I moved the slider to 96% towards (B) being the best answer in contradiction to the AI answer (A).  

I continued looking around online to see if there was anything I had missed and did not find anything to refute my views.

On first seeing the two Lojban phrases I had no idea which one was correct (50/50) but I did know what I needed to investigate was ke’o and ke’u, presumed to be verbs,  because they were there only words that were different in the two phrases. 

On seeing the AI explanation I felt more confident than usual, that would be more than what I speculated to be the usual AI success rate (89%). The explanation seemed reasonable and clear cut so I put the slider up to 92% for (B).  I was not greatly familiar with ‘discursive particles’ and I speculated that this may be how the AI would fail if my initial impression was wrong.
  
  Along with ‘discursive particles’ generally,  I would be targetting the meanings of ke’o and ke’u in my investigations because this was the key difference.  

The online research came out unusually clean and straightforward this time.  I worked out what ‘discursive particles’ were in English. Then how it applied to ‘I repeat’ in English.  I gathered that you could have ‘repeat’ as in ‘pardon I  didn’t get that’ or you could have someone just repeating which was the meaning I needed.  With this in mind I continued to seeing if there were suitable online translations in Lojban for these words.  On this occasion I found an online dictionary that I had found to be reliable previously (https://vlasisku.lojban.org).  The definitions corresponded clearly to the AI description and I was happy to put the slider up to 99% for (B) at around 17 minutes before I stopped early. The missing one percent was there because I understand that the internet can be an echo chamber and completely fictitious information can sometimes take on the appearance of facts. I imagine this could become especially confusing with Lojban.  I did not attempt a full translation because firstly it would probably be extremely inaccurate and secondly that it was not necessary to expend time and energy in this way, when I could get to the right answer in a more incisive way.

column7: I initially went with 75% towards (A) because of my rudimentary knowledge of hearsay in the Uk.  My view of this was that it was second hand knowledge and therefore inadmissible. I did not know there were exceptions to this in US law.
column10: After my research: A (disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception.): 45%; B (dismissed, because its potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value.): 55%
column12:
I initially went with 75% towards (A) because of my rudimentary knowledge of hearsay in the Uk.  My view of this was that it was second hand knowledge and therefore inadmissible. I did not know there were exceptions to this in US law.

After reading the AI explanation towards (A) I was initially confident that the AI was correct then had mounting doubts which caused me to pull the slider back to 60% towards (A). My reasoning was that according to the AI this would fall into an  ‘excited utterance’ exception. Furthermore something seemed odd about the individual reporting on the event going into a similar car. I hadn’t thought out the significance at this point, but it increased my doubts in that there was no discussion of it by the AI.

When I got to the online research I spent time just thinking more about the case.  I wasn’t sure how much online research would help in this instance.
I went online to confirm definitions, in particular ‘excited utterance’ exception, this description was congruent with the AI definition.  What was odd was that the AI did not see it as significant enough because the reporter of the hearsay had a very good chance of falling into this exception.  

Furthermore the reporter going back to a similar looking car might suggest the defendant is part of the same car club as the defendant. This would point to (B) being more likely because if the defendant know the reporter it make the account more prejudicial than probative. For instance he might be a friend and say things to lessen the seriousness of the charge. The ‘cerulean’ aspect did not register with me during the 20 minutes.  

Not sure if this is admissible in the trial but it was my thought process.  Cutting off from something and coming back to it can allow answers to emerge. Shortly  after I had stopped the timer, literally minutes  I had  gone to feed the birds before writing up my account,  the ‘cerulean’ feature of the car came to the fore.  I had discounted it as irrelevant initially. I was not familiar with this word, for all I knew it could be a car type, an obscure province or a colour.  When I looked it up I found it was a very rare and exclusive car colour, this in my view greatly increased the chances of the defendant and reporter being linked and hence a much greater confidence level towards (B). That is, it made the case being thrown out because it was more prejudicial than probative and that (A) was not the valid answer because hearsay could be included because of the ‘excited utterance’ exception.

On reflection and because of the new information, shortly after the time trial, weighing things up I would put up my confidence level to 95% towards (B).

column7: Regarding my initial view of the correct answer I could not choose either being very unfamiliar with the terminology and dynamics of this medically oriented trial so it was 50/50.
column10: After my research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 95%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 5%
column12:
Regarding my initial view of the correct answer I could not choose either being very unfamiliar with the terminology and dynamics of this medically oriented trial so it was 50/50.

On reading the AI explanation I stuck with my generic statistic of 89% towards whatever was the AI answer (B).  What I had read did not really change my view I just went with what was most likely to be correct until hopefully I became more knowledgeable about it with my online research.  

With my online research a lot of the terms where unfamiliar to me.
I checked up on ‘GCS score’  which was moderately serious, confirmed what a backhoe was and confirmed  82/68 mmHg was low blood pressure for a 40 year man.  I next found out if 115 was a high heart rate, it would be if the man was not doing any activity which I presumed he was because  he was injured. I then found out about  fractures in ischial rami which I  gathered were not too serious and would heal on their own.

From here I directed my attentions to reading about DLP.  I found a journal which compared DLP, CT and FAST (https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2663535/ ) .  I was running rather low on time from looking up all the unfamiliar terms and what was ‘normal’. I read quickly through this journal and found  two useful pieces of information which began to make me question the AI answer. 
   If blood pressure was not normal or there was some  mental  impairment DLP was suggested.  The bricklayer had low blood pressure and a GCS of 10, which I equated to moderate mental impairment so it was indicated that DLP would be best.  This suggested that (A) was the correct answer.  What made me question this view was that there was bleeding and DLP was invasive which would increase the risk.  However if DLP was done properly, I gathered it would not be a major cause for concern.
 
   I continued establishing that the patient was not ‘hemodynamically’ normal.  I added to this that in the original question  intravenous fluids where given to him and there was no change would suggest his   hemodynamic status was not normal at all.  All this pointed to (A) being the best answer and not (B) as suggested by the AI.

I continued confirming that DLP was recommended for low blood pressure patients.  I found another extract from the journal I was reading stating that DLP was better than fast if the results were equivocal.  The ineffectual results of FAST were already stated in the trial account which further pushed my view towards (A). We already knew that after adding 2 litres of fluids nothing happened which further cemented my view.

With what seemed like good evidence to me I went against the AI answer putting my answer up to 95% for (A).  The 5% against this was my apprehension that I was going against an artefact that was usually correct and that DLP was invasive.

column10: After my research: A (Yes, as it constitutes a declaration against interest.): 75%; B (Yes, as it is considered a statement made by a co-conspirator.): 25%
column12:
Initially
I went with (A) because I thought hearsay could be relevant here and I didn’t know anything about co-conspirators in US law.

After Reading Ai answer
I went above my statistical confidence level  that the AI was usually correct because the explanation towards (A) appeared compelling to me. 

During and After the online research I gradually had doubts building but not enough  to completely give up on (A).

When I began my online research
 I started with investigating the relationship between declarations of interest with conspiracy in US Law. According to top of 1st page Google results and ‘People also ask’, which are usually very reliable hearsay could be very significant in co-conspiracy cases.  It concerned me that the AI did not mention anything about hearsay. From what I was reading answer (B) would appear to work with hearsay exceptions associated with co-conspiracy.  The journal abstract ‘Co-conspirator Declarations...’ (scholarship.law.wm.edu/facpubs/564/) continued to confirm this.

I could clearly see that (A) is more straightforward and easy to prove.  However the original case was a conspiracy case,  would the insurance company have to restart the case again if they are not going for conspiracy ?  In which case (A) would be wrong. 

Regarding (B) it appears hearsay would be acceptable as an exception for ‘excited utterance’ but to make it stick the utterance has to ‘further the conspiracy’. In this instance the utterance detracted from the conspiracy rather than deepening it.  Furthermore the laws around of hearsay and co-conspirator statements do not fit together well according to a journal I pulled up (The Hearsay Exception for Co-conspirator).  Towards the end of the 20 minutes I could see the notion of ‘hearsay’ was conflated with co-conspiracy laws around ‘res gestae‘ exceptions and others. This rather proved the AI’s point, that (B) would be harder to prove. 
I continued by looking some more at ‘hearsay exceptions’ and ‘‘hearsay’ and ‘excited utterance’’.  From there  I did a search with ‘co-conspiracy vs declaration of interest’ to see if anything else emerged. I pulled up another journal ‘The Hearsay Exception...’ (chicagounbound...) and found a fuller definition of ‘res gestae‘.

Weighing it all up I stuck with the AI explanation but not with a great degree of confidence putting the slider to 75% for (A).

column7: Initially I did not have any idea what was the correct answer was but I could see that to find the best answer I needed to look at ‘cfagau’ and ‘cfari’ which were the words, I presumed verbs that were different in the two sentences.
column10: After my research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 89%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 11%
column12:
Initially I did not have any idea what was the correct answer was, but I could see that to find the best answer I needed to look at ‘cfagau’ and ‘cfari’ which were the words, I presumed verbs that were different in the two sentences.

After reading the AI explanation it looked very plausible to me and I put the slider higher (92% for A)  than what I imagined to be the AI average score for getting answers correct.

I really found it difficult to find an unequivocal answer in this trial, but did find an answer as to why I couldn’t.  The two related key verbs were difficult to tell apart and the online dictionaries et cetera only helped to a certain degree.

I did not try for a full translation of the phrases just the key verbs in each phrase, cfagau and cfari.  I began searching for a English to Lojban of cfagau in Google Chrome. I went to the dictionary that I had found to be the most reliable in past trials ‘vlasisku’ and got a definition of cfagau (https://vlasisku.lojban.org/cfagau)  which supported the AI explanation in favour of (A). Also in the notes here there was ‘cfari’ which gave the same definition but without the person connection.  This by default seemed to support the Ai explanation too.  I proceeded to dig further into this online dictionary to try and investigate this more (https://vlasisku.lojban.org/dict/cfagau).

I continued in this dictionary following best guess for ‘cfari’ (https://vlasisku.lojban.org/dict/cfari…...), this did not inspire confidence since ‘best guess’ infers the answer was not well established and had a good chance of being incorrect. On this page there was a note about cfari being ‘non-agentive’ I suppose in a roundabout way this supported the AI explanation again, but I was far from being convinced.

I began another search this time I tried ‘cfari vs cfagau’ to see if anything useful came up. From the Google results a site called ‘Yumpu’ (https://www.yumpu...),  some online dictionary, described cfagau as [cfari vs gasnu] and I was getting further into the weeds while still not refuting the AI explanation.

I had a look at cfari on its own with Chrome and pulled up a Wiki (wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Loijban/cfari).  It gave a definition which was congruent with the AI explanation and described it as an intransitive verb. I proceeded to remind myself what an ‘intransitive verb’ was. I thought getting a better understanding of the grammar here would help me find an answer so I continued searching based on the definitions moving from intransitive verb to direct object and then transitive. All this continued to support the AI explanation.

I continued to look for better definition of the two verbs.  I found a discussion of ‘cfagau’ on jbovlaste (jblovlaste.lolban.org/comments…..)  From the comments I was beginning to think an unequivocal definition of the differences between cfari and cfagau simply did not exist. Which made me wonder a whether our AI was hallucinating by giving a clear definition. I had gathered in this and previous trials that Lobjan, a constructed language,  was very young as compared to ‘organic’ languages. Many of the subtleties of this language just didn’t exist or were not well established. People on jbovlaste were voting for the correct definition which rather supported this thesis.

In the last few minutes I looked again at some of the pages I had already been to help confirm my views.   Finally I pulled up a Wikipedia entry on Lojban grammar (en’wikipedia/wiki/Lojban_grammar) and did find some examples of cfari usage which supported the AI explanation.  

While the Ai answer to this question may be technically correct as generated by an AI using what I would imagine to be the rules of Lojban grammar,  how correct is it when it is not endorsed by humans in the real world ?  I moved the slider a few steps back with this in mind.

Overall I supported the AI answer  of (A) but not without a degree of uncertainty.

column12:
On first reading I had no idea what the correct answer was.

After I had read the AI explanation the answer (A)  looked convincing. I had no reason not to think that the AI was correct.

I began the online  research by familiarising myself with unfamiliar phases and terms.  There were rather a lot of them.  I put :  2+ posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses on both sides’ into Chrome,  found this meant the pulses were more diminished than normal. Looked up ‘edematous’ which was swollen with excessive accumulation of fluid.
I proceeded by looking up the risks associated with hypertension and colon cancer.  It was rather a broad search but I was hoping something would emerge that was related to my case. Did not find much that was useful to me so I went for what I considered to be a central phrase in the AI explanation that was only hinted at  in the question 
 ‘deep venous thrombosis (DVT)’.  I wanted to see if the AI was jumping to conclusions before I went fully with this line of enquiry.

The online definitions appeared to fit with the AI having a high suspicion of DVT, so I went with that. I proceeded to check if the state temperature of the patient was normal, which it was. After looking around online about blood pressure I went with the questions statement of hypertension. 

In the question it stated ‘sudden onset swelling in his right leg that started 6 hours ago’.  I put this into Chrome because I wanted to see if there was anything time sensitive with the swelling and to see if anything useful emerged.

After acquainting myself with keys terms and working around the dynamics I was beginning to run out of time so I began to look for answers in a more direct way. If I hadn’t have done the early familiarising the answers may not have made any sense to me.  
I tried ‘tests and scans for DVT’ in Chrome. I gathered that a venous duplex scan was   an ultrasound scan for the legs. Then I plugged the two answers from the question into Chrome removing (A) and (B) and adding vs and ‘for DVT’ at the end : 

 ‘Venous duplex scan vs Lower extremity CT angiogram for DVT’

The first result I got to was suggesting (B) was best in the first instance but we already knew something about the patient.  I gather that some patents can be ‘asymptotic’ and yet still have DVT.  The fear is that a blood clot can start in the leg then move to the heart, which would justify a Ct  angiogram. However in our case there were enough symptoms to point to DVT so a  ‘Venous duplex scan’ would be sufficient.

 More results emerged, I downloaded a journal I thought might be useful then I pulled up another one with unfamiliar terminology. I was uncertain if it was discussing the topics I needed to look at closely enough.

I decided to finish by looking at each option individually  ‘vinous duple scan disadvantages’ and then ‘Lower extremity CT angiogram disadvantages’ I carried on till the end just to make sure I had got this straight but had come to enough of an understanding to make a good choice.

I put the slider up further in alignment with the AI and answer (A).

column7: I was unusually very confident in my answer this time.
column10: After my research: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 1%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 99%
column12:
On first reading I went for (B) fairly confidently. I cannot see how the constitutional rights against someone being surveilled can be valid for someone breaking into a commercial factory that is not owned by the defendant. If it was someone in their own home being surveilled that would be a different matter.

On reading the AI explanation this was congruent with my view and filled some of the details. I pulled up the slider to high level of confidence in (B).

With my online research I set to trying to find some way to undermine (B).

 I copy and pasted a significant phrase in the AI explanation in the hope  that Google find what I was looking for.  I purposely did not put inverted comma’s on both side of the phrase because I wanted to use Google to search for the gist of what I was searching for and not the specific combination of words. 

- infrared imaging technology is a tool used to gather evidence, not a witness itself

The first site I got to was commercial and while it was close to what I was looking for it was only on the top line, top page, because I imagine they had paid Google a large amount of money. Not a good enough source. I went back to search and made it more specific adding – US law.  I tried to make the search clearer for Google by taking out ‘not a witness itself’.

From the Google snippets I gathered surveillance was a ‘Fourth Amendment’ matter and Kyllo was a significant case regarding home surveillance, but  I needed the laws standing on commercial surveillance. I also noted it was ‘presumptively unreasonable’ without a warrant.   I narrowed the net a little more with 

- infrared imaging technology + evidence + US law + break ins

I tried to zone in more on business surveillance and I added –  + commercial.

Apparently thermal imaging (infra red as subset) was allowed when surveilling a marijuana grower in a domestic setting. Looking through the Google snippets this seems to be the cutting edge of  the law.   I speculated that a person breaking into a commercial property being surveilled is not discussed as much because it is ancient history in this area.

I pulled up a journal on the fourth amendment and thermal imaging (digitalcommons,law,villanova.edu…).  I couldn’t read it all so I targeted ‘business’ in the local search after trying commercial and then ‘homes’ just to make sure the search was working properly. I found a case where the authorities had set up a business premises selling growing equipment to surveil  marijuana growers (pp.17).  This was seen as perfectly acceptable so someone breaking into someone else’s commercial  property in the night  and being surveilled is a long way from this level of reasonableness. Furthermore according to Ismael (pp.21, paraphrasing) a Fourth Amendment charge was not valid. 

Continuing with the search I tried - ‘commercial premises’ + us law +  infra red 

I did not find anything useful there so I tried -  commercial premises’ +’ us law’ +  surveillance 

I found a useful snippet that Google scraped from Cornell Law School stating that surveillance had its limits and that the Fourth Amendment  protects individuals from unreasonable searches.  I simply could not see how using infra red pictures that had been installed by the proprietor could be seen as unreasonable and whether it would even apply in this case. I pulled up the website from this snippet and continued reading (https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/search_and_seizure).  

I just could not see how the defendants argument in (A) could hold up (that his/her constitutional rights were being infringed) and stopped the ticker a few minutes early confident that I had the right choice.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 15%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 85%
