column7: On initial reading I had no idea what was the correct choice,  but I could see it was very time dependant.
column10: After my research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 70%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 30%
column12:
On initial reading I had no idea what was the correct choice, but I could see it was very time dependant. 

After reading the AI explanation I went with the statistical guess of the AI being usually correct. I had no reason not to go with the AI but it looked like something the AI could get wrong.

I began my online research with looking at some unfamiliar terms using Chrome – Parkland formula, premature ventricular contractions.  I then wanted see if there was any connection to  premature ventricular contractions and choking.  This didn’t look like an immediate issue.

‘circumferential burn on the neck’   I hadn’t recognised the implications of this initially because of the language style but I realised that if someone had a serious burn all the way around their neck this may warrant a different treatment from what was standard advice. Understandably my search indicated potential throat obstruction and this brought me more towards (A) in conflict with the AI explanation.  The Google snippet indicated a ‘tourniquet effect’  I overlooked the significance of this on first sight because of the language style which seemed obscure to me.  The snippet meant choking in my vernacular. This would warrant more emphasis on (A) than (B).  However I could not see why the procedures could not be performed almost simultaneously. 

 I tried -‘Insertion of an endotracheal tube’ and neck burns.  I could see from the searches that there were a lot of potential complications from placement so it was no casual practice.

I then tried  - ‘neck burns’ and swelling

There was further confirmation you might have trouble breathing from swelling ! Also that the patient would be better sitting up to stop fluid accumulation, the latter not really relevant.

I tried – neck burns and swelling and endotracheal tube
With this search I had the answer (A) made explicit in the top snippet – ‘a decision for early intubation should be based on : deep burns to the face or neck’. 

I subsequently  found further confirmations of a decision to make an early intubation was valid in this case.

I proceeded to check how long it would take to fit such a tube.  According to nursing times it would take 30 seconds.  So I speculated that in a real situation fitting the tube in terms of time  would not compromise time considerations too much when doing (B).  Plus in any case they could be performed simultaneously if it wasn’t too distressing for the patient.

I proceeded to look at ‘fluid resuscitation’ I remembered form a previous trial that this was a difficult term for me deal with.

I tried -  can fluid resuscitation stop your body from suffocating

 At that moment I did not know if I was pursuing a blind avenue here but realised later what was obvious, that the brain would be getting starved of oxygen so ‘fluid resuscitation’ would not work because apparently this was done below the neck.

,  I was trying to see if supplying oxygenated fluids could stop someone from dying if they were choking.  I am sure there could have been a better way of describing this without being drawn into the keyword which I was confused about,  but I could not bring it to mind. 

Then I went down a blind avenue with the search – burn suffocation

Just to see if anything more emerged I tried putting option (A) and (B) together into Chrome but starting with ‘severe neck burns’.  I got a snippet that contradicted my view towards (A) that stated that if there was no massive swelling,  tube insertion (A) was not necessary.   Evidently the fire fighter had just come from a live fire incident.  I could not help thinking that at some point there had to be swelling around his neck with the extent of the burns.

Sticking with the same search there was this notion of ‘fluid creep’ which further emphasised my view towards (A).

I tried increasing the severity of the burns in the search with : 
- ‘severe neck burns’ emergency >40% burns Insertion of an endotracheal tube
vs  Administration of intravenous fluids

I did not find anything that useful except that a patient with 40% burns was lucky to alive and people with 10-20% burns die of shock after.  Anaesthesia was discussed in the snippets but this was not a choice for me. 

I tried ‘severe neck burns’ >40%,  then I plugged the patients bodily readings into Chrome just to see if anything else emerged.  I did not get anywhere with that. 

Then I tried -  ‘severe neck burns’ >40% burns best emergency treatment.

There was no mention of a tube down the throat in the search snippets.

Getting towards the end of the twenty minutes I decided to find some further confirmations of the time it took to fit an ‘endotracheal tube’.  I had initially got 30 seconds from nursing times and now started to get ‘5 minutes’ typically from the snippets.  This  was vexatious to me because if for some reason the tube could not be fitted at almost the same time as option (B) was being set up 5 minutes, it could mean life or death.
    
There was something else, in a real situation there may not be enough staff on hand. I noted that Larkhill Community Hospital from this terminology suggested it  is Uk based.  Community hospitals tend to have less sophisticated equipment and less resources generally.  From many personal experiences with close relatives the NHS is appalling anyway I am afraid.   Staff availability is not the best, so I expect there will be more time pressure to do the jobs sequentially.

Factors against (A) – the patient did not yet have a swollen face, worst scenario 5 minutes may be life of death to get (B) set up,  and a commodity hospital with probably limited resources may not have the manpower or resources to do (A) and (B) quickly and at the same time. 

I would have put the slider to 96% towards (A) but with these confounding factors I put it to 70% towards (A), the insertion of an endotracheal tube in contradiction to the AI’s choice.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 50%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 50%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 11%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 89%
column20: After reading the AI explanation I went with the statistical guess of the AI being usually correct. I had no reason not to go with the AI but it looked like something the AI could get wrong.

column7: On initially reading the question I had no idea what the correct answer was.  Additionally because there were more variations of words between the two options I speculated that this was going to be more difficult than some of the other Lojban trials.
column10: After my research: A (do gleki coâ€™a lo nu ra moâ€™u jukpa): 96%; B (do gleki coâ€™a ku moâ€™u lo nu ra jukpa): 4%
column12:
On initially reading the question I had no idea what the correct answer was.  Additionally because there were more variations of words between the two options I speculated that this was going to be more difficult than some of the other Lojban trials. 

After reading the AI explanation I put the slider higher than my average level of confidence in AI answers because it looked plausible to me.  

When doing the online research I tried to concentrate on Lojban grammar mostly and tried to combine it with significant extracts from the sentences.  Then I moved to searching for direct translations of significant parts of the two sentences.  

I began my online research in Chrome with -  Lojban grammar ku

I chose ku because according to the AI it was significant  as being out of place in the sentence plus it was one of the words that were different in the two sentences.  If I could find examples of usage and ideally examples of it being used incorrectly that would help with my final answer a great deal.

I looked at truncated descriptions of ‘ku’ in the Google snippets I gathered that it was a ‘terminator’ or something to separate parts of a sentence in Lojban. This rang true with the AI explanation although the AI did not use this term. From the snippets I pulled up a ‘Lojban Cheatsheet’ (tmh.conlang.org/lojban/cheatsheet.html) to pick up some short cuts hopefully to Lojban grammar.

From the cheatsheet I could see there were references to putting Ku after le,lo and la but nothing after co’a  suggesting by default that it could be out of place as described by the AI.  This deduction was by no means definitive.

I tried – co’a ku lojban          then,  ‘co’a’+ lojban

I tried co’a ku without the inverted commas first just to see what came up. Nothing much useful came up so I narrowed the search by adding inverted commas.   If there were example of ‘co’a ku’ in sentences it might serve to refute the AI’s assertion that ku was out of place in the sentence structure of answer (B).  My only deduction was by default again that co’a and ku don’t have any instances of being put together in a phrase.

From the snippets I pulled up a site on Lojban basics (lojban.io/courses/introduction/3/) Found examples of ku in how it should be used which was nothing like option (B) but no examples of incorrect usage which would have been more useful.

I had more direct try at finding incorrect usage of ku with -  incorrect grammar Lojban + ‘co’a ku’

I couldn’t see anything from the snippets so I pulled up a book on Lojban(la-lojban.github.io…) I used the local search and used a search trick to zone in on what I wanted.  When doing searches in journals you can get a large quantity of search results because that combination of letters are in many words, so I just put spaces to the back and front of the word.  This worked fine for ‘ku’ or rather ‘ ku ’. I read more about the correct usage of ku and then moved onto another line of investigation with the time remaining.

I plugged in – ‘co’a lo’ + lojban grammar

This was from option (A) and described by the AI as correct usage. From the snippets I pulled up a rather extensive tome on Lojban Grammar  (theswissbay.ch/pdf/Books…..). 
In this pdf I tried -  co’a lo     and got nothing. 

Then I tried -  co’a      and got a few hits.   I did not find anything directly useful for making my choices of options.

I used the last few minutes with online translators. Using Stars21 (stars21.com/translator/lojban/english) I tried – co’a lo (from option(A))  and got ‘it’s starting’
I then tried – co’a ku (from option(B)) and got   ‘it started’. 

I had run out of time so I stopped the time.  I did not find anything to contradict the AI but this was more by what I didn’t find than what I did.  The AI explanation held together well based on my limited knowledge of Lojban, so I was reasonably confident that the AI had got it right and I pulled the slider up just a few more degrees for answer (A).
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (do gleki coâ€™a lo nu ra moâ€™u jukpa): 50%; B (do gleki coâ€™a ku moâ€™u lo nu ra jukpa): 50%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (do gleki coâ€™a lo nu ra moâ€™u jukpa): 92%; B (do gleki coâ€™a ku moâ€™u lo nu ra jukpa): 8%
column20: After reading the AI explanation I put the slider higher than my average level of confidence in AI answers because it looked plausible to me.

column7: On initial reading I had no idea what the correct answer but I was curious how schizophrenia and homelessness may factor in this trial, if at all.
column10: After my research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 35%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 65%
column12:
On initial reading I had no idea what the correct answer but I was curious how schizophrenia and homelessness may factor in this trial, if at all.

After reading the AI explanation I went with my standard level of confidence for the AI being usually correct.

After some online reading I was initially baffled as to why  intravenous erythromycin had been presented as an option that might challenge (A). However towards the end of the 20 minutes I was struck with a dilemma in that  intravenous erythromycin may be valid if the actual diagnosis was Pseudo-SBO here a real obstruction did not exist.  Add to this schizophrenia and the potential of anti-psychotic use which are massive confounding factors producing their own sets of gut problems that are not well characterized, then you have a very confusing picture.

I began my online investigations with copy and pasting the whole description into Chrome to see what Google produced with this.  For all I knew it could be some classic case.  Nothing much came out of that so I proceeded with looking up  unfamiliar terms.   I then continued to see if there was anything concerning with the bodily metrics.  There was not much to attract anything worth investigating with this.
 
I tried putting option (A) -  Intravenous erythromycin     into Chrome in isolation to see what it was known for. I gathered it was for treating infections. Then I added ‘side effects’ onto the search to see if anything useful came up.  Quite a few slightly serious side effects but nothing to attract my attention except that these side effects were  a good reason not to use it.

I tried -  Intravenous erythromycin and abdominal pain and vomiting

Unfortunately this search centred around the side effects of erythromycin. This which included both abdominal pain and vomiting  so I would speculate it would not be a great way to ease these symptoms.  Putting a tube down someone’s throat would hold mechanical risks but nothing like this.

I tried -  Intravenous erythromycin used today.

I was satisfied that it was still in  contemporary usage but nothing to suggest it was the best choice.

I moved my search to option (B) and put it into Chrome
 - Nasogastric tube decompression

Straight forward enough moving the contents of the stomach out through a tube.  I had underestimated the risk factors though  because the patient could die of vomiting or getting bits of matter or liquid stuck in the lungs. I pulled up an image from Google so I could visualise it better and dispel any flawed assumptions.

I shifted my search to schizophrenia and homelessness.  I couldn’t see how this might impact my choices.

I tried -  Schizophrenic homeless man abdominal pain and vomiting

I started getting search results linked to gut problems and schizophrenia and remembered I had come across this sometime and knew it was poorly researched but very significant regarding mental states.  I also read that this condition could induce many of the symptoms that I was seeing in the description.  Furthermore the trial description did not assert it was SBO, that was an assumption made by the AI.

I pulled up the journal from the top snippet.  Gastroenterology issues in schizophrenia: why the gut matters (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc….)  Anti-psychotics were mentioned and I began thinking about if the patient did not have SBO.

I put in – homelessness and drug use     to get a statistic on the proportion of homeless people involved in drug use which was high as expected.

I pulled up some symptoms from the question description and tried :

- homelessness and distended, tympanitic, diffusely tender abdomen + drug use

I speculated that the homelessness aspect could involve eating food from skips that held a  cocktail of undesirable bacteria.

As a wild card I tried – homelessness and fentanyl

Nothing particularly useful came up with this search although nausea and vomiting were mentioned as side effects.

I put the AI assumption into Chrome -  small bowel obstruction (SBO) 

I got predictable results and nothing much new so I tried - SBO (A) vs (B) :

- SBO  Intravenous erythromycin  vs Nasogastric tube decompression 

 For SBO option (B) was coming up from the snippets but I still had suspicions that SBO may be a false assumption. I pulled up a journal from the top snippet ‘Management of small bowel obstruction and systematic review of treatment without nasogastric tube decompression’  (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov….).  I gathered that option (B) was  standard practice but some patients rejected it because of the discomfort. 

I tried – symptoms of  SBO deceiving ‘not SBO’ 

I pulled up another journal ‘Bowel Obstruction...’ (m.clevelandclinic.org…)

I came across the term ‘pseudo-obstruction’ in there. Where you experience the symptoms of bowel obstruction, but it does not exist. Poorly researched.

I tried – ‘ pseudo SBO’

I found it was a genuine condition with almost the same symptoms and speculated that if no obstruction existed would a tube still be the best option ? This was the dilemma I found at the last moment. The snippet was from a respectable journal ‘Intestinal Pseudo Obstruction’ so I pulled it up. (ncbi.nlm.gov….) I gathered it was called Ogilvie Syndrome. I noticed option (B) was still suggested for early management which I did not see rationale for if nothing was there.

I gradually lost confidence in the AI answer (B) during the trial and that accounts my pulling the slider back a considerable amount.  I speculated that option (B) was standard practice but I had considerable doubts given that  we had a homeless schizophrenic which was going to ramp up the probability of the true condition being Pseudo-SBO and the best initial treatment something to reduce infection like option (A).
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 50%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 50%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 11%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 89%
column20: After reading the AI explanation I went with my standard level of confidence for the AI being usually correct.

column7: On first reading the trial I thought doing a CT scan would be best as a precaution. So (B) was my choice.
column10: After my research: A (Wait and watch): 99%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 1%
column12:
On first reading the trial I thought doing a CT scan would be best as a precaution. So (B) was my choice.

On reading the AI explanation I changed my view to (A)  because I hadn’t taken into account the health risks from radiation associated with Ct scans. However I was not extremely confident in the AI’s choice until I had investigated further.

I started my online search into Chrome with :   -  mass on the right side of his scrotum

I gathered from the top snippet from a respected source that it was usually benign and with an outside chance of cancer. Could be an indication of other conditions.   Would someone want something like that hanging out of them ?

- I pulled up the site from Cleveland Clinic (my.clevelandclinic.org…) I read through the article.

I added : - and Ct scan     to the end of the last search.

From the snippets on the top page of Google I pulled up a page that mentioned Ct scans from the Mayo Clinic (mayoclinic.org…).  I saw that there were an array of tests to do before a Ct scan was considered necessary.  This indicated to me that a Ct scan would only be necessary if there were indications from the other safer tests.

I felt I already had what I needed, which would be a high confidence in option (A) in congruence with the AI explanation. I continued just in case I had missed something.

I tried:  - scrotal mass when Ct scan justified

I pulled up a site from the top snippet  ‘Imaging Testicular and Scrotal Masses...’ (ncbi.nlm.gov….)
I gathered that radiologists are reluctant to do scrotum scans because  the scans are confusing to characterise.  In the journal there were outlines of  symptoms  that would be a cause for concern.
I flicked through them and almost nothing aligned with the trial description of our patient. The only outlier was  if the growth had an irregular shape.  A ‘bags of worms’ texture from the question description would qualify as irregular I would imagine.

I continued with this line of investigation in Chrome : -   scrotal mass  ‘bags of worms’ texture

 Varicocele was highlighted in the top snippet which aligns with this texture and was suggested by the AI.  The source was ‘Men’s Health’ (menshealth,com….) which I am not 100% confident in  but I pulled it up anyway. I was happy to accept the Men’s Health layman’s description of varicocele, if little else.   Varicoceles can be bad news for fertility I gathered, so that could be a reason to go further with tests and surgery I speculated.

I tried: - scrotal mass varicocele
Read the top description on the top snippet for background (Mayo Clinic).  I then added to the search with:

- right side + ‘when Ct’

What I was looking for were further examples of when it would be a good chioce to do a Ct scan. I already had descriptions of red flags from previous searches which did not align with any good reasons to do Ct scans with our cab driver. I was just making sure I had not missed anything.  From the top snippet from Midwest Institute I got the ‘watchful waiting’  suggestion again in congruence with the AI choice of options (A). I pulled up the article and did not see anything to refute the Ai’s choice.

I tried a further search in Chrome: - scrotal mass distinct from the testicle and epididymis.
I did see anything useful I did not already know now.

I added : - varicocele + no pain+    to the beginning of the previous search
I pulled up another article by the Mayo Clinic which discussed  varicoceles as the main topic. I pulled up another article about varicoceles from the Cleveland clinic.  

By this point I felt like I had read enough to have a very high confidence in answer (A) in congruence with the AI and so I stopped the timer a few minutes early.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Wait and watch): 30%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 70%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Wait and watch): 89%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 11%
column20: On reading the AI explanation I changed my view to (A)  because I hadn’t taken into account the health risks from radiation associated with Ct scans. However I was not extremely confident in the AI’s choice until I had investigated further.

column7: After my initial reading I thought the claim would be unsuccessful (A). It had some similarities to a previous trial I had worked through so I was not completely naive at the beginning.  There were a number of different issues that had to be in place and I did not think a verbal contract unwitnessed with the student’s deceased father for an allowance would be enforceable in a US court. For this reason I went with (A) but was not greatly confident in my choice.
column10: After my research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 95%; B (successful.): 5%
column12:
After my initial reading I thought the claim would be unsuccessful (A). It had some similarities to a previous trial I had worked through so I was not completely naïve at the beginning.  There were a number of different issues that had to be in place and I did not think a verbal contract unwitnessed with the student’s deceased father for an allowance would be enforceable in a US court. For this reason I went with (A) but was not greatly confident in my choice.

After reading the AI explanations  I was not confident at all in AI’s choice of (B).  Firstly the case was very  long and convoluted, it looked like something our current generation of AI’s could get lost in. Secondly I spotted an error  in the AI’s argument regarding the father’s signed statement.  There was no mention of the student’s allowance in this letter and the AI stated there was. I put the slider up a few more degrees against the AI’s choice.

The Ai had made asserted a number of points.  All the arguments but one seemed reasonable to me which I attributed to the AI’s getting overwhelmed with all the details and becoming ‘sketchy’ which I have seen before in my daily activities.  I decided to concentrate on this aspect mainly during my online searches.

I began my online search with :

- wills + verbal consent      then added:    + ‘us law’

I was getting frustrated with Uk hits which are not useful here.  With hindsight I would have switched on my VPN and found a US server but in honesty this finesse did not occur to me and I was mindful of the timer running.  Unravelling the key features of this detailed case took a sizeable portion of the time available.

I changed my search to -  wills + verbal consent  + ‘american law’
I gathered that most wills needed to be executed in writing with two witnesses. 

I looked in the ‘People also ask’ section and there were one or two sections that looked like they could be useful like such as ‘is verbal consent acceptable’.  I continued down the page and found a useful looking snippet. I continued to pull up the ‘AllLaw’  website (alllaw.com…) It suggested that oral wills typically don’t work. Also in most states it has to be in writing.

I refined the terms of my search: - verbal agreement after death + ‘american law’

A snippet was stating almost all contracts were still valid after death.   I was already familiar with contracts continuing after  death and really wanted something closer to my case. 

  Further snippets continued to emphasise that verbal contracts are very difficult to enforce after death and this was supporting my choice of (A).

I tried  - ‘unfinished verbal promises after death’ + ‘american law’

I had satisfied myself that as far as I could ascertain in the time available that the first AI assertion would not hold.  I moved on to the last assertion from the AI, that just because the executor turned down the student’s claim did not have  any bearing in a court and furthermore a challenge in the courts could still be made.

I tried:  - claim denied by the executor + ‘american law’
I pulled up a snippet ‘Executor mishandling….’ (hchlawyers.com…)  I did not see anything I could use.

I put the slider up to 95% for (A) because the AI had made a mistake and could not defend the case on the strength of the other points. The remaining 5% accounts  just for uneasiness because the AI is usually correct and I am not a solicitor.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 65%; B (successful.): 35%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 75%; B (successful.): 25%
column20: After reading the AI explanations  I was not confident at all in AI’s choice of (B).  Firstly the case was very  long and convoluted, it looked like something our current generation of AI’s could get lost in. Secondly I spotted an error  in the AI’s argument regarding the father’s signed statement.  There was no mention of the student’s allowance in this letter and the AI stated there was. I put the slider up a few more degrees against the AI’s choice.

column7: On my initial viewing of the trial the Lojban option (A) looked preferable to me.  I had spend time in the other trials looking at Lojban and had got some understanding of ‘ku’.  My decision was not a technical one, option (A)  just seemed to look right.
column10: After my research: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 80%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 20%
column12:
On my initial viewing of the trial the Lojban option (A) looked preferable to me.  I had spend time in the other trials looking at Lojban and had got some understanding of ‘ku’.  My decision was not a technical one, option (A)  just seemed to look right. 

I spent time trying really working with the AI explanation and I felt like it made sense to me, in that the first sentence was separated in the right way so my initial intuition seemed vindicated. 

I don’t think the internet search really helped that much on this occasion.  I could get translations of certain words without any problem but the trial was much subtler than that and the translators were a long way from making sense of full phrases. If the translators were not thinking in Lojban they would get nowhere for instance ‘cmoni’ could mean tweet, bark or neigh depending on the creature which whilst elegant, could be confusing for a translator.

On other projects when I had come across a fairly obscure phrase or word spelling, and physical dictionaries were becoming difficult (with taxonomy for instance) I often used a technique where the spelling that got the most hits  was often often the most dominant one. I cannot say this shortcut worked with Lojban.  My thinking was that if there were phases in common usage in the Lojban community there would be examples,  and word combinations that did not work so well there would be much less hits or none at all.  Normally this kind technique worked well for a host of topics but only marginally with Lojban I found. It worked with two words at a time but for both correct and possibly incorrect word combinations.  Maybe if correct usage  becomes more widespread from its connection with AI this may change.

I began by looking up a few words and word combinations in ‘vlasisku.lojban...’ which  I find is one of the better translators online. ‘ co’u ’ was congruent with the AI explanation but it stopped short with longer combinations such as ‘ co’u ku ‘ from option (A). 

I tried: -  ‘lo nu ’    from option (B) on the same site and came up with a translation that was congruent with the AI description.  I did this with a number of others words in option (A) and (B) and they were all congruent with the AI description.  If the AI was going to make a mistake with this trial I speculated it was more likely in the grammar and overall meanings of each sentence which was much harder to assess without a deeper understanding of Lojban grammar.

I  put a shorter extract of option (B) into Chrome – co’u lo nu    The extract came up in an obscure site with a post from 2010. I was not familiar with it, Tatoeba (tatoeba.org/en….) . I pulled it up.  It had a  translator.  I put in the whole of option (A) and got nothing. I tried ‘cmoni’ and got numerous examples but I was already familiar with the different meanings of this word for different creatures which I understood as a feature of Lojban.  I tried an English-Lojban translation putting in the whole phase from the trial and got nothing.
 
 I decided to try another translator. Into Chrome : Lojban translator
I pulled up a main Lojban site just titled ‘Lojban’ on that page (mw.lojban.org…) then moved to another site. I pulled up ‘Stars21’ (stars21.com/translator…).  I tried an extract of the English in the trial: 

- it was quiet until        got a Lojban translation that was slightly different to options (A) and (B) with a number of the same words, which got me nowhere.

I tried putting into Chrome: -   co’u lo nu      and pulled up a Wikipedia site (en.wiktionary.org/wiki….) 
Using option (B) :   -    co’u which had examples which included:   co’u lo nu    So apparently it was acceptable to use this combination of words.

I tried a longer extracts in option (B) in Chrome: - ‘smaji co’u lo nu’    That combination of words was not presented in Google, just stray words or pairs of words.

I tried a longer extract from option (A) - ‘smaji co’u ku’ lojban    and nothing useful.

I had run out of time. On this occasion I brought the slider back slightly because if anything my searches supported option (B), but it was very inconclusive.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 60%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 40%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 85%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 15%

column7: On first reading this trial I went with (A) based on my superficial knowledge of the 5th Amendment from popular films and the news. My impression of the fifth  was that in any case criminal or civil case a person could bail out at any moment by pleading the fifth.
column10: After my research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 4%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 96%
column12:
On first reading this trial I went with (A) based on my superficial knowledge of the 5th Amendment from popular films and the news. My impression of the fifth  was that in any case criminal or civil case a person could bail out at any moment by pleading the fifth.  

On reading the AI explanation and choice of (B) I just could not buy it.  I suspected the AI was reeling out plausible untruths.  Therefore I discounted it and stayed with my original confidence levels.

After my online research I had found pretty clear evidence that my initial view was incorrect in this case and I shifted view in support of the AI’s choice of (B) with a high level of confidence.

I began my online search with: - fifth amendment + self-incrimination
The top snippet reeled off  the well known material I already knew,  de facto knowledge.  Paraphrasing – you don’t have to testify if it incriminates you, you can plead the fifth…

I pulled up a post from the snippet from the Cornell Law School (law.cornell.edu...) which seemed to occupy quite a prominent position online judging from my searches.  I found a part which stated that the moment the witness takes the stand or says something self-incriminating when asked specific questions  they waive the fifth. This supported (B) congruent with the AI answer in clear terms. 

I scrolled down to the ‘People also Ask’ section of Google search and found ‘What is the fifth amendment privilege against compulsory self-incrimination’  The snippet from Practical Law (uk.practicallaw…)  was the a repeat of the fifth. I pulled up the site to investigate further .  It was a Uk site, but they were discussing US law. They appearing to support option (A) but did not go into enough details.

In Chrome I tried :  - fifth amendment + ‘avoid self-incrimination’      
I saw mention of  the ‘Miranda v’ case in the snippet which it labelled as  a landmark  case in this area. The rest of the snippet was just another re-iteration of the main gist of the fifth.

I added ‘waiver’ and tweaked the search a little : -  ‘waiver fifth amendment’ + self-incrimination 
I found something useful in the top snippet from SMU scholar ‘waiver the fifth: What level of incrimination….’ .         This was discussing that once the witness had answered an incriminating question he/she loses the option to plead the fifth on related questions. It also stated that what determines the waiver is if it was sufficiently incriminating to qualify.  

 I pulled up the PDF, looking through the pages it was a monograph on the area I needed to look into.   I gathered the authors of this account discussed the fifth in terms of ‘privilege’  and two situations characterised the confusion and debate (pp.2). 

One is when the witness is asked a potentially incriminating question and the witness has the choice of answering or refusing. This is where the issue of how incriminating the answer would need to be for the fifth to be claimed.

 The second situation occurs when the witness has decided to answer the question. As far as I can see just the act of walking into the witness box is an admission to answer the question and waiver the fifth (pp.15 and 20).   If she wanted to plead the fifth she would have needed to do it earlier.   This appeared to be confirmed in a very expansive way in the law journal (SMU)  and in a more distilled form in the  Cornell Law article.

The extended discussion on this legal dilemma was very  convoluted so there is no way I can be 100% on this without spending all day reading, but from what I had found online I am highly confident in favour of (B) in agreement with the AI.

column7: On first reading I went for (B) somewhat confident towards the evidence being inadmissible. I was not going into this trial completely blind because I had spent time only the day before working on the fifth in a previous trial, so I had a head start.  I already knew that defendant B could remain silent and that silence should not be construed as an admission of guilt.  This looked too easy to me so I was looking for a nuance in some part of the case to make matters more finely balanced.
column10: After my research: A (Permissible as evidence, on the grounds that a confession from one participant in a crime is legally admissible against the other participant.): 1%; B (Impermissible as evidence, given the situation, there was no duty or obligation for accused B to respond to the accusations.): 99%
column12:
On first reading I went for (B) somewhat confident towards the evidence being inadmissible.
I was not going into this trial completely blind because I had spent time only the day before working on the fifth in a previous trial, so I had a head start.  I already knew that defendant B could remain silent and that silence should not be construed as an admission of guilt.  This looked too easy to me so I was looking for a nuance in some part of the case to make matters more finely balanced.

 The AI choice of (B) served to reinforce my confidence in this choice. I pulled the slider much higher than my statistical estimation of the AI being usually correct.  Much of the explanation confirmed my own understanding of the fifth but I needed to look into the hearsay rule a little more.

I began my online search with:  Miranda rule + ‘us law’
From the top snippet (Cornell Law) Right to remain silent… et cetera.  Knew this by heart from popular TV.  I continued to pull up the article (law.cornell.edu...) and reminded myself of some of the finer details.

I continued with : ‘us law’+ ‘arrestee A accuses B’+ fifth
This was rather clumsy but at that moment I could not think of a better way of putting it hoping Google search would find its way towards something I could use. From the top snippet I pulled up another article from Cornell on the fifth (law.cornell.edu.fifth_amendment) At this point the timer reset itself on its own volition, but it did not matter because I had timer on the screen recorder. Only drawback was that it did not have an alarm feature which I was finding useful.  
  I read in this site that in some instances silence can be deemed an admission of guilt.  This contradicted my understanding of the fifth and cast some doubt on my choice of (B).  I hoped to try and find which instances at some point in this trial.

I tried: - confession + hearsay rule + ‘us law’     I gathered from the top snippet there were two tests in order to allow hearsay as  admissible against a criminal defendant (Roberts, 448 U.S. 56 (1980):

1. The declarant had to be unavailable.
2. Have to make the statement in circumstances that indicate it is trustworthy and credible in order to be reliable.

Our case falls down on both counts in that the declarant was available and the evidence was unreliable because it was coming from someone who had been arrested and  may have been lying to protect there own interests. This snippet was from Wikipedia which is good but not the best. I scrolled down ‘People also ask’ to find a better source.  I pulled up the Cornell article on hearsay (law.cornell.edu/wex/hearsay…)  I did not find anything particularly useful.

I tried: -  ‘right to remain silent’+ ‘us law’     In the snippets there did appear to be some examples of cases where the defendant’s right to remain silent was used against them, which seemed contradictory to me.

I added: -   + ‘admission of guilt’             to the end of the previous search.  I gathered from a snippet that if a defendant is on the stand and is accused of something then goes silent this could be construed as admission of guilt.  Regarding our silent defendant this was not applicable because the circumstances were different since  he was silent throughout.  This bolstered my confidence further in favour of (B).

Scrolling down to the FindLaw site (findlaw.com/criminal...) I could see a potential problem with choice of (B),  that the accused defendants testimony was ‘impermissible’.  This site emphasised that the defendant has to be very explicit in invoking the fifth which infers that our defendant B may not be covered unless he or his solicitor expresses it in a very direct way.  However,  according to this site a defendant has to waive his right to the fifth also.   He could do this by speaking, which our defendant did not do. 
  In clarification on this same site it states that prosecutors are not permitted to attribute guilt by a defendants silence but it is still possible that a jury might.  

I followed the link ‘self-incrimination’            I got to  ‘Fifth Amendment Protection Against Self-Incrimination’      (constitution.findlaw.com/amendment5/annotation04.html)  This site went over a variety of cases and was something of a monograph on self-incrimination.  It didn’t give me anything more that I had not already worked through earlier.

I tried:  -  ‘silent but did not call the fifth’ and then added + ‘us law’
I clicked on the top site, MoloLamken LLP (mololamken.com…)  This site did not give me anything useful and from my recent knowledge of the fifth it had errors.

Going over everything the choice I had made was certainly not as clear cut as I first thought but I had by this point got enough knowledge to go confidently with the AI in support of (B).

column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Permissible as evidence, on the grounds that a confession from one participant in a crime is legally admissible against the other participant.): 6%; B (Impermissible as evidence, given the situation, there was no duty or obligation for accused B to respond to the accusations.): 94%

Much of the explanation confirmed my own understanding of the fifth but I needed to look into the hearsay rule a little more.

column7: On first reading the question I was confident that the answer was option (A). I had come across some US contract law in a previous trial and the written offer with a written acceptance looked like a valid contract to me.  The leasehold argument in option (B) did not seem relevant.
column10: After my research: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 100%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 0%
column12:
On first reading the question I was confident that the answer was option (A). I had come across some US contract law in a previous trial and the written offer with a written acceptance looked like a valid contract to me.  The leasehold argument in option (B) did not seem relevant.

After reading the AI explanation and choice of (A) this concurred with my choice and I was very confident.  

I began my online search with  ‘contract law’ +‘written offer’ + ‘was accepted’ + renague+‘us law’
Google helped me change the Uk English ‘renague’  to American English altering to ‘renege’ this would help me get more American hits.

I scrolled down the snippets pulled up the CFI article ‘Reneging’ (corporatefinanceinstitute.com...)
I gather from this account discussing contract law that if the uncle is still within the 72 hours cooling off period he could renague without getting sued.  Not sure if this aspect of the law applies in this particular case.  
Just for the sake of discussion since the Uncle sent the offer by letter and the nephew returned her acceptance by letter it may be over the 72 hours from the time going through the postal system.  However there is no indication of this in the question so it is conceivable that the uncle is within the 72 hours cooling off period and safe from being sued. However option (B) would still be invalid so we would be left with two invalid options. I can only presume we are the past 72 hours cooling off period to continue.

 Looking through the current batch of snippets there were mentions of ‘compelling ground to renege’.  More reading would be needed, but our case did not appear to have any such compelling grounds. 

I attempted a ‘long shot’ zoning in tightly on antique businesses.  There was a good chance that my search would be too narrow to bear useful results here:

I tried : - antiques business + ‘contract law’ +‘written offer’ + ‘was accepted’ + renege+‘us law’
I scrolled down the snippets and pulled up an article by USlegal on Contract Law (business.uslegal.com/contract-law/).  This site began by describing key features of written contracts I was already acquainted with.  Namely the offer in writing, ‘consideration’ - financial offer in this case, then there has to be acceptance by the other party.

Mutual agreement needed all in writing.  Going back to our previous discussion of what might make the uncle’s offer invalid this article described some examples.  Paraphrasing if he wrote the letter offering the business at gunpoint, or had just been sectioned.  These circumstances would make an arguable case. This could make the contract ‘voidable’.  From the question description no such circumstance existed so the case was not voidable.  

There was also mention of ‘intent’ if the offer was made as a joke, it could be invalid.  Our offer was sent in writing without any humour as far as can be discerned.  From the perspective of a reasonable person this cannot be a valid argument.  The article continued to discuss  areas not valid to our case.  There  was mention of the ‘mailbox rule’ in that the letter of acceptance has to be deemed to be received.  This was affirmative in our case.

If the nephew was under 21 (some states 18 years) the uncle could argue that his nephew lacked ‘contractual capacity’ and did not know what his nephew was getting into and for his own good the uncle felt he had to renege. I did not have any information regarding the nephews age and in any event such a circumstance appears rather contrived.

I tried: - ‘us law’ + ‘buy retail business’ + ‘breach of contract’ + ‘offer in writing’ 
I thought to add retail business rather than ‘antiques business’ to have more chance of getting relevant hits.  I pulled up a site by Hanon Neighman & Wright (hnwlaw.com...)  that was more specific to my case but I did not see anything further that I needed.

I had enough to inform my choice but I continued just to see if I had missed anything.  In the last few minutes I decided to try and find a monograph on this area of law adding: 

pdf+‘us law’ + ‘buy retail business’ + ‘breach of contract’ + ‘offer in writing’ 
After scrolling through the snippets I pulled up a site by the Judicial Branch of California (selfhelp.courts.ca.gov….) It was just a re-iteration of material I was already aware of.

I tried  : - contract + ‘us law’ + ‘offer in writing’
I pulled up an article by FindLaw (findlaw.com/smallbusiness…) ‘What contracts are required to be in writing?’ I did not learn anything new.

I tried  : - contract + ‘us law’ + ‘offer in writing’ + retail
I pulled up ‘Fundamentals of contract law for businesses’ by Ontra (ontra.ia.blog…….) I did not see anything further that I needed.

I was extremely confident in my choice of (A) concurring with the AI.

column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 96%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 4%

column7: On first reading I went with (A) with no great amount of confidence. I had a slight concern with the sentence structure and use of misleading pronouns.  I speculated that this could be a confounding factor with the AI’s choice and explanation.   ‘the respondent wishes to introduce evidence demonstrating that the expert witness had previously submitted false testimony during HIS personal marital dissolution proceedings.’  This is ambiguous and could refer to either respondent or expert witness.
column10: After my research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 4%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 96%
column12:
On first reading I went with (A) with no great amount of confidence. I had a slight concern with the sentence structure and use of misleading pronouns.  I speculated that this could be a confounding factor with the AI’s choice and explanation.

 ‘the respondent wishes to introduce evidence demonstrating that the expert witness had previously submitted false testimony during HIS personal marital dissolution proceedings.’  This is ambiguous and could refer to either respondent or expert witness.


On reading the AI explanation I changed my view towards (B) concurring with the AI.  It looked plausible but I would have to check the details. 
 It was  concerning  me that option (B) did not fit well with the issue in the question with the respondent wanting to add evidence to discredit the expert witness, which could fall into the category of ‘extrinsic evidence’ and not be allowed. Option (B) seemed to be answering a different question.

I began my online research on Chrome with :  ‘expert witness’ + Rule 608(b) + ‘false testimony’  

I gathered from the top snippet that it was permitted to look into an expert witness’s misconduct on the stand, in order to attack his/her credibility if it helps to prove his/her level of truthfulness.  

From the snippets I pulled up an article from The University of Chicago ‘Proving Corruption: Extrinsic Evidence of Uncharged Perjury’ (lawreview.uchicago.edu….)
Describes exceptions to extrinsic evidence and ‘bad acts’ are permitted to be proved under cross-examination because witness statements are not extrinsic evidence.  I gathered that the point of restricting certain testimonies was to prevent a waste of the courts time effectively making  a trial within a trial. 

I pulled up the article from the top snippet of the same search from Cornell Law School: ‘Rule 608. A Witness’s Character for Truthfulness or Untruthfulness’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_608#….)

Extrapolating narrowly from the trial question the respondent wants to call the expert witness and wants him to be cross-examined in such a way that the expert witness damns himself because of the his past false testimony.

According to various cases described in this accounts eg. Mc Mormick,49: pp.105   Attacks to establish untruthfulness of a witness were admitted, as long as it was direct or the ‘extrinsic evidence’ rules could be in enacted.

I tried: - ‘alleged violation of a  violation of a business agreement’ + ‘previous false testimony’ + ‘expert witness’ (too much Uk)  then I added to the beginning: -  ‘us law’ +

From the top snippet I pulled up the article from Cornell Law School ‘Rule 702: Testimony by Expert Witness’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_702)

It went into what an expert witness can discuss and how to assess the validity of his/her testimony. The account did not engage with undermining the expert witness with regards to truthfulness or false testimony. For my trial question I surmised that is was not necessary to get involved in that level of detail in this particular subset of law  so the article was not useful. 

Scrolling down the snippets I pulled up from Cornell Law School  ‘Credible Witness’ ( https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/credible_witness )  

 This listed six ways to prove a witness was not credible.  Number 2 on this list ‘ reputation for untruthfulness’ corresponded with the trial question that the respondent wanted to establish that the expert witness made previous false statements. 

From the snippets I pulled up an article by the Expert Institute ‘False Expert Statements: Legal Consequences for Expert Witnesses and Attorneys’ (expertinstitute.com/resources/insights/false…)

It gave some background information on the potential legal consequences for false testimony from expert witnesses. I gathered actual legal action against them was very rare.  It did not offer me any further useful insight towards my case.

By this point I noticed that the timer had run down but not gone off and the Modulo questions page had reset itself so I went back and returned the sliders to their original places finally adding a high level of confidence towards (B) concurring with the AI.

Option (B) seemed to be answering a different question.

column7: On first reading I thought that (A) looked like the best answer, lawyers are not known for their charitable acts towards clients and the letter was on the lawyer’s desk.    Furthermore  in option (B) I could not understand what ‘disadvantage’ could be referring to.
column10: After my research: A (Yes, because the clientâ€™s message and the attorneyâ€™s actions resulted in a contract implied-in-fact.): 96%; B (Yes, because the attorneyâ€™s response to the clientâ€™s note led to a disadvantage to him.): 4%
column12:
On first reading I thought that (A) looked like the best answer, lawyers are not known for their charitable acts towards clients and the letter was on the lawyer’s desk.   
Furthermore  in option (B) I could not understand what ‘disadvantage’ could be referring to.

On reading the AI choice it concurred with my own.  The explanation looked plausible and now I understood what was meant by ‘disadvantage’.  Option (A) still looked the best and I was quite confident.

I began my online research in Chrome with: - ‘sharp practice’ + ‘implied-in-fact’ + ‘implied contract’
Looking at the top snippet (Cornell Law) it concurred with  the AI explanation. I proceeded to pull up the article ‘contract implied in fact’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/contract_implied_in_fact…)  The short account concurred with the AI explanation. 

I followed a link on this site ‘express contracts’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/express_contract)

 From reading the description I did not think that the case in our trail was like this because there was no explicit written or oral contract, so that kind of contract could be discounted from my investigations.  
   I was of a mind that we were indeed considering an implied contract. For instance when you buy an ice cream cornet from a van you expect to pay.  The client could have been naïve or she could have just changed her mind regarding the yacht and just not wanted to pay. 

I clicked back to the ‘contract implied in fact’ article and clicked on the ‘implied in law’ article
(law.cornell.edu/wex/contract_implied_in_fact) 

Apparently from this account  this was equivalent to a ‘constructive contract’ According to the case sited (Bailey v. West) for such a contract to exist amongst other features there had to be a ‘benefit’ and there did not appear to be a benefit for the client because she had decided not to buy the yacht.  

There was  at some point in time when she wanted the answer so it would have been reasonable to expect a charge, but it would also seem reasonable if their was a charge  for  the lawyer to contact the client give him a quote rather than just going ahead and doing the work.  This concurred with the AI descriptions highlighting the weaknesses in option (B).

To be a constructive contract there was also the feature of acceptance and retention by the client. Clearly there was no acceptance from the client.  There was also mention of ‘appreciation’ by the client.  This was clearly not the case.   All this looked rather dubious but legal, that the client was getting this bill.  This led me to think it was ‘sharp practice’.

I clicked back to the original search: - ‘sharp practice’ + ‘implied-in-fact’ + ‘implied contract’
I was surprise that there was so few hits regarding ‘sharp practice’. This seems a little suspect to me and with hindsight I would have used another browser. Maybe for some inscrutable algorithmic reason Google was suppressing certain useful results.

I tried: ‘unethical’ ‘implied-in-fact’ + ‘implied contract’   
      
I flicked through the short definitions in the People Also Ask section.  One of the snippets described a circumstance where the client-professional relationship has broken down and described in this context the ‘implied’ meant reflecting the intentions when the implied contract was developed. 

The snippets continued with making distinctions between quasi contracts and implied contracts.  I cannot suggest that I found this particularly useful to me.

I simplified my search with: - ‘unethical’ + ‘implied-in-fact’
Now my search was too broad.  I got hits for ‘unethical’ but not for the topic area I needed.

I tried: - ‘unethical’ + ‘implied contract’        

This search brought me to a snippet describing ‘unconscionable contracts’ which it described as unjust where one party had considerably more bargaining power.  With our case it was true to suggest that the lawyer had considerably more bargaining power because he  chose what to charge but this case looks more like a breakdown in communication rather than ‘unconscionable practice’.  Maybe if the lawyer had charged $50,000 it would be that. Plus the question did state it was a reasonable price for this service.  

In the other option there was mention of being ‘disadvantaged’ I understood this to mean the time and effort the lawyer expended in assessing the yacht contract and writing an A4 response. The solicitor should have been aware of the legal status of his actions and it would at least have been good manners to attempt some confirmation. I concurred with the AI that this defence would be unlikely to play out well in court. 

I added: - + ‘us law’ 	                      to the end of the last search

I did not see anything promising enough for the snippets on the first page so I continued with the second.

I found that the Modulo questions page had reset itself so I quickly restored the sliders back to their previous places.

I tried: -  ‘unethical’ + ‘implied-in-fact’+ ‘us law’ + ‘unfair bill’

I saw that the timer had reset itself but I continued with reference to the timer on my screen recorder. I was at the end of my 20 minutes so I closed the search and proceeded to move the slider to a high confidence in option (B) concurring with the AI.

column7: On first reading I had no idea what the correct answer was. I noticed that the case was complex and very convoluted.  I had an understanding of some of the terms but not to the legal depth I really needed in relation to US law. Furthermore the answers seemed very convoluted.
column10: After my research: A (prevail, due to the fact that Xavier deliberately negotiated and procured a quitclaim deed from Zoey in anticipation of securing the apple orchard.): 40%; B (emerge victorious, as Xavier, by offering the initial $1,500 payment, is estopped from renouncing the validity of his contractual agreement with Zoey.): 60%
column12:
On first reading I had no idea what the correct answer was. I noticed that the case was complex and very convoluted.  I had an understanding of some of the terms but not to the legal depth I really needed in relation to US law. Furthermore the answers seemed very convoluted.

On reading the AI explanation and choice I was not greatly confident in the choice of (B). Furthermore I was highly confident that there was not a good answer in the choices offered. It appeared it was a choice of which one was less worse rather than correct.

I began my online research looking up some terms.

I put into Chrome: - property warranties  define		then +‘us law’

I was only really clear on warranties in regard to retail products.  In the context of property it appeared to be some kind of assurance that facts about a property are true.

I put into Chrome: -  estopped define			then +‘us law’ 

I had seen the term in passing from these trials but I did not have a good understanding of it. I gathered that in a legal sense, which is the only sense I think existed, that it stops someone going back on something they have committed to previously.

It was difficult to see a way through this case. In Chrome I tried : 

-  quitclaim deed + ‘false premise’ + ‘us law’

From the snippets I pulled up the article ‘How to deal with Quitclaim deed fraud’ (schorr-law.com/quitclaim-deed-fraud/)

I had taken the AI definition of quitclaims as valid so saved time confirming it online. I did not think that this was a fraud case I just wanted to get some understanding of the dynamics and key features of quitclaims.  I gathered  a quitclaim deed can applied for by a fraudster to build the appearance legitimacy in property ownership. 

From the snippets I pulled up ‘Consequences of an improper quitclaim deed’ (korshaklaw.com/blog/2021/10/consequences….)

This was getting closer to what I needed with our case.  Was our quitclaim deed improper ? 
From this site I understood that quitclaim deeds could be used to record that someone has no longer has any links to a property and additionally you could add someone else to the property title.  In our case Zoey transferred her interest in the orchard to Xaxier which turned out to be precisely zero. 

Continuing with this article I gathered that quitclaim deeds are made sometimes when the title status is uncertain.  This would apply to our case because claims to the orchard were disputed.  Xavier was aware that the twins were bickering but apparently not enough to show bad faith.  If he had been privy to more details of the dispute between Zoey and Zane a case involving bad faith could have been made.  
  With regards to option (A) Zoey’s claim to the orchard with peremptory and would invalidate Zoey’s contract when it had been established that Zoey had no claim to the orchard.   Another interesting aspect of quitclaim deeds are that generally they do not involve money changing hands between the involved parties.  This was not the case in that $1500 was passed to Zoey which maybe indicates something going on that is questionable.

From this site I clicked on the link: - ‘repercussions of a quitclaim deed’ (korshaklaw.com/real-estate-litigation/)  This link led to a plug for this company and was not relevant or useful.

I continued with: -  ‘initial payment’ + estopped + ‘us law’

Scrolling down  there was a snippet from The International Journal of Business and Social Science.  This suggested that promissory estoppel was best used for defence not attack.  This cast quite some further uncertainty on option (B) since Zoey was making a claims against Xavier based upon tools used primarily for defence.

Then I tried: - ‘initial payment’ + estopped + ‘us law’ + probate
Google sent me down the wrong track not recognising ‘estoppel’ and re-interpreting as ‘stopped’

I added to the end of the previous search : -    + cornell 
From the top snippet I pulled up the Cornell article on Probate (law.cornell.edu.wex.probate)

I saw that my time was up so I briefly flicked down a few more snippets then went to the questions page.  I did not move the slider from my original place of 60% towards (B).  I think option (B) just tipped the scales in its favour because option (A) was more clearly wrong.

column10: After my research: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 96%; B (Double bubble sign): 4%
column12:
On my first reading I had no idea what the correct answer was.

On reading the AI explanation and choice I was more confident that the correct answer was (A).  In option (B) there was no clear diagnosis because according to the AI a double bubble sign is typical of the duodenal atresia but this not followed by typical symptoms such as the inability to feed or vomiting.   Breathing problems are indicated which I surmise are anomalous to this condition. So there is something wrong here that had not been discovered.

I began my internet search in Chrome with : -   ‘Double bubble sign’ + diagnosis

The top snippet from National Institute of Health (NIH) confirmed the AI was correct in suggesting duodenal atresia was associated with the  X-ray showing the double bubble sign.

Scrolling down further I saw an image of the double bubble.  

I pulled up what looked like a monograph from the National Library of Medicine (NLM) titled ‘Respiratory Distress in the Newborn’ (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4533247/)

Understandably I gathered that cyanosis (blue hues) was related to oxygen deficiency in the affected area. Looking at diagnosis there was mention of cardiovascular disease being difficult to differentiate from pulmonary causes.  They also suggested the notion of timing describing how it may take time to become noticeable. I speculated if this could be the root of the confusion regarding no clear description by the AI of the condition when considering option (B). 

I put into Chrome : -  subcostal retractions and breathing

I understood from the snippet from the Cleveland Clinic that subcostal retractions was pushing the stomach up into the rib cage when breathing in.

I put into Chrome: -   moderate perioral cyanosis

I gathered from the NLM snippet that perioral meant the blue was around the hands, fingertips and toes.  I pulled up the full article ‘Central and Peripheral Cyanosis’ (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559167/)

I gathered that cyanosis could be caused by pulmonary conditions. A large part of this technical article was characterising different oxygen level profiles, I did not think I needed to go into that level of detail to find my answers. 

I tried: - ‘Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema’ and diagnosis

I gathered from the top snippet (Penn Medicine) that diagnosis did not appear surgical or minimally so.  I pulled up the article  ‘Interstitial Lung Disease Diagnosis’

(pennmedicine.org/for-patien…)   Diagnosis was around 95% non-surgical with only one procedure than was surgical at the end if a larger sample of lung was needed. Their policy was to use the least invasive method.

I tried: - ‘pulmonary interstitial edema’ and diagnosis’

I pulled up an article from the Mayo Clinic ‘Pulmonary edema – Diagnosis and treatment’
(mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/pulmonary-edema…) Regarding diagnosis there was no mention of surgery.

I put into Chrome: -  ‘Double bubble sign’ + diagnosis
I noticed that the top snippet mentioned  duodenal atresia concurring with the AI explanation.

I scrolled through the snippets and pulled up an article from the Cleveland Clinic ‘Duodenal Atresia’
 (my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/.)  This was mentioned by the AI as not the likely condition because there was no digestive problems such as vomiting or not wanted to feed. I thought I would just check diagnosis while I was here and it did not indicate any surgery.

I tried: -  ‘Double bubble sign’ + ‘difficulty breathing’    and got back to something I had previously read

I tried: - ‘subcostal retractions’ and ‘moderate perioral cyanosis’
The top snippet had  a case study held many similarities with our case

I added to the beginning of the search: - ‘breathing difficulties’ and got the same snippet so I pulled up the article from the NIH, ‘Respiratory Distress in the Newborn’
(ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4533247/) I found I had already looking through this journal previously and had turned full circle.

My time was up so I put the slider to concur with the AI and a high confidence in option (A).

column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 89%; B (Double bubble sign): 11%

Breathing problems are indicated which I surmise are anomalous to this condition. So there is something wrong here that had not been discovered.

column7: On first reading I was extremely confident  that the correct answer was (B).  I had come across this area of contract law in a previous trial and if it was just about getting the correct answer realistically I could have stopped here without the AI explanation or online research.   Option (B) Incapacity could clearly be established and this would make the contract invalid. Option (A) could go astray because oral contracts are valid in US law.  Enforcing it would be a different matter.
column10: After my research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 0%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 100%
column12:
On first reading I was extremely confident  that the correct answer was (B).  I had come across this area of contract law in a previous trial and if it was just about getting the correct answer realistically I could have stopped here without the AI explanation or online research. 

Option (B) Incapacity could clearly be established and this would make the contract invalid.
Option (A) could go astray because oral contracts are valid in US law.  Enforcing it would be a different matter.

On reading the AI explanation I was still extremely confident the AI explanation did not make any difference to my confidence level in (B).

I did notice something that the AI overlooked in that the trial description stated   ‘discovered the agreement’ this rather indicated that there was some kind of written agreement and could make option (A) irrelevant depending on what was there.   Otherwise the AI concurred with my own understanding of this matter.

I began online with: - ‘us law’ + incapacity + voidable
Top snippet from Cornell titled ‘Incompetency’ stated that a contract with someone who was incompetent was voidable.

I added: -  ‘us law’ + incapacity + voidable + ‘pain killers’		attempting to narrow my search towards the case. 

I pulled up an article from Cornell titled ‘Voidable’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/voidable) That article did not quite have what I needed. 

I added:  +cornell  to the end of the search then changed the search around because I was getting the same results.

I tried: - ‘us law’ + ‘contract law’ incapacity + ‘pain killers’ + cornell

I pulled up the Cornell Law article on ‘Incompetency’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/incompetency)
The article described a lack of physical or intellectual ability. I went to the contract law part of the article.  Offers can be terminated because of the incapacity of the person before acceptance.

I looked through some snippets ‘People also ask’  and found similar confirmations in support of (B)
I came back to the Incompetency article and viewed the ‘Termination of Offer’  which re-iterated that incapacity was a valid defence especially under these circumstances because the lady had just had an accident and come out of hospital. It went on to state that a contract with someone who was incompetent was voidable.

I put extracts from option (A) into chrome: - ‘us law’ + ‘contract law’+ oral

I pulled up the article ‘Oral Contract’ from Cornell Law (law.cornell.edu/wex/oral_contract) 

The article continued to confirm that oral contracts could be valid. It also stated that some contracts could fail according to the Statue of Frauds.

It was a digression but I thought it should be valid in the US so I finished with a check : - ‘car sale’ + ‘us law’ + cooling off period    

According to the Federal Trade Commission there was a 3 days cooling off period and our senior citizen was within that period, so that sealed the matter there was no way the offeree was going enforce his contract legally.  

Most of the trials have been challenging so this trial was a gift although I expect if I had not done the previous trails it would have been just as difficult. I could not put the slider any further up in confidence for option (B).

column7: On first reading the trial I was somewhat confident that the answer was (A).  I had come across ‘undue influence’ in previous trials but I was not so familiar with ‘insufficient consideration’ although I understood the term.
column10: After my research: A (Undue influence.): 99%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 1%
column12:
On first reading the trial I was somewhat confident that the answer was (A).  I had come across ‘undue influence’ in previous trials but I was not so familiar with ‘insufficient consideration’ although I understood the term.

On reading the AI explanation and choice the AI concurred with my understanding of our case and filled some of the details. I was even more confident that my choice of (A) was correct.

I began my online research in Chrome with: 

 - ‘insufficient consideration’ vs ‘undue influence’ + ‘us law’

It was telling that all the snippets were discussing ‘undue influence’ and not ‘insufficient consideration’. This was a crude rule of thumb but it indicated that the most dominant interest online in this area was with regards to ‘undue influence’.  

From the top snippet I pulled up an article by the American Bar Association (AMA) ‘Defining Undue Influence’ (americanbar.org/groups/law_aging/publications/bifocal/vol_35/issue_3_feb2014/defining_undue_influence/)

I was familiar with this term and it was certainly valid in our case with the daughter’s unconscionable actions.  What I really needed to confirm was what would be  the most appropriate basis that the Will could be invalidated.  I was looking through the articles with this frame of reference. This accounts for why I put  ‘insufficient consideration’ vs ‘undue influence’ . I was not so concerned with seeking definitions.

I understood from the article that there was a ‘new’ (01/01/2014)  law which outlines four metrics for ‘undue influence’ to be valid, the daughter scored well in every one.

1. Vulnerability.  Her late mother was on her death bed.

2.  Influencer’s apparent authority.  The influencer was her daughter who provided support and company  whilst the late mother’s son was distant.

3. Evidence of Tactics. This had three parts - Controlling necessities (No) , use of intimidation, affection, coercion (Yes), changes in person or property rights (Yes).

4. Inequity.  Buy property worth £250,000 for $100,000

This would give our beloved daughter 4 out of 4 for undue influence.  Regarding the fourth metric, this is very closely related if not identical to ‘unfair consideration’.  In the text it stated that if the only metric was this one, it would not be enough to prove undue influence.   

Furthermore in this article there was a case study that quite closely aligned with out case where ‘undue influence’ was effectively used.
 
 I continued my search with : - ‘Insufficient consideration’ + ‘us law’

I wanted to reflect on this term in isolation in relation to US law.  Looking at the top snippet (US Law Essentials) this described what would be common sense that one party gets considerable more value with a transaction leading to the ‘consideration’  not being adequate.  I understood from previous trials that ‘consideration’ was used in a special way and could mean money or other things of value.

I added   +wills         to the end of the search.

I briefly pulled up a Wikipedia article on ‘Consideration’ and quickly shut it down again because I did consider it to be an exceptional source. It would probably qualify as a reasonable source but I was not short of options.

From the ‘People Also Ask’ section I pulled up the US Law Essentials snippet I referred to earlier,
‘What is insufficient consideration?’ (https://uslawessentials.com/2015919…)
I gathered from this article that courts do not care how much consideration you have or do not have.  All they care about is that sufficient consideration exists in a legal sense for it to be valid. Based on my superficial knowledge of consideration this would suggest that buying a $250,000 for $100,000 would be irrelevant to this aspect of the law.

I went back to the snippets and pulled up an article from Cornell Law School ‘Failure of Consideration’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/failure_of_consideration….)

It outlined two key aspects of consideration. One was when it was lacking, there was none at all which inferred the contract was never valid.  The second was that the consideration becomes valueless after the contract which makes it unenforceable.  Neither of these two descriptions fitted with our case.  I followed a link on this site entitle ‘Remedies’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/remedy).  This did not appear relevant to our case at its current stage.

I put into Chrome: -   ‘Undue influence’ + ‘us law’ + wills + cornell

I pulled up the article from the top snippet Cornell Law School ‘Undue Influence’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/undue_influence)  I did not see anything else I could use so I returned to the snippets.

I pulled up another article from Cornell ‘Will Contest’ (law.cornell.edu/wex/will_contest)

This would be relevant to our case in that the son and daughter in our case where conducting a will contest to dispute a will. Presumably this would be during probate.  I gathered that the most common challenge to a Will was ‘undue influence’.  This would concur with my rule of thumb estimation that this would be most dominant based on its dominance online.  I did not see anything of any further particular furhter interest here and flicked back to a previous snippet to see if there were any useful links I could follow.

I pulled up the article on ‘undue influence’ again and followed the link titled ‘unenforceable’  (law.cornell.edu/wex/unenforceable) . ‘ Unenforceable’ was where the courts still see the contract as valid, but will not or cannot do anything to enforce it. I gather an unenforceable contract was not a void contract.

 I went back to ‘undue influence and followed the link to void contracts  (law.cornell.edu/wex/voidable) The meant the contract was valid unless it was rejected by a party with a ‘legally protected’ option to do this. Whilst useful as background this did not further my case.

The timer froze at ‘52’ this time.  With the information I had in front of me and with previous knowledge from other trials I was happy to put the slider up further with a high degree of confidence in (A) ‘undue influence’.

column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Undue influence.): 92%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 8%
