column7: On first reading the description I had no idea what the correct answer was.  It was describing a physical movement which I was having trouble visualising.  I thought actually seeing a clip of the movements might help.
column10: After my research: A (Infraspinatous): 0%; B (Supraspinatous): 100%
column12:
On first reading the description I had no idea what the correct answer was.  It was describing a physical movement which I was having trouble visualising.  I thought actually seeing a clip of the movements might help.

On reading the AI explanation I trusted it for describing flexion and abduction but I think it could get confused and possibly hallucinate when processing descriptions of movement.  For this reason I allocated less confidence than normal in the AI’s answer of (B) Supraspinatous. 

I began my online search in Chrome with: -  
 ‘the patient to position his thumbs downward’ + test + muscle

From the snippet I got ‘Empty Can Test’ (Physiopedia) which mentioned supraspinatous in its truncated description.  I pulled up the article (physio-pedia.com/Empty_Can_Test)

This described the test in our trial and stated it was for the  supraspinatous muscle.  Realistically I could have stopped there but I decided to continue because this seemed too easy. I could confirm this with another respectable site, checkout some unfamiliar terminology and see what the moves for the  infraspinatous muscle were. Maybe there could be a confounding factor down the line somewhere.
  
I watched the video associated with the article to better understand the ‘Empty Can Test’.

I continued my search by replacing ‘muscle’ with ‘supraspinatous’ just to see if there were other tests or the same test on different sites. Many of the snippet descriptions looked to concur with Physiopedia and thought I would be wasting my energy looking for further confirmations. 

I tried swapping  supraspinatous with infraspinatous in the search: 
-   ‘the patient to position his thumbs downward’ + test +  infraspinatous

From the snippets I pulled up an article from Physiopedia  again that described the moves for testing in a similar format to testing  supraspinatous.  I could see that there were a considerable amount of similarities with the  supraspinatous test.  Furthermore I could see how confusion could arise here between the two tests. I could see the differences quite clearly watching but the descriptions both had 90 degrees included and a person or AI could easily overlook that the persons arm was bent and pushing outward and there was no twisting in the infraspinatous test. If my layman’s description was wrapped up in medical terminology the picture could be most confusing.

I looked up the meaning of edamatous : -     edamatous define

  It meant swollen and full of fluid.  I speculated if it was a good idea to even do the Empty Can Test with a damaged shoulder.

I tried: -  edamatous + ‘can test’
On the top snippet I got a description on how to diagnose an edamatous area. It involved pressing it to see if a ‘pit’ forms afterwards.

I tried: -  edamatous + ‘empty can test’
On top snippet I got the post of  Physiopedia for testing  supraspinatous again and I had gone full circle.

I decided that there was no point continuing now and finished early.  I was very clear on the answer of (B) and pulled the slider up to the maximum.
column16: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Infraspinatous): 50%; B (Supraspinatous): 50%
column19: After reading the AI's answer: A (Infraspinatous): 21%; B (Supraspinatous): 79%

column7: On first reading the case there was no mention of payment.  As far as I understood regarding contract law if there was no ‘consideration’ it was not a proper contract and whether anything in it could be enforced was dubious at best. Because I suspected that none of this was valid in contract law I went with (B), no obligation to pay.  I did not know anything about presenting the money on the day but if the agreement was invalid it would not matter.
column10: After my research: A (The plumbing supply corporation is obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, and the property manager is required to pay the agreed price for the 25 sets within a timeframe that can be considered reasonable following their delivery.): 4%; B (The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporationâ€™s headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.): 96%
column12:
On first reading the case there was no mention of payment.  As far as I understood regarding contract law if there was no ‘consideration’ it was not a proper contract and whether anything in it could be enforced was dubious at best. Because I suspected that none of this was valid in contract law I went with (B), no obligation to pay.  I did not know anything about presenting the money on the day but if the agreement was invalid it would not matter.

On reading the AI explanation this was a game changer in my understanding of the trial, presuming the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) was genuine.  I was certain that it would be too much of a stretch to believe the AI had hallucinated this organisation.  Whether its guidelines were legally enforceable was something I needed to look into.  Possibly the AI had decided to be guided by these rules and forgotten the actual law. I thought this scenario was plausible. Furthermore although the description of the case was straightforward enough, the options were not straightforward and I thought that this was another potential stumbling block for the AI.

For these reasons I was not confident at all in the AI’s choice of (A).  Furthermore I had no idea what the correct answer was, given the new information regarding the UCC.  With these factors in mind  I moved the slider back to 50/50.

I began my online research in Chrome with: - ‘Uniform Commercial Code’+ ‘legally enforceable’

I began writing +’us law’ but stopped myself because it would not be necessary if the UCC was a North American organisation, and my search would automatically present for US related sites.

I gathered from the top snippet (Wikipedia) that the UCC was not law.  However it could be enacted by a particular state in which case it would become law.  This added another confounding factor because  I did not know which states had enacted it, which could present a picture of the UCC being enforceable in some states and not in others.

In the ‘People Also Ask’ section I opened a snippet (Brainly.com)  that described mixed contracts and the ‘predominant purpose test’.  If the main purpose was dealing goods then UCC applies. If the main purpose is a service then common law applies.  With our case there was a service element because the bathroom units were delivered but the purpose of the deal was to sell goods so the UCC should apply in our case, if it had been enacted whatever state we are delivering to.
  
   Scrolling through the snippets I gathered that the UCC was well established across the US and had been universally adopted.

I pulled up a snippet from Cornell Law School ‘Obligation of Good Faith’ (law.cornell.edu/ucc/1/1-304)   It was not useful so I followed a further link on there  ‘Course of Performance, Course of Dealing, and Usage of Trade’ (law.cornell.edu/ucc/1/1-303)  I did not find that useful either.  

I followed the links to a definition of ‘Good faith’ (law.cornell.edu/ucc/1/1-201#Goodfaith)   I gathered reasonableness and honesty was key.

Returning to the snippets I went to ‘People Also Ask’ and opened the snippet from (Brainly) titled ‘What happens if a dispute occurs over the existence of a contract under the UCC?’  

 This site was explaining the UCC rules and apparently all that was required for a contract to exist was a purchase order. Regarding our case this would suggest there was a valid contract under the UCC rules.

I pulled up another snippet from ‘People Also Ask’  (Nolo.com) ‘What is required for a contract to be enforceable under the UCC?’   

 It had to be in writing, signed by the person who was being enforced and against and had to be more than $500.  I would imagine a first delivery of 25 bathroom units would be much more than $500.  The order in our case was signed in a written order by the bathroom supply company and signed off by the property manager at the other side.  So from the evidence our case looked to be enforceable as a valid contract.  

I pulled up the snippet from Nolo (nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/when…)  I had already established that we had a valid contract, what I really needed to find now were time constraints in relation to UCC rules.

I put into Chrome: -  ‘Uniform Commercial Code’ + payment

I pulled up the top snippet from Cornell Law School ‘Payment’(law.cornell.edu/ucc/3/3-602)
I did not find it useful.

I tried: -  ‘Uniform Commercial Code’ + ‘pay on delivery’ 
I pulled up an article from the top snippet ‘Effect of Seller's Tender; Delivery on Condition.’ (law.cornell.edu/ucc/2/2-507)

I took ‘seller’s tender’ to mean that the goods had to be delivered by the seller and paid for by the buyer.   In our case the bathroom units  would be the business’s headquarters because according to UCC rules if it is unspecified that was to be the place of delivery.  Payment needed to be in accordance with the contract however in our case the details were not specified.

I pulled up another snippet from ‘People Also Ask’ from BYU-I-Books ‘What does the UCC says about the terms of payment when a contract does not specify them’  

It stated that the payment was due and the ‘time and place’ at which the buyer received the goods.  This was a very indirect way of stating that the goods were due on delivery and it mirrored the way the AI had stated it.  It could easily be misinterpreted.

I was not confident of  ‘BYU-I-Books’ as reliable source so I looked for further confirmations that payment was due on delivery unless arranged otherwise. There were no payment details specified on our bathroom unit delivery so payment terms would default to this. This directly contradicted the AI choice of (A) which stated at a ‘reasonable time’ this was not the same as payment on delivery.

I scrolled down the snippets and spotted the  Cornell snippet which again was quoting ‘payment at the time and place of delivery’ . I pulled up the snippet.

‘Open Time for Payment or Running of Credit; Authority to Ship Under Reservation.’ (law.cornell.edu/ucc/2/2-310)   This was confirmation that payment should be on delivery.  This  invalidated  the AI choice of option (A).

During writing up account I  noticed an inconsistency in the AI explanation because initially the AI stated ‘payment is due at the time and place at which the buyer is to receive the goods.’  I did not focus on this term ‘time and place’ and only realised later that this was key to the whole case.

The AI chose  option (A) which stated ‘contract does not specify a payment date, so a reasonable time is implied’.    It appeared that the AI interpreted the UCC regulations incorrectly saying ‘reasonable time and place’.  This increased my confidence  further, and along with the clear online evidence caused me to contradict the AI choice in favour of option (B)

column7: On first reading I would be inclined to put the child’s welfare  ahead of the courts needs therefore if I  would choose (A).  Option (B) seems to infer more bureaucracy and interactions with authority which are likely to be more intimating and stressful possibly  causing the child to relive their trauma.    Considering what would be most correct according to law I do not think that the prosecuting attorney would need to convince the judge before summoning, this would just be part of the process so I would still go for (A) but not with a great deal of confidence.
column10: After my research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 96%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 4%
column12:
On first reading I would be inclined to put the child’s welfare  ahead of the courts needs therefore if I  would choose (A).  Option (B) seems to infer more bureaucracy and interactions with authority which are likely to be more intimating and stressful possibly  causing the child to relive their trauma.  

Considering what would be most correct according to law I do not think that the prosecuting attorney would need to convince the judge before summoning, this would just be part of the process so I would still go for (A) but not with a great deal of confidence.

On reading AI choice of (B), I was not greatly confident in the explanation provided.  I was sceptical of the AI’s explanations. In (A) the AI discussed the important of understanding what truth was and then it discussed the need for reliability.  I would be inclined to think that understanding what truth is tends to infer attempts to be reliable.  Furthermore AI’s are pretty notorious for their difficult relationship with truth, so the AI is possibly not well qualified for this brief.

Regarding the AI’s explanation of (B) it would have helped to convince me if the AI could produce some proper evidence, cases, rulings, quotes from statutes and so forth.  The explanation just looked like word salad to me and not convincing at all.

After reading this I was no wiser so I did not change the slider.

I began my online search in Chrome with : -
  ‘first-hand account’+ child+ victim+ crime+summons          then:  +’american law’ +    at the front
I pulled up the top snippet from Cornell Law School ‘18 U.S. Code § 3509 - Child victims’ and child witnesses’ rights’ (law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/3509)    

Initially my impression was that tests for ‘competency’ were down to the courts decision but getting into the details I refined my view.

I gathered that the tests for competency are overruled by the Federal Rules of Evidence 601.
With the competency rules of examination it is presumed that the child is competent.  This would suggest option (A) rather than option (B).  It goes on to suggest that competency examinations can be ordered by the court only if there is a compelling reason.  The child’s age is not a compelling reason.

This suggested to me that option (A) was correct in contradiction of the AI’s choice.

I had what I needed but I just had the feeling I was missing something and the sense that the AI was failing too many times in my estimation of it generally getting things right.

I continued with: -  competency tests + court + child	then + ‘american law’ at the beginning

I noticed a snippet by the Office of Justice Programs ‘Children's Competency To Testify’ (ojp.gov>ncjrs….)
This snippet concurred with the position of US Law that children are competent to testify.  The grey area was how they reacted in court.  I did not know whether this text was American or English and I would imagine English and American children are probably even in terms of their cognitive abilities given the similar cultures and whatever extent the nature-nurture debate is implicated.

From the snippets I pulled up an article by the American Bar Association ‘Assessing Children's Competency to Testify’   (americanbar.org/groups/public_interest/child_law…) Rule 601 was repeated stating that children were competent to testify concurring with Cornell Law School descriptions of Rule 601 and so on.  Plus it stated that there had to be a compelling reason to do competency test.   Again I was brought to the conclusion that the AI was mistaken in choosing option (B).  
  Furthermore it notes another statute ‘Rule 603’ stating that there was nothing in this rule to indicate a necessity  to prove truthfulness.  However it went on to suggest that many states successfully used this rule to insist that some test was made.  According to this interpretation of the law, strictly speaking they were mistaken so despite common practice I still stayed with option (A) but not without a degree of uncertainty despite what I was seeing in the text.

In (A) the AI discussed the important of understanding what truth was and then it discussed the need for reliability.  I would be inclined to think that understanding what truth is tends to infer attempts to be reliable.  Furthermore AI’s are pretty notorious for their difficult relationship with truth, so the AI is possibly not well qualified for this brief.  Regarding the AI’s explanation of (B) it would have helped to convince me if the AI could produce some proper evidence, cases, rulings, quotes from statutes and so forth.  The explanation just looked like word salad to me and not convincing at all.  After reading this I was no wiser so I did not change the slider.

I began my online research in Chrome with: ‘complete Lojban’
I was just concentrating on the one place in the two sentences that were different. I did not see it as necessary to confirm translation of all the words that were the same. 

From these trials the google algorithm had been following me and taking note of my preferences, the video promoting the book just kept coming up when I was watching YouTube so I thought I would give the book a try. Looking at it I think I had downloaded it before on another trail.

I tried  ‘jadni’ in here with the local search.  I got a hit, which it translated to ‘adorned’ this corresponded  with the AI definition of adornment.

I tried ‘spali’ and did not get anything. I proceeded to try the english ‘polish’.  I got  one hit in this dictionary for ‘polish’ in relation to ‘nail polish’ but another 26 for its homograph relating to the Polish language. Then I found ‘nail’ and ‘nail polish’.  All the translations corresponded with the AI explanation.

I got ‘polished object’ which was close to the AI translation.  I looked up ‘nail’  and got jgalu as one of the translations concurring with the AI.

I tried  ‘jadni’ in the mw.lojban search engine and got ‘resurrected gsimu’ according to this page jadni was one of the ‘older’ words in Lojban that had become archaic. According to this list ‘jadni’ had become redundant.

I put ‘adornment’ and got jadni back along with other variations and it described adornment indicating fancy and decorated.

On reading the AI explanation and choice it looked very plausible. I did not think the translation looked confusing for the AI, there were no awkward tenses or anything particularly contrary.

I began my online research with a new idea,  do not know why I had not tried it before. If I couldn’t find an exact match with a particular phrase I could just try adding wildcard characters.  Well that was the theory and in this trial I found it to be spectacularly ineffective.

In Chrome I tried: - 	‘ne'i *’	
I did not think that the phrase from the trial ‘ne'i la .makax’  would get many hits but I thought ne’i, and then some other name might. The * is a wildcard meaning that it can be anything.
That did not work at all, I got hits for rap videos and the periodic table.

I tried: -   ‘ne'i *’ lojban to english
‘Phasebook: Lojban to English’ came to the top of the Google.  I pulled up the site (mw.lojban.org/papri/Phrasebook) and I was on a familiar site in an unfamiliar page.

I tried: -  ‘ne'i la *’ 	In the Lojban site’s search engine and it took me to some index. I did not see anything useful there or in the search.

I tried:  -  ne’i 	
It took me to a very obscure place. I persevered but none of it was any use to me, (mw.lojban.org/papri/Talk...)

I tried: -  within 				In my own laptop’s local search to search through this page. I was just getting into the weeds and making no progress.  I reversed out of this part of the site.

Still in the same site, I went back to the previous search:	 ne’i
Then I tried ‘within’ again in the site search engine and did not find anything useful.

I tried: -    bu’u 	In the same search engine and got some hits that looked promising. I pulled up one of the snippets showing ‘bu’u la’ which was a good sign.  It was a page about a lojban translation of one of Lewis Carol’s works titled  ‘lo selfri be la .alis. bei bu'u la selmacygu'e’

Looking at the last part this corresponded to the option (A) in the trial except that the name was different ‘selmacygu'e’ instead of ‘.makax.’  This was encouraging and an indication that the sentence structure in the question was valid. Looking further I found ‘bu’u la’ which indicated this phrasing was a valid word  combination in Lojban. I copied the full phrase ‘bu'u la fagzda lolgai’. 

I wondered if I may be able to find a translation of Lewis Carol’s work and use it as a reference to see how the phrases in my two options aligned if I swapped certain words. Reverse engineering in a round about way.

I put ‘bu'u la fagzda lolgai’ into Chrome.  Google immediately recognised this as Lewis Carol and pulled up a number of images of the work, with Lojban captions.  

I tried to translate the page with the google translator.  Google moved me to another page.
(wiki-source.org.translate.goog…)  I looked through the list of languages of the translator and Google did not appear to have Lojban. This was getting confusing.

I tried in Chrome: -  ‘bu'u la fagzda lolgai’ lojban
From the snippets I pulled up a Wiki that had bu’u in its title ‘Appendix: Lojban/bu’u’

This was unequivocal it was describing ‘at a location’ linked to bu’u.  This was significant for the trial and one of the key distinctions in the AI discussion.  This corresponded directly with the AI’s translation in option (A).

I tried the same Wiki with: -   ne’i
I got another good result which corresponded again with the AI translation.  ne’i meaning ‘in’.

I went back to Chrome to find some more confirmations of the AI translations which were looking solid. I put ‘Complete Lojban’ into Chrome.   I pulled up ‘The Complete Lojban Language’ (lojban.org/publications/cll/cll_v1.1_book.pdf) by J.W.Cowan. 

From previous experience this was a decent source for Lojban.  I put -    ne’i     Into my local search.   Got 9 hits which corresponded directly with ‘within’ or ‘In’ concurring with the AI translation. According to this authoritative text ne’i was a spatial tense which fitted very well with its correct usage in option (B).

Next I tried bu’u and got 5 hits with a clear indication that bu’u was associated with ‘at’.  I gathered that this was a location tense.

I finished a little early because I felt that I had enough confirmations and evidence to be extremely confident in the AI choice of (B).  Everything fitted together very well so I put the slider up to the maximum.

column12:
On first reading the case I had a slight bias towards (A).  This person was not in a good state and needed an in depth assessment of his condition.  The situation did not look like an emergency, this problem had built up over time. I wondered how being a gardener, a seemingly  irrelevant factor might be influential in some way.  It was rather a stretch but I speculated that but maybe he regularly uses some pesticide that can have symptoms that can confuse diagnosis.
 
On reading the AI explanation I put what I guessed to be the average score for AI’s getting trials correct.  I was beginning to think this estimation was over optimistic with the nature of the questions in these trials.
 I had one or two concerns with the dense amount of symptoms and metrics described.  If some of these gave an indication that the diagnosis might not be peripheral artery disease (PAD) it may profoundly change the next step.  


I began my online research in Chrome with: -  
			gardener and ‘peripheral artery disease’


I targetted ‘gardener’ first because it appeared to be the most obscure and irrelevant factor in this trial.  In previous trials these factors can sometimes be more significant than they first appear. All I found was that there was an author with ‘Gardner’ as a second name who wrote about PAD.

In Chrome I put just: -  	 ‘peripheral artery disease’
I gathered it was reduced blood flow in the arms or legs. I looked through some snippets and images.

I pulled up an article from the Cleveland Clinic ‘Peripheral Artery Disease’
(my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/17357-peripheral-artery-disease-pad)

Reading through this account PAD did indeed correspond with many of the symptoms  of this patient. Furthermore his smoking, diabetes, high cholesterol, high blood pressure and age increased his chances of PAD developing.  Exercise lessened the symptoms so being a gardener should help.

There were a number of non-invasive tests suggested and then an angiogram was suggested. 

I followed the link titled ‘angiogram’ which was supposed to reveal clotting areas (my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diagnostics/4977-angiography)

I gathered that an angiogram is the next step if there are signs of blocked, abnormal or damaged blood vessels. Our patient had many symptoms indicative of PAD which pointed to an angiogram.

I decided to move my search to investigate the merits of option (B). 

In Chrome I put:  -  ‘ulcer appears dull gray without pus’ and ‘antibiotics’
According to the AI such an ulcer did not require antibiotics.   I gathered from the snippets that it was not as binary as the AI suggested.  Some ulcers do need antibiotics which made my choice of options more difficult. Apparently if the ulcer was not infected it may still need antibiotics if it had developed to the bone. It was unclear if this had occurred. In another snippet The National Institute of Health suggested antibiotics for non healing ulcers. 

 Considering these snippets brought down my confidence in option (A), angiogram first.

I pulled up an article by Health, ‘What Is an Ulcer?’ (health.com/ulcer-7489325)
It was useful background reading on Ulcers but did not bring me closer to any better choice in the trial.

I tried in Chrome (copy and pasted from the trial):
- ‘dorsalis pedis and popliteal pulses were not palpable on thr right’ and pad

then : - ‘When to use Angiograhy’ and PAD
			
I stopped  with my analysis in the last two searches because it was past 20 minutes and to my surprise Google had injected ‘AI Overviews’ at the top of the snippets.  The was a new development and I would have to look at my settings and switch it off if that was possible or use a different browser.   It was a minor part of the search and I do not think it influenced me either way.

Considering the evidence for and against it was not as clear cut as I would have liked.  There were numerous metrics and symptoms that I could have dug into further.
In the balance the AI choice of (A), angiogram looked the best but I was not supremely confident.

column12:
nitially on reading the trial I was vacillating between option (A) and (B) until I realised that there was no explicit mention of a previous criminal conviction existing for the defendant.  I had remembered that there were certain exceptions to admitting previous evidence to  cases if that aspect of the defendant’s history is introduced by one side.  I went with (B), ‘lack of mistake, more because (A) appeared flawed and I did not have a great amount of confidence.

On reading the AI choice and explanation, a convincing case was made for (B) but I would have to do some reading online to feel more confident.

I began my online research in Chrome with: - 

'us law' + 'Can the evidence of the defendant's involvement in the prior scheme be admitted' 

I deliberately did not mention the statute 404 in this search, as introduced by the AI, because I wanted to see if other statutes came up also that the AI may have overlooked.

It so happened that Rule 404 came up as the top snippet concurring with what the AI had targeted.

I pulled up Cornell Law School’s article ‘Rule 404. Character Evidence; Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts’  (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_404)

Reading through the account I noticed that 404.3(b2) basically paraphrased the statute  the AI had described. Section (B) referred to ‘Other Crimes Wrongs or Acts’ this went on to highlight that certain evidence (evidence against the defendant) could be admitted from absence of mistake.

Presumably this infers that once you introduce ‘absence of mistake’ , the prosecutor can then use, not absence of mistake to mount an attack.

Further along in the account it then clarifies  a point in 404(b) that suggests that when information is offered, it is not excluded.

All this looked to correspond with the AI explanation.

I followed the link by Cornell at the bottom of the page ‘Rule 403. Excluding Relevant Evidence for Prejudice, Confusion, Waste of Time, or Other Reasons’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_403)

Looking at Rule 403 it was set up as a way of stopping defendants tying up proceeding in essence using ‘filibuster’ tactics.  I really did not think this was the situation in our trial with option (B). It appeared that it was part of a narrow window of defences available to our defendant to save his career and reputation.

I tried in Chrome: -  'us law' +tax+ 'Can the evidence of the defendant's involvement in the prior scheme be admitted'

I pulled up a United States Department of Justice Pdf ‘Criminal Tax Manual’ (justice.gov/media/1239021/dl?inline)

I wanted to see how Rule 404 applied to tax matters.  I was running low on time and looking through the Pdf I could not see any reference to Rule 404 or 403 in the text.  I could only surmise the tax matters existed as a separate entity in US law of which I had little knowledge. In the text there were numerous references to accountants adding the previous years returns to the current year as our defendant did.  This added some uncertainty to my choice, I could not help suspecting that the our crooked defendant was in the wrong court.

In the final instance I went with the AI’s choice of option (B) but not without a good amount of uncertainty.

column12:
On my initial reading (B) looked like the better choice because (A) was almost certainly wrong.

On reading the AI explanation and choice of (B) I concurred it looked compelling to me.

I began my online search in Chrome with: 
‘us law’ + ‘under the influence of intoxicating’+civil+’conviction’

From the snippets I pulled up a professional law firm Heslin Law, ‘The Importance of Pursuing a Civil Drunk Driving Lawsuit’  (heslinlawfirm.com/blog/philadelphia-civil-dui-cases.cfm)

The account was unequivocal in stating that evidence from the criminal case could be used to strengthen a civil case. I also gathered that DUI (Driving Under the Influence) was the key acronym I needed for further searches.

I tried:	 ‘us law’ + ‘dui’ + Civil + ‘prior conviction’
I pulled up the site from Cornell Law School, ‘Rule 609. Impeachment by Evidence of a Criminal Conviction’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_609)

I gathered that  a conviction could be inadmissible in either a civil  or criminal case if the person had a ‘certificate of rehabilitation’, presumably after the conviction.  Our defendant was just contrite that she did the crash while under the influence. I imagine that cases may take time to book and if she got busy she might had an angle to pursue there.
There were other irrelevant exceptions mentioned such as a crime older than 10 years that may stop admission.

I admit ignorance in attempting to interpret one passage that quoted Rule 609(a) regarding a court admitting convictions in a civil case that, paraphrasing - did not have anything to do with the credibility to reach undesirable results. This was incomprehensible to me at that moment. I imagine I would need to spend quite some time reading the actual statute rather an interpretation of the statute to get anywhere with it.

With regards to option (A) I was very confident that the AI had got it right there, so however confusing option (B) was, in a sense it did not matter and wins by default. To clarify I was well aware that a prior conviction was not hearsay so did not need to waste time searching for any confirmations there.

I was satisfied that option (B) was the best answer to a high level of confidence.

column7: On first reading I went with option (B) not because I liked the look of it but because option (A) was definitely wrong.  Taking an excerpt from trial from the last sentence before the options part:  ‘The co-passenger, who made the statement, is ready and available to deliver their testimony during the court trial. The presiding judge in the case should determine this testimony as:….’  Going on what was in front of me, by widely accepted principles of writing,  the pronouns ‘this’ and ‘their’ refer to the co-passenger and not someone in a previous sentence.  Unequivocally the  co-passenger is the antecedent in this sentence and not the officer from a previous sentence.  Based on this, option (A) is 100% invalid because what the co-passenger had to say was first hand knowledge and not hearsay.  The reason I did not put the slider to 100% in favour of (B) at that moment was that I did not know if option (B) was impossibly wrong also, in which case I would have had to leave the slider at 50/50 as the best possible option available to me.  With this in mind I struck a compromise at 75% for (B) until I had found out more.

column12:
On first reading I went with option (B) not because I liked the look of it but because option (A) was definitely wrong. 
Taking an excerpt from trial from the last sentence before the options part: 
‘The co-passenger, who made the statement, is ready and available to deliver their testimony during the court trial. The presiding judge in the case should determine this testimony as:….’ 
Going on what was in front of me, by widely accepted principles of writing,  the pronouns ‘this’ and ‘their’ refer to the co-passenger and not someone in a previous sentence.  Unequivocally the  co-passenger is the antecedent in this sentence and not the officer from a previous sentence.

Based on this, option (A) is 100% invalid because what the co-passenger had to say was first hand knowledge and not hearsay.  The reason I did not put the slider to 100% in favour of (B) at that moment was that I did not know if option (B) was impossibly wrong also, in which case I would have had to leave the slider at 50/50 as the best possible option available to me.  With this in mind I struck a compromise at 75% for (B) until I had found out more.

On reading the AI explanation and choice of option (A) I was convinced that the AI had hallucinated. I can only speculate but based on its choice of option (A) it had attempted to read between the lines and make an interpretation based on what it inferred the author was meaning rather than what was actually on the page.  This I would deem as a hallucination.

It was clear that the AI mistakenly interpreted from the last sentence quoted above as referring to the police officer with the pronouns ‘this’ and ‘their’.  Holding this interpretation  went against the standard rules of correct interpretation. 

Based on the little the AI had  noted regarding option (B) and my imperfect memory of past trials I felt that someone could make a specious argument in favour of option (B) which was not 100% impossible.   Based on this premise I had an expectation in favour of 100% for option (B) because option (A) is impossible, rather than 50/50, best response I had for both impossible. 

I put 94 % for B) and not 100%  because I was holding out that I may have overlooked something.

I decided to try and justify a tenuous case for option (B) because that was the only option left to me.

I began in Chrome with: - ‘us law’ + ‘  nonessential, irrelevant topics’
From the top snippet from Cornell Law School I read that evidence was irrelevant if it did not affect or relate to the matter in controversy.    I supposed that someone could contend that we already knew that the driver was not denying his intoxication and there was no point calling the a witness to that effect.  It would be reasonable to presume that the police officer has breathalysed the driver in accordance with standard practice, but there was no mention of it in the trial.  Could such be inferred ?

I pulled up the article from Cornell titled ‘irrelevant’(law.cornell.edu/wex/irrelevant)
Based on Rule 401(a) if the evidence was more likely to make the fact look less or more probable then it should be admitted. In our case this would be more because the witness was saying the driver was drunk, so this would lessen the likelihood of (B) being valid.

I following the link for ‘Rule 401’ still on the Cornell Law School page (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_401) to article  ‘Rule 401. Test for Relevant Evidence’

The article went into a discussion about probative value, once it was established that the driver was intoxicated the witness had little value after,  other than describing the level of intoxication.

I followed a link at the bottom of the page (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/article_IV)
‘Article IV. Relevance an its limits’
This led to a small table of contents of associated topics. I clicked on ‘Rule 403. Excluding Relevant Evidence for Prejudice, Confusion, Waste of Time, or Other Reason’  (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_403)

The relevant evidence we are considering is the first hand account of the co-passenger should he take the stand.
Looking at the synopsis an argument could be to exclude relevant evidence on time wasted and pointlessly describing things the court already knows.  There was not much more to add regarding this page.

I  following the link at the bottom of the last page for ‘Rule 404. Character Evidence; Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_40)
There was not much I could use there.

I followed a further link from the last page ‘609’ 
‘Rule 609. Impeachment by Evidence of a Criminal Conviction’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_609)
I gathered that wasting time was an issue again and that the credibility of the witness could be attacked for various reasons, but our witness appeared to be going against his own best interests by going against his travelling companion.

Summing up a weak argument could be made for (B) which was the only viable option because option (A) was irrelevant.

column20: On reading the AI explanation and choice of option (A) I was convinced that the AI had hallucinated. I can only speculate but based on its choice of option (A) it had attempted to read between the lines and make an interpretation based on what it inferred the author was meaning rather than what was actually on the page.  This I would deem as a hallucination.  It was clear that the AI mistakenly interpreted from the last sentence quoted above as referring to the police officer with the pronouns ‘this’ and ‘their’.  Holding this interpretation  went against the standard rules of correct interpretation.   Based on the little the AI had  noted regarding option (B) and my imperfect memory of past trials I felt that someone could make a specious argument in favour of option (B) which was not 100% impossible.   Based on this premise I had an expectation in favour of 100% for option (B) because option (A) is impossible, rather than 50/50, best response I had for both impossible.   I put 94 % for B) and not 100%  because I was holding out that I may have overlooked something.

column7: On first reading I had an inkling that the option was (B) the best answer.  Just looking at it the last two words of (B) seemed to correspond better with the English, then I realized ‘xunre’ was most likely red and I left it there.

column12:
On first reading I had an inkling that the option was (B) the best answer.

Just looking at it the last two words of (B) seemed to correspond better with the English, then I realized ‘xunre’ was most likely red and I left it there.

On reading the Ai Explanation and choice of (A) I was not all that convinced.  The differences in the two sentences were rather subtle,  possibly something the AI might get tangled over.
Also with regards to the AI discussion with verbs, I was rather uncomfortable with the AI explaining Lojban from an English frame of reference. I would have imagined what was correct for that language was to stay true to the conventions of that language.

The AI taking the alternative option was enough for me to bring the slider back to the middle.

I began my online investigation with: - complete lojban
I pulled up ‘The Complete Lojban Language’ by J.W.Cowan
(lojban.org/publications/cll/cll_v1.1_book.pdf)

I focussed on the last few words that were different around ‘xumre’ which I gather from the AI was the colour red. I was quite happy to accept this as the correct definition for ‘xumre’.

After pulling up the Pdf I continued with my local windows search which would look through the Pdf for selected words for me.

I began with ‘carna’  - I got no hits.  Then ‘xunre’ just to check, it corresponded directly with the AI translation of red.

Next I tried ‘become’ but did not find anything in the right context.  Become was key to deciding which option was best. The AI was stating that,  "co'a xunre" means "become red".  I was looking for confirmation or otherwise of the meaning of co’a. It did not matter so much about something becoming red, just that the notion of co’a being ‘becoming’ was valid.   From this authoritative text it seemed to indicate that co’a was more about beginnings which raised some question marks. The text suggested that it was part of a set of words representing points in time or sometimes points in space.

It was not a complete event as suggested by the AI and then at the end of the text there was the definition that described it unequivocally as a starting point.

I then tried ‘cu’.  It was some kind of separator.  The text described it as coming at the beginning of any ‘sumti’ or ‘selbri’ and was often left out.

I went back to Chrome and typed in: lojban grammar wiki
(en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lojban_grammar)
I pulled it up ‘Lojban Grammar’

I could try and get more confirmations and definitions here. 
I put in ‘Carna’- still nothing
I tried ‘turn’ - got nothing in the right context.

I typed into Chrome: carna lojban to english. 
I ignored the Google translate and pulled up  (jbovlaste.lojban.org/lookup.plForm=lookup.pl2&Database=*&Query=carna)
This had ‘carna’ as, rotates or turns about an axis.  This suggested ‘turning red’ may be a more novel or symbolic usage. There was a little history about the word which indicated that it was one of the newer additions to Lojban.  This could have lead to the AI being less accepting of its usage in this context.

I typed into Chrome: - lojban dictionary
I pulled up ‘User:Gleki/Lojban Dictionary with Examples’
(mw.lojban.org/papri/User:GlekiLojban_Dictionary_with_Examples)

I typed ‘carna’ into the site search engine and got turns/rotates around an axis again.  That was a good enough confirmation.

In one of the examples I  noted that ‘pritu carna’ meant ‘turn right’ and this structure fitted with the replacement of ‘xumre carna’ for  ‘turn red’ leaving the verb at the end as I gather is usual in some Lojban phrases.

Thought I might as well try co’a again and did not get anything useful.  I reversed the search back to a more central part of the site to: 
/jbovlaste.lojban.org/lookup.pl?Form=lookup.pl….

Then I tried ‘co’a’ again. I got a definition as ‘starting point’ again.

I went back to the ‘la sutysiku’ site which translates Lojban and tried ‘turn’
The result was ‘carna’. With similar definitions from other sites.

I then tried co’a again and got further confirmations of ‘starting point’.

I then closed my activities (by now the Modulo questions site had reset).

My online research pointed to (B) being the best answer in contradiction to the AI.

column7: On first reading I went with (A) a CT scan because if the child’s ear is  displaced it could be serious and there was the issue of hearing loss. I gather from previous knowledge that there are possibly better tests depending on the symptoms, time and money e.g. MRI , but if the  CT is  all that is available.
column10: After my research: A (CT scan): 99%; B (Observation and follow up in 14 days): 1%
column12:
On first reading I went with (A) a CT scan because if the child’s ear is  displaced it could be serious and there was the issue of hearing loss. I gather from previous knowledge that there are possibly better tests depending on the symptoms, time and money e.g. MRI , but if the  CT is  all that is available.  

On reading the AI explanation and choice of (A) I was more confident with my choice. The AI had filled a lot of the gaps.  I just wondered whether it had extrapolated too much.

I began my online investigations in Chrome with: - 
		acute otitis media and temporal bones diagnosis

On reading the top snippet from the National Institute of Health (NIH) a computed tomography (CT) scan was suggested if complications with Otitis Media are suspected in relation to temporal bones. This appeared to concur with the AI choice of (A).

I pulled up the article ‘Acute Otitis Media’ (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470332/)
This article appeared quite central to me, I could just do a fast track search and target diagnosis and certain keywords but time permitting I wanted to read it all to get a thorough grounding in this area.  I opted to get the best of both approaches by targeting certain keywords using my local scan – imaging, ct.

The material was dense with unfamiliar terms and concepts so I approached it two ways. Some intentional repetition can bring forward understanding in my experience.

I gathered that generally CT is not recommended for  Acute Otitis Media (AOM) but if a complication is suspected that it is recommended.  There was a conflict of views between the Netherlands and the US.  The argument put forward by American Institutions was that if someone waits then they can risk serious conditions escalating and becoming impossible to salvage.
I noted a list of really serious conditions which centred on the temporal bones.

I also understood that the use of antibiotics are considered controversial unless a clear  diagnosis of AOM is indicated. Highlighted in this journal was that  intracranial and intra-temporal complications are central to deciding to use a CT scan.

I  wanted to pursue these two avenues further. I put into Chrome: 
 intracranial complications define

Looking at the top snippet nothing appeared to correlate with the trial description but certain features came up with what the AI had expanded upon.

I pulled up ‘Orbital and Intracranial Complications of Acute and Chronic Rhinosinusitis’  (link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4939-0265-1_27#)

I gathered that if there was a complication to AOM then CT or something with similar capabilities was recommended. I could see the complications described by the AI but it seemed rather embellished to me. These complications may have been inferred by the conditions described by the trial but I really wanted something more concrete.

I looked down the list of symptoms in the ‘People Always Ask’ section. Tinnitus was indicated along a  list of other symptoms that did not quite fit the trial description.

I tried in Chrome:  intra-temporal complications define
I understood this had nothing to do with time ! Google produced a list of time related snippets.

I tried: - 	intra-temporal or intracranial complications and Acute Otitus Media

In the snippet (ScienceDirect) mastoiditis and others were indicated as described by the AI along with a number of other very serious conditions.

I pulled up the article from the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology
‘Intratemporal and intracranial complications of acute otitis media in a pediatric population’ (sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165587614005540#)

Post auricular pain was indicated to suggest there may be intratemporal complications.  This was good enough for me.  Our case had pain behind the left ear.  

Furthermore if hearing was affected this could indicate a swelling inside which could quickly become very serious.  This was a major concern with the wait and see approach of the Netherlands with hearing and speech problems.

I returned to the original journal I pulled up at the beginning  ‘Acute Otitis Media’ 
I put in :-	imaging
 This was to see if there were further paths to journals I may want to follow up.

I clicked on reference 25 and followed a ‘PubMed’ link to ‘Intracranial complications of otitis media: 15 years of experience in 33 patients’ (pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15632907/)
I did not find anything of any further use to me in there.

I went back to the original journal then back to Google search

I tried: imaging + intra-temporal or intracranial complications and Acute Otitus Media.

The same study came back to the top and I stopped my search there because I was over the time limit.

I felt I had enough evidence and the condition was serious enough for me to go with the AI and choose (A) the CT scan.

column7: On first reading the case I had an inkling that hearsay would be admissible because of some exception to deathbed utterances. When reading through websites for other cases  I must have skimmed over some of this material. I went with option (A) but not with a great amount of confidence.
column10: After my research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 100%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 0%
column12:
On first reading the case I had an inkling that hearsay would be admissible because of some exception to deathbed utterances. When reading through websites for other cases  I must have skimmed over some of this material.
I went with option (A) but not with a great amount of confidence.

On reading the AI explanation its choice concurred and filled in some of the gaps in my initial impressions. I was almost certain that this was the correct answer now but would need to do some research online to confirm it.

I began my online investigation into Chrome with:
‘dying declaration’ + hearsay + exceptions

On reading the top snippet from Cornell Law School it confirmed my initial view and  the AI’s explanation.  I pulled up the site.

‘Dying Declaration’  (law.cornell.edu/wex/dying_declaration#….)

I gathered from the site that the words of our declarant were indeed a deathbed declaration.  Furthermore I gathered that to be admissible the declaration must relate to the circumstances or cause of the declarants demise.  This former did indeed align again since he was heard by the nurse fifteen minutes before his death  saying "I was hit by a car that blatantly ignored the traffic signal and sped through the intersection."
This evidence was corroborated by the doctor’s affidavit.

Regarding general rules of hearsay the declaration needs to be the declarant’s actual knowledge.  The again concurred with the declarant’s utterances.

I could have left the case here with 99% confidence but I wanted to continue just to see if there was any way I could undermine my own position in this matter.

I pulled up a Pdf from the bottom of the Cornell article from the Indiana University Law Review  (https://www.repository.law.indiana.edu/cgi/viewcontent…) ‘Her Last Words: Dying Declarations and Modern Confrontation Jurisprudence’ A. A. Orenstein (2010).

After reading the first two pages of this lengthy tome I had already read enough.  It was critiquing the deathbed hearsay exception going far away into the hinterlands of how and why this law came about.  It was a niche theoretical text with a feminist theme. There was no way I was going to waste my time continuing with it.

I returned to the Cornell article which was more central and tried another link entitled ‘Section 804(b)(2)’.  This took me to an article still on the Cornell site ‘Rule 804. Hearsay Exceptions; Declarant Unavailable’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_804)

It began with the criteria for being unavailable in 804 (a).  In section 4, being dead was a valid reason and our declarant fitted into this category!

In the Section 804(b)(2) of this article, further confirmations that hearsay was allowed if it was believed that the declarant was indeed dying, plus there was a cause/circumstances element.   I speculated that if the belief in the immanent death was a delusion would it still be valid ? Common sense suggests not.
I looked further with ‘death’ in my local search. There was nothing else I could see here that was relevant or did not repeat the same point of law.

I reversed my search and pulled up a case from a link in the first Cornell Law School site I went to (‘Dying Declaration’) entitled ‘People v. Bartelini’  (casetext.com/case/people-v-bartelini)

This account emphasised the importance of proof of dying declarations and in this case without this proof there could not have been any judgement.  Our case was made more solid by not only a permitted hearsay account by a nurse but also another  in the form of a signed affidavit of a doctor.

I stopped the timer a few minutes early and moved the slider to the maximum because I had more than enough material to support my choice of option (A) and refute option (B).

column20: On reading the AI explanation its choice concurred and filled in some of the gaps in my initial impressions. I was almost certain that this was the correct answer now but would need to do some research online to confirm it.

column7: On first reading I had to go for option (B) with quite a high level of confidence.  It had been agreed in the salesman’s contract that he would not be entitled to any commission after if his contract of employment closed before the invoice was received.   I was reaching in speculating that if he sued he could argue for unfair dismissal on the grounds that the actual reason he was sacked was because the company did not want to pay the massive commission, not because he did not meet sales targets in 2009 and 2010. If they had a history of this kind of sharp practice I wondered if  a case could be made.
column10: After my research: A (The salesman will triumph, as he had committed to the client to aid in the operation of the equipment.): 1%; B (The manufacturer will prevail, due to the fact that at the time the client was invoiced for the supercomputer, the salesman was no longer an employee of the manufacturer.): 99%
column12:
On first reading I had to go for option (B) with quite a high level of confidence.  It had been agreed in the salesman’s contract that he would not be entitled to any commission after if his contract of employment closed before the invoice was received.  
I was reaching in speculating that if he sued he could argue for unfair dismissal on the grounds that the actual reason he was sacked was because the company did not want to pay the massive commission, not because he did not meet sales targets in 2009 and 2010. If they had a history of this kind of sharp practice I wondered if  a case could be made.  

On reading the AI explanation this concurred with my view with a similar observance that the contract was in place to enforce their policy of not paying commissions if the salesman was no longer employed by them.

When I began my online research I struggled initially to find the right combination of words to find what I needed.  It suggested to me that what I was looking for was not very dominant in Google searches. I even suspected a bias against employees from the Google algorithm.  Normally my searches hit first time, so this seemed rather odd to me.

I put into Chrome:  ‘unfair contract’+ sales +sue		then + ‘us law’ added to the end

No useful snippets were coming up and Google was interpreting ‘sue’ as ‘Sue’s Law’  as the most dominant search phase.  It offered the option to go with the less dominant  term ‘sue’. I went with this and did not get anything useful. At the bottom of the page Google indicated that some results had been omitted.  I clicked the link to see what. I did not get anything.  Just images where coming up presumably because they did not appear to have any snippets.  This was most unusual.

I replaced ‘sue’ with ‘sales’  in Chrome: 	‘unfair contract’+ sales + ‘us law’

I gathered from the top snippet that there was no all encompassing law regarding unfair contract terms.  I disposed of the thought experiment I outlined at the beginning to press a case for unfair dismissal, although to complicate matters the law was different for different states.

I was not seeing much from the snippets so I replaced another term.

I put into Chrome:  	‘unfair contract’+ salesman + ‘us law’
I did not see anything useful and the search was not focussing well to target the US.

I tried in Chrome: 		‘unfair contract’+ commission+ ‘us law’ + employment

Looking at the snippets I was getting closer, but not close enough.

I tried: 	‘unfair contract’+ commission+ ‘us law’ + employment+salesmen
The top snippet (Henrichson Law Group)  was mentioning about companies trying to withhold  commissions and tying things up legally, this was looking better.

I tried:  ‘unpaid commission’ + ‘contract + employment        then ‘us law’ + to the beginning of search
I did not get much except that not paying commissions was a very serious business.

I tried:  ‘us law’+ ‘unpaid commission’ + ‘contract employment’ + statue
Google had decided to change my typo ‘statue’ to ‘status’.   I pulled up the top website anyway because it was entitled, ‘Your Guide to Unpaid Commissions’
(employeelawgroup.com/your-guide-to-unpaid-commissions)

This site gave a detailed background on commissions and also listed the many ways that companies attempt to cheat salespeople out of commissions. They termed it ‘wrongful termination’, that is, sacking people to avoid paying commissions. This was what was happening in our case. It suggested filing a claim for wage theft with the states department of industrial relations.  
  They were also suggesting that the contract may have been ‘unconscionable’ which meant it put the salesperson at a distinct disadvantage.  Then I got to the real meat of this article for our case – the ‘forfeiture clause’.   This was the term I needed.   I wondered why our AI had not suggested it because it opened the door for further investigation. 
  What was impossible for me to reconcile was that they were writing from the perspective of California law and offered a strand of hope saying that the forfeiture clause may not be enforceable in California.  This posed to problem for our case because there was no indication of where the sales company in the trial was based or for that matter where the sale was made.

This was starting to look promising  except they were not a neutral website and they were selling their services. I put it on the back burner for the time being with the intention of possibly returning to it later in the current 20 minute session.
 
I reversed back to chrome and different sites were showing.

The top snippet was from ‘Smith Law Llc’  it described that commission should be paid if a salesperson loses their job. I pulled up the site, ‘Unpaid Commissions: What happens to commissions payable after termination?’  Strictly this was not exactly what I wanted because the crux of the matter was that the company had set up a forfeiture clause to deny this. 

In the first paragraph the site outlined this issue.

This Georgia site was discussing the exact area I needed to look into.  They offered hope to the salesperson saying that courts frowned upon contracts of the type that were in our trial.  They went on the mention that these contracts were lawful and enforceable unless there was something ambiguous in the terms.  As far as I knew there was nothing in the salesman’s contract that suggested ambiguity so I was still in the option (B) camp but not 100% now.

 I was mindful of the liberal tendencies of California and Georgia so if our trial was based there our salesman would have half a chance of prevailing in court. Of the other 48 states I could not say.

I put into Chrome: 
‘us law’+ ‘unpaid commission’ + ‘contract employment’ + ‘forfeiture clause’

I scrolled down the snippets and pulled up another site that alluded to ‘forfeiture clause’. It was another professional legal site, YusafButtar,  ‘Are Commissions Owed After Termination of Employment?’ (buttar-law.com/are-commissions-owed-after-termination-of-employment/)
The site was rather vague but tended to state in various paragraphs that if there was ‘cause’ then the salesperson would not prevail.  They also stated the confounding issue for me that different states approached these matters differently.

From the ‘People also search for’ at the bottom of the page I followed the Google suggestion, ‘Suing for unpaid commissions’

Top snippet (Myers & Co.) stated that as an employee you are entitled to be paid according to your contract.    That was not useful to me.

I put into Chrome:  ‘Suing from unpaid commissions’ + ‘forfeiture provisions’+ ‘us law’
From the snippets I gathered that even in Georgia our salesman would not prevail unless there was ambiguity.

Returning to the snippets I pulled up Shouse Law Group California ‘California Law on Commission Pay After Termination’
(shouselaw.com/ca/blog/california-law-on-commission-pay-after-termination/)

I was thinking if it was dubious for California too, there would be little concrete hope for our salesman.  This site explained the ‘forfeiture provisions’ in starker terms.  Our salesman had no chance.

I tried:  ‘Suing from unpaid commissions’ + ‘forfeiture provisions’+ ‘us law’+ ‘won’

I pulled up from the snippets, Just Answer, ‘Can I sue my employer for unpaid commissions ?’  (justanswer.com/employment-law...)
It was a question and answer regarding commissions.  It was supposed to be an expert at the other side.  It was not useful in any way and  judging by the style of writing it was not a human expert, probably just a sales bot.

My timer had stopped and I was almost 100% confident in option (B).

I had been beginning to get a sense of how Lojban worked.  It was not the kind of phasing in Lojban that was going to cause me problems. column10: After my research: A (.eâ€™u miâ€™o zgana lo solnuncanci): 100%; B (.eâ€™u miâ€™a zgana lo solnuncanci): 0%
column12:
On first reading I did not know the correct answer but I was confident that I could find it. The meanings of ‘mi’o’ and ‘mi’a’ were key to the choices here.  I had been beginning to get a sense of how Lojban worked.  It was not the kind of phasing in Lojban that was going to cause me problems.  I had a few of authoritative online resources and felt I could corroborate too within the timespan.

On reading the AI explanation I was somewhat sceptical, it looked like something the AI could mix up. I went a few degrees only in favour of the AI’s choice of option (A),  which according to the AI used  ‘mi'o’ to include ‘I’ and ‘you’.  
All I needed to do was to check my most reliable online resources and see if the AI had worked it out correctly for ‘mi’o’ and ‘mi’a’.

I began my online investigation with ‘complete Lojban’
I pulled up ‘The Complete Lojban Language’ by  J.W.Cowan (lojban.org/publications/cll/cll_v1.1_book.pdf)

I was happy to trust this authoritative text, if I could understand it. It was not as simple as the ‘instant’ online translators which could be extremely poor.  This work just took a little more reading and understanding to manage.

I put into my local windows search with the Pdf still up:	 mi’o

I got 13 hits for this.  Clicked to each section with ‘mi’o’ and read around some of the theory too. It was very clear to me that the AI had got it spot on this time.
Something that I did notice that the AI had successfully navigated was that ‘mi’o’ and ‘mi’a’ where often mentioned together with other related words so I imagined that could be confusing for a person or an AI if they did not really get a handle on what the text was driving at. 
I noticed one particular sentence (pp.140 or 6/14 on local search) in the Lobjan book where it discussed  mi'o, mi'a, ma'a, and do'o  as a group of related forms.  If just this sentence had been scraped by the AI without the related context it would be too universal to differentiate the meanings of ‘mi’a’ and ‘mi’o’ and effectively would not make any sense at all.  In the sentence it was using ‘and/or’ in combination with the listener, speaker and other people.  It was valid with regards to describing the collective scope of these forms but it smudges the individual meanings.

With regards to ‘mi’a’ it was mentioned on many of the same pages as mi’o.  Mi’a was in option (B) and the AI concurred precisely with the Complete Lojban in excluding the listener.

Content with what I had found in this work I returned to Chrome to find a corroborating source.

I put into Chrome:   lojban dictionary
I pulled up the ‘The Logical Language Group, Online Dictionary Query’
(jbovlaste.lojban.org/lookup.pl?Form=…)  It was some kind of meta-search engine that I had found decent results from before.

In the jbovlaste search  I put in: 		mi’a
It was not the most user friendly of resources but I had found reliable results in the past. It listed out Lojban to different languages.  In the Lojban to English part it clearly describe ‘mi’a’  in a way that aligned very clearly with the AI definition,  ‘we, not you’ and so on.

This could be a little disconcerting because it automatically put searches in  to its engine that were links too, and filled the search before I got back to the main query page.

I put in:		 mi’o
I got the confirmation I needed concurring with the AI explanation in option (A) and the Complete Lojban book.

I finished a few minutes early because I had what I needed. Based on the reliable sources I had online and the AI explanation I was extremely confident in my choice of option (A) -  .e'u mi'o zgana lo solnuncanci.

column12:
One first reading the trial I had an inking that there would be an exception for the opposing party so I went with option (A) that the declaration from the criminal court would be permissible.

On reading the AI  explanation and choice,  this helped me fill in the gaps of knowledge and I was more confident with option (A). 

I began my online investigation in  Chrome with: 
‘opposing party’ + hearsay

From the top snippet (Cornell Law School) this concurred with the AI explanation stating that party-opponents are excluded from the category of hearsay. In our case the opponents would be the security personnel  
since a certain officer employed there had been charged with manslaughter and his testimony was to be presented at the civil proceedings in the form of a verified transcript. 

I pulled up the article from the top snippet ‘Rule 801. Definitions That Apply to This Article; Exclusions from Hearsay’
(law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_801#)

Reading through the conditions that were  NOT hearsay which continued from 801(d) we have 801(d)(2)(D) titled ‘Opposing Parties Statement’ which appeared to be relevant for our security guard. This described a party agent while he was in that role.  This would fit with the security guard before he stopped being employed there. This would indicate that our security guard’s transcript is admissible.

It also continued with  801(d)(2) regarding Admissions. I gathered that an admission was a statement made by the declarant which is being used against himself.  Apparently in theory this would give him an opportunity to deny, explain or refute  the statement and so on.  Unfortunately this was not possible, he could not do that because he was refusing to attend on the grounds that he was in the middle of a manslaughter appeal.

After reading through Rule 801 I think I had found what I needed, I decided to continue a little longer and look at some of the related links.

Following the link at the bottom of the page ‘Article V111-Hearsay’
(law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/article_VIII)  I got the impression that this page was getting much further out from where I needed to look and was not directly relevant for my case.  However I found a link at the bottom of the page that may  offer better prospects. I clicked on ‘Rule 804. Hearsay Exceptions; Declarant Unavailable’ (law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_804)

As I mentioned previously our security guard had refused to attend on the grounds that he has in the middle of a manslaughter appeal.  I thought this rule may shed to some light on why he was justified in not attending. I gathered the 5th amendment may be valid here and he may be reticent because of self incrimination.

The legal rhetoric was getting hard to manage but 804(B)(1)(b) appeared to suggest that since our guard had been cross examined in the criminal trial previously under court conditions that would be good enough. I would suppose this would apply to allowing the presentation of the verified transcript at the civil case.

I had got to the end of my 20 minutes so I went to the questions page and put the slider to a high confidence in option (A). I was not supremely confident because I felt I could have easily overlooked some significant factor because of all the clauses and sub-clauses in the legal discussion.

column12:
PIE is a serious condition. It can cause death if not correctly treated. For this reason, treatment is done inside a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

Treatment is done to make sure your child gets enough oxygen. It also aims to prevent more air leaks. Treatment may include:

Lying your baby on the side with the air leak, which helps move more air into the lung that is working well
Lowering ventilator pressure if possible, to help prevent more air leaks
Using high-frequency oscillatory ventilation, which may lower pressure in the air sacs
Giving extra oxygen

column12:
Courts recognize an implied-in-law contract in situations where one party might otherwise be unjustly enriched at the expense of another party. A key characteristic of such contracts is that a contract may be recognized to exist even though neither party had the intention to enter into an agreement.

The following scenario is an example of an implied-in-law contract. Bob, who is a doctor, happens to be walking by a neighbor’s house and sees the neighbor suddenly collapse on his front porch. Bob rushes to his neighbor’s aid, determines that he has suffered a stroke, and provides medical treatment to the neighbor until emergency services personnel arrive.

Later on, Bob submits a bill for his medical services to the neighbor. A court will typically recognize an implied-in-law contract to exist between Bob and his neighbor simply because the basic principle of fairness decrees that Bob should receive just compensation for the professional services he provided, even though the neighbor did not request the services nor, at the time, possess any intention of paying Bob.

After my research, i believe The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporation's headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.
the following requirements must be followed for silence to be deemed acceptance:

The offer must be concise and specific: Silence must be regarded acceptance if the offer is explicit and not subject to interpretation.
The offeree must be aware of the offer: For silence to be deemed acceptance, the offeree must be informed of the offer and its conditions.
The offer must be made in conditions when silence would be considered unusual: Silence must be fair to suppose that a response would be anticipated if the offeree did not plan to accept for silence to be deemed acceptance.
The offeree must be given a fair chance to reject the offer: The offeree must be given a fair length of time to contemplate the offer and, if desired, reject it.
The offeror must not specify that silence is not an acceptable form of acceptance: The offeror must not state that silence is not an acceptable form of acceptance, nor must a particular action be taken to accept the offer.
It is always better to get legal guidance if in doubt. Furthermore, remember that silence is not always regarded as an acceptable form of approval, particularly in contracts with substantial monetary value or legal ramifications, where verbal assent is frequently necessary.

Silent contracts generally are not valid. When someone makes you an offer and you do not respond to it, you normally will not be bound to a contract. Your silence is not considered an acceptance if you do not truly intend to accept the agreement. This is true even if the person making the offer specifically says that your silence is considered an acceptance.

A "breach" of the contract is one party's failure to fulfill any of its contractual obligations. There are three requirements for a breach:

1. A valid contract, ( The company, gave the executive a valid contract)
2. Performance by one party, (being for the performance of the executive in the company for the past years). and 
3. Damages suffered by the performing party,   (Unable to fulfil payment of recreational vehicle worth $30,000  which might incure late fees charges for him and other damages, emotionally, mentally)

If the breaching party:

Fails to perform on time,
Fails to perform at all, or
Fails to perform according to the terms of the agreement.

It’s most often used to diagnose a common condition among older adults ( the Man is 63 years old which fits the criteria) called peripheral artery disease (PAD). PAD is caused by hardening of the arteries in the pelvis or legs. It can cause leg cramps, pain, and fatigue in the leg or hip muscles when walking or climbing stairs. ( same as his situation)

It’s important to diagnose and treat narrowing or blockages in the leg arteries. Complete loss of blood flow to the legs can lead to tissue death (gangrene) and amputation.

column10: After my research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 60%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 40%
column12: Insertion of an endotracheal tube.  The first priority in treating the burn victim is to ensure that the airway (breathing passages) remains open. Associated smoke inhalation injury is very common, particularly if the patient has been burned in a closed space, such as a room or building. Even patients burned in an open area may sustain smoke inhalation. Risk for smoke inhalation is greatest in victims who have injuries to the upper torso or burns of the face and in victims who cough up carbonaceous material or soot. If inhalation injury seems likely, an anesthesiologist or surgeon passes a tube through the patient’s nose or mouth into the trachea. This endotracheal tube allows the administration of high concentrations of oxygen and the use of a mechanical ventilator.

In most states, there is no longer any minimum age for a witness. This means the child is incompetent to testify

column10: After my research: A (Undue influence.): 65%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 35%
column12: Undue influence.Undue influence most commonly occurs when a more powerful party exerts its influence over a less powerful party in order to achieve its desired outcome. Undue influence is one of the grounds of relief developed by the courts of equity as a court of conscience. The objective is to ensure that the influence of one person over another is not abused. In everyday life people constantly seek to influence the decisions of others. They seek to persuade those with whom they are dealing to enter into transactions, whether great or small. The law has set limits to the means properly employable for this purpose. The law will investigate the manner in which the intention to enter into the transaction was secured: If the intention was produced by an unacceptable means, the law will not permit the transaction to stand. The means used is regarded as an exercise of improper or 'undue' influence, and hence unacceptable, whenever the consent thus procured ought not fairly to be treated as the expression of a person's free will. It is impossible to be more precise or definitive. The circumstances in which one person acquires influence over another, and the manner in which influence may be exercised, vary too widely to permit of any more specific criterion.

column12:
The privilege against self-incrimination parries the general obligation to provide testimony under oath when called upon, but it also applies in police interrogations. In all cases, the privilege must be supported by a reasonable fear that a response will be incriminatory. The issue is a matter of law for a court to determine,  and therefore, with limited exceptions, one must claim the privilege to benefit from it. Otherwise, silence in the face of questioning may be insufficient to invoke the privilege because it may not afford an adequate opportunity either to test whether information withheld falls within the privilege or to cure a violation through a grant of immunity.  The woman invoked her right to remain silent to avoid self-incrimination only, she didnt explicitly plead the fifth, so it will be Disallow , on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.

A witness who fails to claim the privilege explicitly when an affirmative claim is required is deemed to have waived it, and waiver may be found where the witness has answered some preliminary questions but desires to stop at a certain point. However, an assertion of innocence in conjunction with a claim of the privilege does not obviate the right of witnesses to invoke it, as their responses still may provide the government with evidence it may later seek to use against them.

The admissibility of the officer's testimony about the driver's statement should be disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception. As stated by Findlay.com "Hearsay is an out-of-court statement used to prove the truth of what was said. For example, a police officer testifies about what an eyewitness said to them at a crime scene. In general, prosecutors can't use this testimony to actually prove what happened.

These out-of-court statements are not limited to only spoken words. They can also be documents, written statements, or body language. For example, nodding is non-verbal conduct to indicate yes."
