column10: After my research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 40%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 60%
column12:
the evidence should be Admitted, but only if it's obtained from the expert witness during cross examination. because the section of the law states clearly that : It should be noted that the extrinsic evidence prohibition of Rule 608(b) bars any reference to the consequences that a witness might have suffered as a result of an alleged bad act. For example, Rule 608(b) prohibits counsel from mentioning that a witness was suspended or disciplined for the conduct that is the subject of impeachment, when that conduct is offered only to prove the character of the witness. See United States v. Davis, 183 F.3d 231, 257 n.12 (3d Cir. 1999) (emphasizing that in attacking the defendant's character for truthfulness “the government cannot make reference to Davis's forty-four day suspension or that Internal Affairs found that he lied about” an incident because “[s]uch evidence would not only be hearsay to the extent it contains assertion of fact, it would be inadmissible extrinsic evidence under Rule 608(b)”). See also Stephen A. Saltzburg, Impeaching the Witness: Prior Bad Acts and Extrinsic Evidence, 7 Crim. Just. 28, 31 (Winter 1993) (“counsel should not be permitted to circumvent the no-extrinsic-evidence provision by tucking a third person's opinion about prior acts into a question asked of the witness who has denied the act.”).


The Rule has been amended to clarify that the absolute prohibition on extrinsic evidence applies only when the sole reason for proffering that evidence is to attack or support the witness’ character for truthfulness. See United States v. Abel, 469 U.S. 45 (1984); United States v. Fusco, 748 F.2d 996 (5th Cir. 1984) (Rule 608(b) limits the use of evidence “designed to show that the witness has done things, unrelated to the suit being tried, that make him more or less believable per se”); Ohio R.Evid. 608(b). On occasion the Rule's use of the overbroad term “credibility” has been read “to bar extrinsic evidence for bias, competency and contradiction impeachment since they too deal with credibility.” American Bar Association Section of Litigation, Emerging Problems Under the Federal Rules of Evidence at 161 (3d ed. 1998). The amendment conforms the language of the Rule to its original intent, which was to impose an absolute bar on extrinsic evidence only if the sole purpose for offering the evidence was to prove the witness’ character for veracity. See Advisory Committee Note to Rule 608(b) (stating that the Rule is “[i]n conformity with Rule 405, which forecloses use of evidence of specific incidents as proof in chief of character unless character is in issue in the case . . .”).

column10: After my research: A (Permissible as a declaration made by a representative of an opposing party.): 65%; B (Not permissible, as it constitutes hearsay without any qualifying exception.): 35%
column12:
The legal status of this evidence is Permissible as a declaration made by a representative of an opposing party. A prior statement by a witness is not hearsay if (a) the previous statement is inconsistent with the witness's current testimony and the previous statement was made in a proceeding under oath, subject to penalty of perjury. (801(d)(1)(a));[11] OR
(b) the previous statement is consistent with the witness's current testimony and the previous statement is being used to rehabilitate the witness's credibility. (801(d)(1)(b)); OR
(c) it is the witness's own prior identification of a person. (801(d)(1)(c))

Children under 6 months of age: Beyond clinical screening exams, US (ultrasound) is the preferred technique. Most obstructions resolve by allowing the small bowel to rest and shrink back to its normal size, thus making the adhesions less problematic. This is accomplished by inserting a nasogastric (NG) tube (a thin plastic tube that goes through a nostril and into the stomach) that suctions fluid from the stomach.

Treatment may include:

Intravenous (IV) fluids: You may need IV fluids and electrolytes to treat dehydration.
Nasogastric tube: You may need a nasogastric tube to suction out fluids and air backed up from the blockage. A nasogastric tube is a long, thin tube that goes in through your nose but reaches down into your stomach or intestines.
Medications: You may need anti-emetics to prevent nausea and vomiting and pain relievers to keep you more comfortable.

This is a very tricky one because i dont believe either option is the answer. According to https://www.legalzoom.com/articles/understanding-your-unilateral-contract

Specific to the performance type, the old law was that—even if the offeree had started performing—the offeror could still revoke the contract. This is no longer the case: Once an offeree starts a physical performance of the contract, the offeror can't revoke a unilateral contract. For example, once the person begins climbing the Empire State Building steps, the offeror must pay if the person completes the task.

However, the offeror can revoke the reward type of unilateral contract at any time, so long as the offeror clearly conveys that they've revoked the offer. (If the offeror posted signs for the reward, then the offeror should post similar signs stating that they've revoked the unilateral contract.) In a reward type contract, the contract isn't fully performed if the dog hasn't been found. Accordingly, an offeror of a unilateral contract for such a reward can revoke it at any time before the dog is found.

i believe this unilateral contract between the bank and the customer is a reward type for compensation which can be revoked since the bank declared and removed the sign before the customer 5 minutes lapsed.

because the customer have already started the performance.

column12:
Another tricky one. but in my opinion the construction company violate the contract because Yes, because there was no consideration provided for the removal of the construction company's duty to install the pavement

https://viewpoint.pwc.com/dt/us/en/pwc/accounting_guides/revenue_from_contrac/revenue_from_contrac_US/chapter_2_scope_and__US/29contract_modificat_US.html#pwc_topic
states that Modifications that reduce the scope of a contract
As described in RR 2.9.2, a modification is accounted for as a separate contract only if distinct goods or services are added to the contract for a price equal to standalone selling price (adjusted for contract-specific circumstances). Modifications that reduce the scope of a contract would not be accounted for as a separate contract because they do not solely add distinct goods or services to the contract. Therefore, the accounting for a modification that reduces the scope of a contract depends on whether the remaining goods or services are distinct from the goods or services transferred before the modification:
If the remaining goods or services are distinct (including goods or services that are part of a series), the modification is accounted for prospectively as if it were a termination of the existing contract and creation of a new contract. Refer to RR 2.9.3.1.
If the remaining goods or services are not distinct (for example, a single performance obligation is being modified), the modification is accounted for on a cumulative catch-up basis. Refer to RR 2.9.3.2. which still makes the contruction company not to violate the contract, but

 Consideration is a legal term used to describe the benefit each party to a contract receives. This is often payment in exchange for goods or services. Consideration doesn't actually have to be money though – it can be anything of value that you get as part of a contract, like equipment or work. The property gets nothing of consideration since the pavement is not done so the propery owner will like succeed because there was no consideration provided for the removal of the construction company's duty to install the pavement

column10: After my research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 65%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 35%
column12:
the court's decision on whether the pedestrian's statement is admissible, should the court take into account the doctor's affidavit

Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.

according to https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_803

 Exceptions to the Rule Against Hearsay states that (1) Present Sense Impression. A statement describing or explaining an event or condition, made while or immediately after the declarant perceived it.

(2) Excited Utterance. A statement relating to a startling event or condition, made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement that it caused.

(3) Then-Existing Mental, Emotional, or Physical Condition. A statement of the declarant’s then-existing state of mind (such as motive, intent, or plan) or emotional, sensory, or physical condition (such as mental feeling, pain, or bodily health), but not including a statement of memory or belief to prove the fact remembered or believed unless it relates to the validity or terms of the declarant’s will.

(4) Statement Made for Medical Diagnosis or Treatment. A statement that:

(A) is made for — and is reasonably pertinent to — medical diagnosis or treatment; and

(B) describes medical history; past or present symptoms or sensations; their inception; or their general cause.

(5) Recorded Recollection. A record that:

(A) is on a matter the witness once knew about but now cannot recall well enough to testify fully and accurately;

(B) was made or adopted by the witness when the matter was fresh in the witness’s memory; and

(C) accurately reflects the witness’s knowledge.

If admitted, the record may be read into evidence but may be received as an exhibit only if offered by an adverse party.

column12:
the evidence of the defendant's involvement in the prior scheme be admitted to establish the lack of mistake. Rule 404(b) gives prosecutors a big loophole -- it allows evidence of a person's past criminal/immoral conduct if it helps prove an issue other than the defendant’s tendency to behave like a criminal. They can be divided into five groups
Identity
Motive
Intent, knowledge, absence of mistake or accident Preparation or plan
Opportunity

Prior acts of criminality are not admissible to prove that the person committed a similar crime, i.e., if Bill Cosby is on trial for sexually assaulting Andrea Constand in Philadelphia in 2004, the prosecutor cannot call Beth Ferrier as a witness to testify that Cosby gave her drugs and sexually assaulted her in 1986. Nor can he call 50 women to testify Cosby drugged and assaulted them. The only reason it would be relevant is prove that he has a pattern of criminal behavior, which is also known as character evidence.
The prosecutor needs to come up with a relevant reason why the jury should hear about Cosby’s past acts. It must be a genuine disputed issue of real consequence or Rule 403 will exclude it. The prejudicial effect is obvious -- the whole world has made up its mind that Cosby is guilty based solely on the number of claims. The jury will too if it hears about them, so prejudicial effect will substantially outweigh probative value unless the issue is genuine. That means the prosecutor cannot just say that evidence tens to show his identity, intent, motive, which are always relevant issues. This is just propensity/character evidence.

column12:
The presiding judge in the case should determine this testimony as excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay and does not qualify for any exceptions.

 The present rule proceeds upon the theory that under appropriate circumstances a hearsay statement may possess circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness sufficient to justify nonproduction of the declarant in person at the trial even though he may be available. The theory finds vast support in the many exceptions to the hearsay rule developed by the common law in which unavailability of the declarant is not a relevant factor. The present rule is a synthesis of them, with revision where modern developments and conditions are believed to make that course appropriate.

In a hearsay situation, the declarant is, of course, a witness, and neither this rule nor Rule 804 dispenses with the requirement of firsthand knowledge. It may appear from his statement or be inferable from circumstances.

See Rule 602.

Exceptions (1) and (2). In considerable measure these two examples overlap, though based on somewhat different theories. The most significant practical difference will lie in the time lapse allowable between event and statement.

The underlying theory of Exception [paragraph] (1) is that substantial contemporaneity of event and statement negative the likelihood of deliberate of conscious misrepresentation. Moreover, if the witness is the declarant, he may be examined on the statement. If the witness is not the declarant, he may be examined as to the circumstances as an aid in evaluating the statement. Morgan, Basic Problems of Evidence 340–341 (1962).

The theory of Exception [paragraph] (2) is simply that circumstances may produce a condition of excitement which temporarily stills the capacity of reflection and produces utterances free of conscious fabrication. 6 Wigmore §1747, p. 135. Spontaneity is the key factor in each instance, though arrived at by somewhat different routes. Both are needed in order to avoid needless niggling.

The first option is wrong because it must be fairly inputted through cross examination not just dropped in. "(a) Reputation or Opinion Evidence. A witness’s credibility may be attacked or supported by testimony about the witness’s reputation for having a character for truthfulness or untruthfulness, or by testimony in the form of an opinion about that character. But evidence of truthful character is admissible only after the witness’s character for truthfulness has been attacked.

(b) Specific Instances of Conduct. Except for a criminal conviction under Rule 609, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness’s conduct in order to attack or support the witness’s character for truthfulness. column12: A CT scan would not be appropriate for a painless mass that has not had other investigations carried out first. A CT scan of the abdomen may be performed to assess the abdomen and its organs for tumors and other lesions, injuries, intra-abdominal bleeding, infections, unexplained abdominal pain, obstructions, or other conditions, particularly when another type of examination, such as X-rays or physical examination, is not conclusive. In this scenario, once a physical examination has been carried out, the best course of action would be to monitor the situation. Due to the painless mass, it is likely to be benign and not cancerous. Alternative treatments would include- a physical exam, transilumination, an ultrasound, a urine test, a blood test. If other tests show you have testicular cancer, you'll likely get this series of X-rays. A CT scan of your chest, stomach area and groin can check to see if cancer has spread to other tissues or organs.

column12:
I think that the case would have been dismissed as there was not substantial evidence of each element of the offense and of the identity of the defendant as the perpetrator. Upon a defense motion to dismiss for insufficient evidence, the question to be decided by the judge is whether there is “substantial evidence” of: (i) each essential element of the offense (or lesser-included offense); and (ii) the identity of the defendant as the perpetrator of that offense. I don't think that there was evidence for either of these things. 
If it was not dismissed it would have been disallowed further down the line due to the 'hearsay' rules but I believe it would have been dismissed before it got this far in court.

As his heart rate is above 90 bpm (Heart rate: Healthcare providers should consider fluid administration when the heart rate exceeds 90 bpm) Also his blood pressure needs to be considered 'Blood pressure: Healthcare providers should contemplate fluid administration when the systolic blood pressure falls below 100 mm Hg'. Without the additional fluid intake he could suffer from burn shock and further problems to his internal organs could arise. 'Patients with burns of more than 20% - 25% of their body surface should be managed with aggressive IV fluid resuscitation to prevent “burn shock."

This covers places such as bathrooms, locker rooms, changing rooms, etc. Generally, if people are likely to undress in the area and see it as a private space, there should not be any cameras there. Other than in these private areas, the use of video surveillance is entirely lawful across all 50 states.' I do not believe that the commercial property constitutes as a private space to the CCTV was legally allowed to be there. As the question states that CCTV had been confirmed as being accurate and reliable, I believe that it can be used as a point of evidence. 'When correctly authenticated and presented, visual evidence can be compelling and influential in determining the outcome of court cases.' column12:
I looked at an online Lojban grammar dictionary and compared the two difference sentences. 
ke'o [vocative] — Eh? Please repeat!, ke'o nai — I heard you. No need to repeat

ke'u [interjection] — I repeat, as I already said, ke'u nai — furthermore, what is more (continuing)

I believe that the example sentence was an interjection, so the correct grammar would be ke'u.

column6: Before research: A (zaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 50%; B (gaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 50%
column10: After research: A (zaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 20%; B (gaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 80%
column12:
The sentence was- 'As you saw, a snake bit me.'
It was written in two different ways. One way was 'za'a' and the second way was 'ga'a'. I chose Option B as I believe that the sentence is referring to an observer/ acknoledging what had been observed and therefore the correct grammar would be the 'ga'a' as a preposition rather than 'za'a' as an interjection. 

za'a [interjection] — I observe
i oi nai za'a melbi tcima — Oh, what a nice weather.
i za'a le mi'u aftobuso cu jai lerci — Apparently, the bus is late.
i za'a cladu bu'u le bartu — I can hear the loud sound outside.
i ja'o carmi carvi — So it must be raining heavily.
Comment: za'a is for expressing external experience, se'o is for expressing internal experience.
Related words: zgana, lanli

ga'a [preposition from zgana] — to observer ..., observed by ..., adverb: being observed
i ga'a mi ca cerni — To me it's morning now.
Comment: not limited to vision. When used as a preposition (with a noun after it) the clause itself describes what is being observed. When used after ne the clause itself describes sense via one observes.

and

column12: I believe that the passengers statement is inadmissible evidence because it is not necessary for the case. The background to what happened before the driver was pulled over for drink driving is irrelevant because the prosecution have evidence of the fact that the driver was over the legal limit. What happened before the driver was pulled over is not important in this circumstance. Character evidence is a witness’s personal knowledge about a person’s behavior or trait of characters—such as the witness’s opinion about the person or information about the person’s reputation, prior acts, and criminal convictions. Fed. R. Evid. 404. Character evidence usually is inadmissible. Discussing the social event which happened before the drivers got into the car would distract the jury from focusing on the drink driving offence and the evidence obtained at the scene. There is also an argument that as they were the only vehicle involved, the reliability of this passengers statement is under question. He was also admitting to being under the influence of alcohol himself which could affect his credibility.

column12:
I checked whether what she said would be considered hearsay. Dying declarations are exempt but only for criminal cases and this is a civil case. She also cannot be compelled not to give evidence by her husband because of spousal privilege because the marriage ended when her husband died. Finally, the husband's statement was against his self interest which is an exception to hearsay and allows it to be admitted as evidence to court and it does apply to civil cases. 

The wife can testify only if she wants to though and can claim spousal privilege if she wishes.

column10: After research: A (Yes, because the clientâ€™s message and the attorneyâ€™s actions resulted in a contract implied-in-fact.): 77%; B (Yes, because the attorneyâ€™s response to the clientâ€™s note led to a disadvantage to him.): 23%
column12:
The note to the lawyer is likely to be taken by a reasonable person as a contract offer. The lawyer's responses in the form of his advice and invoice can be taken as implied-in-fact acceptance of the contract offer (assuming that a reasonable time had not lapsed since the offer). All the other elements necessary for a contract were present: Mutual asset, adequate consideration (no evidence of economic benefit is needed for a binding contract), legality and capacity. 

No formal documentation is needed for all contracts. The note constituted an offer of a contract and the lawyers submission of an invoice consitituted acceptance. This meets the criteria of offer and acceptance and the lawyer's actions make the contract accepted as implied-in-fact and therefore binding.

column6: Before research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 66%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 34%
column7: I was fairly sure that dying declarations were an exception to hearsay rules but did not know about the minutae concerning their operation
column10: After research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 88%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 12%
column12:
Hearsay is when a person makes a declaration which is witnessed by a third party and is not generally admissible as evidence by that third party. Exceptions include dying declarations, which is when a person who believes in their imminent death makes a declaration based on their actual knowledge about the events concerning their death. Such declarations, although not testable in court, have a long history and override the sixth amendment-sourced confrontation clause that says testimony must be testable in court. Senior courts have ruled that dying declarations can be an exception to the sixth amendment and are admissible as evidence in court and are not, as such, testimonial in nature. 

I began by looking at exceptions to hearsay, then focused on "dying declarations" which is the correct legal phrase to search for. This led me to a number of legal-type websites and papers, many of which were professionally orientated. I came across the confrontation clause later in the search and read about how it might impact upon dying declarations in a 2012 article. I later found a more recent article that expanded upon this in more detail showing that the sixth amendment may not apply to such declarations and felt very confident that the correct result was A) - the judge could allow the dying declaration as an exception to not allowing hearsay.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, to demonstrate the defendantâ€™s inclination to engage in such criminal activity.): 26%; B (Yes, to establish the lack of mistake.): 74%
column7: I believed that previous convictions were not admissible as evidence of character and likelihood of committing another crime.
column10: After research: A (Yes, to demonstrate the defendantâ€™s inclination to engage in such criminal activity.): 9%; B (Yes, to establish the lack of mistake.): 91%
column12:
Prior acts of bad behaviour are generally not admissible in court and doing so might give grounds for a successful appeal. One document noted the "forbidden propensity inference" which shows that the evidence is probably inadmissible for a) (the inclination to engage in such activities). Such evidence is, however, admissible to demonstrate an absence of mistake or accident under the Federal Rule of Evidence 404(B). This explictly forbids evidence of propensity but allows for other purposes such as showing the absence of mistake or accident. 

I began by searching for how evidence of prior behaviour is examined in US fraud cases. This led me to a formal paper that discussed how prior acts are not generally admissible except in certain circumstances. I searched another few sites. One did not appear to have any useful information but the others confirmed the first document's details and expanded upon them to give me a better understanding of whether evidence of prior behaviour was admissible and under what circumstances.

column12:
The doctor is examining for damage to the supraspinatous muscle in the collection of muscles that makes up the rotator cuff. The test being done is known as Jobe's test, the Empty Can test or Supraspinatous test and the patient's arm is abducted to 90 degrees and then the arm rotated and angled forward 30 degrees with the humb pointing down. The observation, however, of an ededatous indicates that the damage may be infraspinatous and the doctor is testing the supraspinatous to ensure it's not damaged too. 

The search began with defining edematous. After that, I searched for what abducting meant before searching for abduction of the shoulder for infraspinatous or supraspinatous muscles. I began a parallel search for shoulder and supraspinatous on one and infraspinatous on the other. After discovering a number of tests, I finally found the definition of a test that matched that in the question (Jobe's test) that was used to test for damage to the supraspinatous muscle. An edmeatous shoulder was not, however, a sign of that but rather of an infraspinatous shoulder but the question asked what muscle was the doctor testing for and not what shoulder was likely to be damaged. The sites I checked were orientated to medical professionals and I ignored those that appeared to be less obviously professional. The information was repeated on more than one site so I felt very confident that the doctor was testing B) the supraspinatous muscle for damage.

column6: Before research: A (Permissible as evidence, on the grounds that a confession from one participant in a crime is legally admissible against the other participant.): 25%; B (Impermissible as evidence, given the situation, there was no duty or obligation for accused B to respond to the accusations.): 75%
column7: My understanding was that suspects in the US do not have to answer questions put to them when in custody.
column10: After research: A (Permissible as evidence, on the grounds that a confession from one participant in a crime is legally admissible against the other participant.): 10%; B (Impermissible as evidence, given the situation, there was no duty or obligation for accused B to respond to the accusations.): 90%
column12:
I chose B) because suspects don't have the duty to respond to questions. The Miranda rights and fifth amendment (the right to silence/not self-incriminate) appear to be orientated towards questions from the police rather than another suspect when in custody. Indeed, I found no information about a duty to answer questions from anyone other than the police so was not able to exactly discover for sure. However, I felt that if suspects didn't have to answer questions from the police under the fifth amendment, it would probably apply to any questions. I was fairly sure that both suspects were in custody at the time. 

My search began by discovering the Miranda rights and found that they apply only when in custody. I followed by trying to find out if they applied to questions from persons other than the police but was unable to determine that. From my reading of the question, both suspects were in custody so the Miranda rights should apply to questions from the police. I finished by trying to find out the answer to the question of non-police questions but found nothing. I still felt confident that the rights applied to questions from anyone. The suspect B also had the right to have an attorney present when questioned and this option was not mentioned so I assumed it was not asked of suspect B.

I then searched for one of the symptoms (reduced pulses on one side) to see if any specific diagnoses came up and found a page on the NIH website which discussed the blood system in more detail. Not satisfied, I searched for impaired blood flow on one side and looked at a The Cleveland Clinic page and eventually found information on carotid artery stenosis. I examined for the systolic blood pressure - this was my least likely choice and I thought to falsify it and found nothing with "systolic blood pressure related to the symptoms. I then entered all symptoms together and got a Medline page that showed the symptoms under "Peripheral artery disease" but the symptoms of dizziness and vertigo were not mentioned. After refining the search, I went again to MedlinePlus that had an article about "subclavian artery stenosis" that matched all symptoms including age, the patient being a smoker and everything else. One treatment discussed was having a stent inserted. The page also mentioned that systolic blood pressure differed with the contralateral extremity so I felt confident that the answer was B - inserting a stent in the subclavian artery was best.

column6: Before research: A (Denied, as it is considered hearsay and does not fall within any recognized exceptions.): 23%; B (Admitted and considered as valid evidence of the womanâ€™s state of intoxication at the time of the incident.): 77%
column7: I know a little about hearsay exceptions and prior convictions as evidence and felt the conviction could be used as a record of fact in a civil case but wasn't entirely sure.
column10: After research: A (Denied, as it is considered hearsay and does not fall within any recognized exceptions.): 8%; B (Admitted and considered as valid evidence of the womanâ€™s state of intoxication at the time of the incident.): 92%
column12:
I began by understanding about exceptions to hearsay. "matter of record" were an exception if properly evidenced but I wasn't sure if they could be in civil cases because I know the courts are keen on enforcing this. They key thing is that the woman's record wasn't being submitted as evidence of propensity but rather as a factual finding and evidential (following a guilty plea) that she was intoxicated at the time of the accident. Searching showed a preponderance of articles about prior convictions being used to impeach court participants but this was not the aim of the litigant. Eventually, I found a site of a Canadian law firm that discussed the situation in the US and said that criminal convictions were not just admissible in subsequent civil proceedings but were also determinative of the facts upon which the case was based 

Given that she pled guilty to driving while intoxicated, it seems reasonable for a court to accept her conviction as evidence of her intoxication as long as it's not used to indicate that she has a propensity to drive while intoxicated. Hence B is the answer I chose.

column6: Before research: A (prevail, due to the fact that Xavier deliberately negotiated and procured a quitclaim deed from Zoey in anticipation of securing the apple orchard.): 62%; B (emerge victorious, as Xavier, by offering the initial $1,500 payment, is estopped from renouncing the validity of his contractual agreement with Zoey.): 38%
column7: I was not sure what a quitclaim deed was or estoppel but felt that the contract had been made and needed to be fulfilled.
column10: After research: A (prevail, due to the fact that Xavier deliberately negotiated and procured a quitclaim deed from Zoey in anticipation of securing the apple orchard.): 75%; B (emerge victorious, as Xavier, by offering the initial $1,500 payment, is estopped from renouncing the validity of his contractual agreement with Zoey.): 25%
column12:
I searched to define "quitclaim deed" and "estopped" to understand the question better. I realised that a quitclaim deed is a transfer of ownership with effectively no obligations on the grantor (seller). Zoey had no claim on the land but that made no difference to the contract under which Xavier is obliged to pay the amount specified. I checked whether such one-sided contracts were enforceable but found nothing other than basic information about quitclaim deeds with the assumption they'd only be used in family situations. 

Quitclaim deeds may vary according to the state but in general terms, Xavier has to fulfill his contract to pay Zoey the full amount. The fact that he gained nothing is down to his lack of due diligence in ensuring that Zoey had the rights to transfer the land over to his ownership. 

I found Wikipedia a useful source of information and used it to search out more formal sources which were mostly lawyers' pages along with some reality-related sites. It was difficult to discover the exact status of a land purchase based on a quitclaim deed when ownership was not valid but my understanding of contract law is that it still stands irrespective of Zoey's lack of ownership.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 77%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 23%
column7: The contract for sale of the business depended upon the lease being transferred which was done. The contract was therefore enforceable from that perspective so A is the most likely.
column10: After research: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 90%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 10%
column12:
Verbal contracts are perfectly valid contracts albeit harder to prove than written. The agreement was made verbally and was contingent upon the land owner transferring the lease. If this did not happen, the contract would have been unenforceable. It did happen so the contract is enforceable and B cannot be the right answer. 

It is more likely that a court, if the verbal agreement between the uncle and his nephew could be proven, would find in favour of the nephew by stating that the contract was verbal but still valid. There may be state-related restrictions upon the sale of certain things (for example, the sale includes the lease of the property but some states say that such contracts must be written). 

I began by confirming that verbal contracts were valid and enforceable. Following this, I confirmed that a "contingent contract" is enforceable upon the contingency happening. This led to many websites, a lot of which were not relevant and not that authoritative. I felt my search terms were not good enough here and adjusted my search a few times. In addition, there were challenges in focusing on US law rather than (say) UK or Indian law, but discussed on websites focusing upon US-based lawyers!

column6: Before research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 30%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 70%
column7: I felt that because the woman had taken the stand, she was obliged to be cross-examined about matters concerning the damages.
column10: After research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 87%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 13%
column12:
The woman could invoke the right against self-incrimination in civil cases. If the consumption of those drugs was illegal in the state concerned, she would be preventing herself from being incriminated. She also has the right to not answer questions during cross-examination that are considered "collateral" to the issues at hand like, for example, things that impact upon her credibility, while still offering testimony. In a civil case, the judge / jury might draw an adverse inference. 

This means that although she's taken the stand, she has no obligation to answer any questions, just those that are relevant. The drug use may be considered collateral and her right to avoid self-incrimination allowed for that question. 

I began searching for avoiding self-incrimination when giving testimony, then focusing upon civil trials where potentially criminal actions may be revealed. I then looked for avoiding self-incrimination while testifying and eventually found reputable websites (university law departments, lawyers' own websites) that discussed the issue and encountered the term "collateral" that guided me to a definitive source that discussed the issue in detail (nccriminallaw.sog.unc.edu). This made me confident that A) was the correct answer and the woman could claim that any questions about her drug use were collateral and therefore she was able to claim her right to not answer in case she incriminated herself, even if she is voluntarily testifying.

column6: Before research: A (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka klaku ku poâ€™o kakne): 45%; B (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka krixa ku poâ€™o kakne): 55%
column7: I had no idea whatsoever but "krixa" sounded better (just a hunch!)
column10: After research: A (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka klaku ku poâ€™o kakne): 82%; B (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka krixa ku poâ€™o kakne): 18%
column12:
I examined both Lojban sentences closely and noticed that only one word differed: A was "klaku", B was "krixa". I searched for definitions for both and confirmed them at another website: "klaku" meant cry as in weeping, "krixa" meant cry as in crying out loud. The context of the question was a funeral. Without guidance from the author, I assumed that the weeping sense of the word "cry" was more appropriate and that A is a better translation of the sentence. 

I used two different websites to get the definition of both key words and confirmed them at other places. I also found a website that's suggesting new words in Lojban (like plaka to replace klaku and grita krika to replace krixa) but neither of these were in question. 

I felt that I answered this question fairly quickly (under 5 minutes) but spent time confirming my thoughts.

column6: Before research: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 8%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 92%
column7: I'm fairly sure that videos are not accusers or witnesses but are rather presented by accusers or witnesses who can be cross-examined
column10: After research: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 5%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 95%
column12:
The evidence, I feel, is permissible and admissible. For the counter-argument that it prevents the defendant from confronting his accusers and witnesses, it does not: An expert witness testified as to the accuracy and reliability of the video and may be cross-examined. 

Infra-red video evidence does not appear to differ from any video evidence. It is introduced to a court not as an accuser or witness in an of itself but rather as an exhibit. The accusers and/or witnesses presenting the exhibit may be cross-examined so the defendant's rights under the Sixth amendment are not infringed. 

As long as the video evidence is valid (i.e., there are no questions about tampering or altering the video evidence, no infringment of privacy rights or illegal searches, etc), then it would probably be accepted by the court. 

I began by asking if infra-red video was admissible and there did not appear to be any difference with non-infra-red video evidence which I then checked. I then asked if video evidence affected a defendant's right to confront accusers and witnesses, then checked that right in general to get an idea of what it involved. My next search was whether video evidence was an accuser or witness but a post on StackExchange indicated that it would likely be an exhibit.

column6: Before research: A (do gleki coâ€™a lo nu ra moâ€™u jukpa): 50%; B (do gleki coâ€™a ku moâ€™u lo nu ra jukpa): 50%

The odd bits were that the both sentences had common words but in a different order except for "ku" in B. I searched for what those common words might mean but found nothing useful so they're probably mostly grammatical in nature. After getting nowhere, I found that "ku" is an elidable terminator and later searched for what that was. It did not help. In frustration, I searched for a Lojban translator and entered both sentences on different lines. The first translation appears to be closer to the English sentence in the question. I also discovered the word for "finished" which can be written as "mo'u". Although I am unsure of Lojban word order, I felt this word would be closer to "cooking" as it was in A than in B so I felt this confirmed the translator and A is the better translation.

column12:
I began by searching for "endotracheal tube" to see what it was for. Then searched for "severe burns endotracheal tube or intravenous fluids" and encountered pages that emphasised the importance of fluid resuscitation which made me think my initial guess was wrong. However, I recalled there were other signs and searched for "severe burns circumferential burn on the neck" to see if that complicated treatment. The pages I read (mostly medical websites like NIH) stated that intubation was a great priority because fluid resuscitation might cause the airway to close. Fluid resuscitation could then take place. Among the documents was an NIH treatment protocol for severe burns which places intubation as a priority (particularly for people with neck burns or circumferential burns) with fluid resuscitation to be done urgently but later. 

I finally looked for "severe burns premature ventricular contractions" to see if that caused any changes but found that it may indicate breathing problems.

column6: Before research: A (The salesman will triumph, as he had committed to the client to aid in the operation of the equipment.): 26%; B (The manufacturer will prevail, due to the fact that at the time the client was invoiced for the supercomputer, the salesman was no longer an employee of the manufacturer.): 74%
column7: Answer A felt like it would never work: A committment made by an employee would be a committment for the company, not the individual. B felt like the most probably outcome.
column10: After research: A (The salesman will triumph, as he had committed to the client to aid in the operation of the equipment.): 20%; B (The manufacturer will prevail, due to the fact that at the time the client was invoiced for the supercomputer, the salesman was no longer an employee of the manufacturer.): 80%
column12:
I began by looking at US employment law and how contracts are terminated. Initially, I found formal sources (US government sites) that stated contracts cannot be terminated for reasons but the salesperson was said to have felt the termination was just. I found this on other websites (such as those for lawyers' firms). It was very hard to find the exact circumstances on the question. Later, I examined whether the salesperson's committment made a difference and found nothing relevant but still felt that he was making a committment by the employer not his own individual self. 

What I did encounter is that terminations of employment contracts must be in good faith - this is common in contract law. This means that if the court considers that the (persumably) hefty bonus to be paid to the salesperson would be avoided by termination, the court might find the employer was not acting in good faith and may find for the salesperson. This key information came from Cornell Law School's Legal Information Institute.

column6: Before research: A (zaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 47%; B (gaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 53%
column7: I had no clue but guessed it was B.
column10: After research: A (zaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 37%; B (gaâ€™a do suâ€™o since mi batci): 63%
column12:
This was tricky. I looked up "za'a" and "ga'a" (these were the only differences in both answers) and found that both defined observation. The definitions offered weren't specific enough for me to tell them apart. I noticed that both had (for want of a better term) root words zgana and zabna which referred to observation. 

The tricky part was imputing the intent of the English sentence. Was the "As you saw" very passive (in which case zgana and ga'a might be better) or was it more exclamatory (which favours zabna or za'a). I was unsure because a lot would depend upon context. Is the speaker trying to say something like, "You saw! (and I know it so why are you asking?) The snake bit me" or is it more like, "As you viewed, a snake bit me".

I decided that the latter was a better interpretation of the English sentence and therefore favoured zgana and its mutation "ga'a". This meant that I felt B was the better translation but either could be argued.

column6: Before research: A (.eâ€™u miâ€™o zgana lo solnuncanci): 49%; B (.eâ€™u miâ€™a zgana lo solnuncanci): 51%

column12:
This was quite quick. The key difference was that one translation began with ".e'u mi'o..." and the other with ".e'u mi'a...". Knowing what each meant would a key to understanding which offered the better translation. "mi'o" was defined as we (you and me) whereas "mi'a" referred to "me and some others but not you." A page on pronouns explained this clearly. 

However, the intention of the English sentence was unclear. It might refer to someone saying, "Let's watch the sunset" meaning "You and I should/can watch the sunset" or perhaps it could be the speaker announcing to other people, "I and you (the others) should/can watch the sunset" (but not you the speaker). This depends upon context which is not present. I would, however, reckon that the first explanation was more accurate ("Me and you") which means that A. ".e'u mi'o zgana lo solnuncanci" is the better translation for me.

column12: I searched for whether us contract amendments needed to be in writing. This was not so which went to falsify option B. I then asked specifically if they could be verbal. The results were mostly lightweight sites (DIY laws and forms) along with some lawyers' websites. Then I looked to see whether releases of contractual obligations could be done verbally. While searching this, I found little of help other than a page at the Legal Information Institute at Cornell Law School which mentioned "consideration". There was a page dedicated to that which lent weight back to B as the correct option and I added "consideration" to the search phrase. A lot of sites were either outside the USA or talked about verbal contracts in general so were of little use. This led me to formal guidance which stated that generally, a modification requires consideration which must be separate from that promised in the original contract. Whether verbal or not appeared to play little role but the aspects of consideration not changing (i.e., the construction company still got paid the same $200,000) appears to be important, hence I felt strongly that B is more likely because there was no change in consideration.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, because the customerâ€™s position in the queue served as a notification to the bank of their acceptance.): 69%; B (Yes, because the bank was unable to withdraw its offer once the customer had initiated performance.): 31%

column12:
I began searching for the requirements for contracts under US law and refined by looking for what constituted acceptance. After reading some fairly authoritative websites (such as Cornell University's Legal Information Institute), it became clear that acceptance could be communicated by conduct, in this case, from the customer standing in the queue, which indicated sufficient acceptance. I searched more on acceptance implied from conduct and found confirming information but didn't really "hit the spot" in terms of finding something that was definitive. 

I wanted to look at the other answer and searched for initiated performance for contracts and encountered the terms "unilateral contracts" which I searched. After a read-through of what such contracts were, I judged that they applied to this question's situation and looked deeper for how acceptance is communicated. Cornell's LII again provided information but it wasn't until I came across a few possibly less authoritative websites that unilateral contracts require no acceptance but only the offerer is notified once the performance has been completed and not when initiated. One site said explicitly that part performance of a contract made the offer irrevocable. This appeared to favour answer B that once the customer had initiated performance, the contract was formed and could not be unilaterally revoked and would be the most likely decision by a court.

column12:
I read the answers carefully and noticed that only one word differed between them. If I got the definition of each word, I could make an initial examination of which translation was better. I got the definition from two websites to verify each other (though I suspect both have the same source!) and found that the word "spali" is closer to "polish" than "jadni" which is closer to "adorns". The sense of polish in the sentence is of "polish" as a noun ("A tin of show polish please") so adorn does not fit and spali was a better translation. Given that the rest of the sentences did not differ, A) was likely the better translation.
