column6: Before research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 27%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 73%
column7: I was fairly sure the incapacity explanation was most likely because verbal/oral contracts are just as binding as written
column10: After research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 11%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 89%
column12:
I was aware that verbal/oral contracts are just as valid and enforceable as written ones (just possibly harder to prove) so A did not feel like a good answer or justification to void the contract. I was not sure about mental capacity and began to search for the incapacity to agree to a contract. My first site was Cornell's Legal Information Institute which informed me that if a party to a contract is deemed incompetent, the contract is voidable unless it involves a representative  who has legal guardianship. The adult daughter might fall into that category but she did not want the contract to be enforced. The question remains of whether the senior citizen had capacity to contract but she was taking potent painkillers and even the other party to the contract noticed that she was "out of sorts" which indicates she lacked capacity. One website (that of some lawyers) mentioned a specific case like this: If on so much pain medication that you couldn't think clearly, the contract should be voided. 

A later checked for oral changes to oral contracts (as the car purchase appeared to be) and did not find anything that said they could not be enforced. 

With that information, A (that the contract was not written) is unlikely to be sustained by a court because oral agreements are just as valid. The lack of capacity of the senior citizen (B) is, however, important and could well void the contract if the court finds that she did not have the capacity to form a contract.

column6: Before research: A (zmadu keâ€™o fa lo fanmo lo krasi lo ka miâ€™o zvajbi): 57%; B (zmadu keâ€™u fa lo fanmo lo krasi lo ka miâ€™o zvajbi): 43%
column7: No real idea which was which but the delta word ended in 'o' which seemed more like a group saying
column10: After research: A (zmadu keâ€™o fa lo fanmo lo krasi lo ka miâ€™o zvajbi): 29%; B (zmadu keâ€™u fa lo fanmo lo krasi lo ka miâ€™o zvajbi): 71%
column12:
I examined both sentences and noticed the only difference was "ke'o" for the first and "ke'u" for the second. Not knowing about word order in Lojban, I could not assume which part of the sentence they referred to. I searched for "ke'o" and it came up as "please repeat" on more than one website which was similar in meaning but not quite. "ke'u", however, came up as a conjugation of "krefu" which referred to repeating, another case, another time. This appeared to be more similar to the English sentence.

I tried to verify this with more sources but found little. An online translator failed to produce any difference and the translation was different enough from the source sentence to make me distrust it for this task. Lojban might be a language for which the entire sentence needs to be known for a correct translation so I was still unsure about my original research into "ke'o" and "ke'u" but I felt the weight of evidence (after some more searching for "krefu") was in favour of B (the sentence with "ke'u" in) to be the more correct translation of the source sentence.

column6: Before research: A (CT scan): 61%; B (Observation and follow up in 14 days): 39%
column7: After a course of antibiotics, it felt serious and needed proper diagnosis rather than just observation
column10: After research: A (CT scan): 87%; B (Observation and follow up in 14 days): 13%
column12:
I began by typing some of the symptoms into a search engine. The results were pages about ear infections. I typed in more and received a couple of pages with the actual question on (no answer though!) and kept on looking. The sites I searched were mostly public healthcare sites like NHS which tends to deal with the most common complaints. I wanted to make sure it wasn't just a minor ear infection, particularly so soon after a course of antibiotics (amoxicillin).

I abandoned the public healthcare sites and focused on sites aimed at medical professionals. The breakthrough was a paper contrasting otitis, sinusistis and mastoiditis. The first two were relatively minor and probably best left to sort themselves out and only a few symptoms were mentioned. Mastoiditis, however, mentioned more of the symptoms (even coming just after antibiotics) and noted that it was a serious infection that required intervention. Treatment was recommended as getting samples to confirm (even surgical debridement) but CT scans were mentioned as preferred for evaluating the bony structures. 

I searched for mastoiditis in other pages and the information was confirmed so answer A. A CT scan appeared to be the correct answer.

column6: Before research: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 41%; B (Double bubble sign): 59%
column7: Unsure but "double bubble" sounded distinct. No other reason.
column10: After research: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 64%; B (Double bubble sign): 36%
column12: I searched for oxygen saturation 86% to see that it was dangerously low. Then I looked for the definitions of "subcostal retractions and moderate perioral cyanosis" to understand what they were and encountered an article on NIH about respiratory distress in the newborn. This article gave too much information and did not offer any clue as to what finding a chest x-ray would give. One diagnosis appeared useful but used the term "perihilar" which I searched for but found only cancer pages. I then searched for the answers to see if there was any overlap. The double bubble appeared to have many causes and the Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema offered little more, even refining the search with some symptoms. After encountering the NIH article again, I read about "Respiratory Distress Syndrome" and there appeared to be similarity with the symptoms so I searched for that and got an article again from NIH. This discussed a perihilar interstitial edema and I wondered if this was the same thing as answer A. There was information on differential diagnosis and I noticed cyanotic congential heart disease which becomes apparent hours after birth. Although only a guess, the double bubble sign did not feature in any medical articles about respiratory conditions whereas edema were so I thought that A. was the best answer.

column6: Before research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 75%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 25%
column10: After research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 84%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 16%
column12:
I began by searching for any cases where an expert witness gave evidence but had lied in another case. Most results were about perjury rather than anything related and there was no issue of the witness having perjured themselves in the question. After that, I got the idea from one document to refine the search phrase to "exclude expert witness" to discover the grounds upon which it could be done but again little of use. I refined the search to see if other trials played a role in this. I changed the word "exclude" for "disqualify" (excluded was conflating with excluding jurors) and read some documents about impeachment of witnesses. Results were confused with criminal cases so I refined the search again and read a Wikipedia page as a start. 

This page led to a judgement about character evidence being generally inadmissible unless, in addition to character being a substantive issue in the case (which I believe it's not), it's being used to impeach a witness but this did not specify whether experts testifying about something else were included. The case linked to (Pino v Koelber, 1980).

I refined the case again to refer to behaviour in other cases, found little other than Cornell University's Legal Information Institute (LII) discussing rule 608 of the Federal Rules of Evidence which was more about witnesses' character and this suggested that the respondent's claim about the expert witness might be admissible. 

I read a question on the Google page about discrediting an expert witness and a lawyer's own page said there were three grounds to do so, none of which applied to the question. I refined the search again to one about challenging expert witnesses and the LII again came up with the Daubert Standard for expert witnesses. A Wikipedia article did not discuss anything to do with testimony in personal and unrelated cases so I felt that the answer A (the evidence should be omitted because the character of the expert witness is not a substantive part of the case, and there were many grounds for excluding expert witnesses established in Daubert v Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals (1993) which laid out the grounds upon which expert witnesses can be challenged in court.

column6: Before research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 57%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 43%
column7: "Cfagau" sounded Welsh so I went for that (no other reason).
column10: After research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 69%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 31%
column12:
The two Lojban sentences contained only one word difference: A. was "cfagau" and B was "cfari". I began by searching for two pages with a translation of both. "Cfagau" meant to begin something but from a person or agents perspective. "Cfari" meant that something had begun as part of a process. I looked for the other words in the sentence ("ma": a question, "lo": possible the, "fagri": fire)to get an idea of word order so the definitions fitted. Both appeared to be quite plausible as translations of "Who started the fire?". I felt confident that "cfagau" was correct because it fitted in with being a person's action rather than just a process ("Who started..."). 

My next step was to try an online translator which confused the issue. The "cfari" version was translated almost correctly but the "cfagau" was translating as being subtly different. I tried translating the first two words of each sentence to compare and confirmed. I then translated "Who started" into Lojban and got something different altogether, as did entering the entire English sentence though "cfari" appeared whereas "cfagau" did not. This was in opposition to my earlier conclusion. 

I checked more sources by refining the search back to "cfagau" and on one of the pages stated that it was a conjoined word of "cfari" and "gasnu" CFAri and GAsnU being CFAGAU. Gasnu meant "to do" which implied it was to be used when a person began something. The question was whether starting a fire was due to a person or to a process. For some contexts, both could be applied (like starting an engine - did you start the engine? Has the engine started?) but for a fire it felt closer to a person doing an action to begin something. Hence I feel that A. "ma cfagau lo fagri" is the better translation.

column6: Before research: A (Wait and watch): 60%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 40%
column10: After research: A (Wait and watch): 80%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 20%
column12:
I began by searching for symptoms ("mass on the side of his scrotum painless bag of worms") and received an article about varicocele which I read and the symptoms appeared to match very well. After scrolling down, I noticed an article by MayoClinic about scrotal masses. Concerned I was jumping on the first likely suggestion, I viewed this article which showed a list (nine in total) of possible conditions that might result in a scrotal mass. I searched for each of these in turn and examined the symptoms to reduce the number of possibilities. All of them mentioned that pain might be a symptom but for most, pain was a key symptom: For varicoceles, pain was mentioned but as a possibility not a probability. 

I searched for treatments of varicoceles. The articles that came back didn't supply much information outside of "examination" so I did the same search but added "NIH" to get formal papers. The article I read from that search went into so much detail that I was quickly overwhelmed. All I understood was that only 2-10% of patients reported pain. Eventually, I focused on a hospital page about varicoceles intended for public consumption rather than medical professionals. This site said that they are often harmless and do not need to be treated. Because of this my decision is A) wait and watch.

column6: Before research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 58%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 42%
column7: No real idea but the DPL felt better.
column10: After research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 62%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 38%
column12:
I began searching for the definitions of terms in the question (backhoe, GCS score, FAST scan, ischial rami. Once satisfied, I looked for ischial rami and added the other symptoms. Articles about pelvic factures came up but the key question was which of the answers the next appropriate step was needed. I also searched for the definitions of lavage and laparotomy to understand the articles. Most websites were for medical professionals rather than interested public. The information was heavy and sometimes overwhelming but useful in terms of diagnosis and treatment. 

I then compared the treatments of FAST scan and CT scan against each other and refined the search to FAST scan and DPL. This search was refined by adding "adbominal" to ensure focus. This led me to information that a CT scan was a good means of aiding diagnosis by locating internal injuries but that it should only be done on hemodynamically normal patients. This patient had signs of weak blood pressure and rapid pulse rate. The DPL on the other hand was invasive but a more sensitive test (more so than a FAST scan) but won't indicate which organs are damaged and can be performed on haemodynamically unstable patients (like this one).

Because of this, I felt that answer A (DPL) was the next appropriate step to be taken to check whether the patient had internal unjuries from the blunt trauma.

column6: Before research: A (Undue influence.): 55%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 45%
column7: I felt undue influence was a more likely grounds for voiding the contract though consideration is a key part of US contracts
column10: After research: A (Undue influence.): 77%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 23%
column12:
q32 I began searching for "undue influence" in terms of US contract law because the house sale was a contract. This produced two pages, one from Cornell University's Legal Information Institute (LII) and another more detailed page from a legal firm. These outlined pretty much what the question discussed, that indue influence is when one party exerts "excessive persuasion on another" (LII). If the brother can prove that his mother had vulnerabilities that made her liable to persuasion, and that his sister was in a special relationship of trust, then it is likely the court would rule the contract unenforceable and voidable due to undue influence. This made me feel very confident that my initial guess was correct. 

I then searched for "Insufficient consideration" and found that it referred to a situation where a contract has been made but the consideration (an essential part of contracts) has become worthless. This did not appear to apply to the house bought by the sister. I checked on a number of sites and was perplexed when the LII did not have anything about this phrase (the nearest was "failure of consideration") but I found the phrase defined on other websites (mostly legal firms and educational websites of uncertain provenance). What one article did point out is that there is a concept of "inadequate consideration" (like selling a valuable car for $1 which is clearly inadequate) which might apply if the court can be convinced that $100,000 is clearly far too little for a house valued at $250,000 but it could be argued that it's a fair price for a beloved close relative and it's not a trivial amount of money. This came from an educational website rather than that of one of or for legal professionals so I am not confident about this as a formal concept in US contract law. 

Given the strength of answer A (undue influence), I regard this as the most likely reason to invalidate the contract.

column6: Before research: A (Reassure the mother): 42%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 58%
column7: I felt it better to at least do an ultrasound to make sure
column10: After research: A (Reassure the mother): 23%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 77%
column12:
My search began with some context and symptoms. The only medical thing of note was the distinct pop (unsure if it was audible or just felt) for a 3-week old baby with everything else being normal. The first result that came up was about hip dysplasia. I read an NHS page (intended for public healthcare) about this and it recommended an ultrasound. I searched specifically for "hip dysplasia" to get more information but this, however, may not have been the correct diagnosis. I began by searching again for the symptom andnoted that some pages used the term "click" or "snap" instead of "pop". I searched instead for click and got a couple of useful pages (one from Brigham and Womens the latter from the International Hip Dysplasia Institute) which both said that hip dysplasia is indeed one diagnosis but most cases were not. An evaluation using tools such as ultrasound and examination would be necessary to confirm this and could well be inconsequential. 

None of this information, however, made is clear which was the next appropriate step. Ultrasound was recommended to be sure (or reassure parents) but it was also likely to be of little to no consequence. In general though, I'd always prefer getting a more reliable diagnosis so have gone for B. arrange an ultrasound of the hip to be certain.

column6: Before research: A (Prevail, since his decision to retire and purchase the recreational vehicle was made in reasonable reliance on the corporationâ€™s guarantee of a lifetime pension.): 34%; B (Not succeed, since the corporationâ€™s assurance of a lifetime pension was an unenforceable promise of a gift.): 66%
column7: I assumed no contract existed because there was no consideration and the promise was unenforceable.
column10: After research: A (Prevail, since his decision to retire and purchase the recreational vehicle was made in reasonable reliance on the corporationâ€™s guarantee of a lifetime pension.): 76%; B (Not succeed, since the corporationâ€™s assurance of a lifetime pension was an unenforceable promise of a gift.): 24%
column12:
I began by searching for formal signed decrees in US contract law but only found that decrees were decisions handed down by judges so not relevant. Instead, I began by comparing the status of contract versus gift (as per answer B) and found a formal document called "gift promises and the edge of contract law". One key phrase used was "reliance, moral obligation and irrevocable trusts" arose in a paragraph that explained that contracts could not include gifts but sometimes promises could be treated like contracts and thus enforceable. 

I searched for this phrase and encountered another heavy document titled, "Irrevocable gift promises and promises inducing reliance" which appeared to be relevant. It also explained that some promises could be legally enforceable using the contractual doctrine of "reliance or promissory estoppel". This felt like I was on the right lines. 

I searched for this phrase and came across a page on Cornell University's Legal Information Institute about promissory estoppel and gained a definition of what it was, and it was an implied agreement. I followed the link to agreement and found they could be as binding as contracts (often depending upon which state) but the terms needed to be as certain as those of a contract. Given that the company's board had made a formal, signed decree, this can be taken as an agreement. I needed more information about agreements and refined the search by adding the word "agreement". 

From this, I got two pages by law firms (both in New York) that explained promissory estoppel in detail and how there were four elements to it. The promise had to exist (the decree fit this), the promise was expected that the recipient would rely on it (he did), that the other party did rely upon it (both qualified by his purchase of a vehicle) and that the injustice cannot be avoided without encorcing the promise (the executive is unemployable now). 

I checked the second page for confirmation and got that but also more information about detrimental reliance. While promissory estoppel is not recognised by all states (for example, Virginia does not but Maryland and D.C. do), the detrimental reliance can be enforceable in those jurisdictions. The elements are much the same as promissory estoppel.

I think that B is not the correct answer because while the pension is a gift and, because of a lack of consideration from the former executive, cannot be a contract, the fact that he relied upon it and needs to continue to do so to prevent the injustice of paying for his vehicle leads me to say A. is the likely result in court.

column6: Before research: A (The plumbing supply corporation is obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, and the property manager is required to pay the agreed price for the 25 sets within a timeframe that can be considered reasonable following their delivery.): 61%; B (The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporationâ€™s headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.): 39%
column7: I believed that paying in a reasonable timeframe was fine.
column10: After research: A (The plumbing supply corporation is obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, and the property manager is required to pay the agreed price for the 25 sets within a timeframe that can be considered reasonable following their delivery.): 25%; B (The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporationâ€™s headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.): 75%
column12:
I did many initial searches focused on US law but kept receiving information about UK law, even when trying to exclude it. The breakthrough came when I encountered a page on Cornell University's Legal Information Institute which used the phrase "open time" in relation to payments. It also contained a list of four principles, the first of which was that unless otherwise stated, "payment is due at the time and place at which the buyer is to receive the goodseven though the place of shipment is the place of delivery". This strongly favours answer B rather than A. After searching some more, I discovered that for the sale of goods, there is legislation in most US jurisdictions called the "Uniform Commercial Code 2". It's been adopted by 49 states (except Louisiana although that has adopted most of it) and a few non-state jurisdictions like the D.C., Guam, and the Navajo Nation which adopted a number of articles (the provision outlined above is in article 3). 

Because the contract of sale does not specify any delivery location or payment date, it's fair to assume that the Uniform Commcercial Code 2's point a) above applies and the most correct interpretation is B, that the goods must be paid for on delivery. 

There might be a difference because only part of the goods have been supplied but this was beyond my searching. My gut feel is, however, that what is delivered must be paid for then and there unless the contract specifies otherwise.

column6: Before research: A (Angiography of the lower extremities): 61%; B (Initiate oral antibiotics): 39%
column7: I'd want to understand what's happening in the extremities before further treatment
column10: After research: A (Angiography of the lower extremities): 77%; B (Initiate oral antibiotics): 23%
column12:
This was difficult to search for because of the number of symptoms. I mis-typed the location of the ulcer (I put leg when it should have been toe) for the first searches but changed later. Initial results discussed leg ulcers and the symptoms reported were different including discolouration or darkening of the skin which was not observed in the patient. I entered more symptoms until peripheral arterial disease (PAD) was mentioned and I read a lot of public-facing websites. They offered some information but little useful detail for diagnosis, treatment or first steps. After more searches, the NIH had a very detailed article (aimed at healthcare professionals) where a lot of signs and symptoms matched including risk factors (smoking, diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, increased age)pain occurring when walking, the extremities being painful when lying down (ischemic rest pain) and the loss of pulses. Symptoms of pain in the calf muscles suggest aortoiliac artery occlusive disease leading to femoropopliteal PAD.

In terms of next steps, antibiotics are only recommended if the ulcer is infected (i.e., with pus). If not, it may be washed with an antibiotic solution (answer B specifies oral antibiotics) but angiography is a commonly mentioned tool for diagnosis. My answer is A, that this patient should get an angiogram on the lower extremities.

column6: Before research: A (la .xadj. cu fasnu pa roi ro nanca buâ€™u la .makax.): 57%; B (la .xadj. cu fasnu pa roi ro nanca neâ€™i la .makax.): 43%
column7: bu'u felt like a better translation of place (rather "ne'i" sounded too English!)
column10: After research: A (la .xadj. cu fasnu pa roi ro nanca buâ€™u la .makax.): 53%; B (la .xadj. cu fasnu pa roi ro nanca neâ€™i la .makax.): 47%
column12:
Q37. I compared both sentences and saw that one word differed: "bu'u" for A and "ne'i" for B. I searched for a definition of each and found that they both referred to location: bu'u being described as "coincident with or at the same location as..." which felt like it fit the sentence (which referred to the Hadj and Meccah). ne'i instead appeared to be a reference to being within or inside. This also fit well as I was unsure which might be correct. I checked a few more pages, one was very long and featured examples of both words but I was none the clearer for reading it: Both words appeared to be good translations. I tried a English-Lojban translator, first beginning with the English sentence which offered nothing useful. I then interpreted A and B to English and got the same answer. Either, it appears, would work. 

I then noticed that both words were conjugates of other words: bukpu for bu'u and nenri for ne'i and examined their definitions. Nenri continued to mean within/inside but bukpu changed to mean a measure of cloth! This didn't fit. 

For the final answer, I checked through some more search listings but found nothing that would answer the question. My guess is that despite bukpu meaning something different, bu'u referring to something being in the same place appeared to be a better translation. I have, however, a very low confidence in either being better than the other and think both would be fine enough translations.

column6: Before research: A (Excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay and does not qualify for any exceptions.): 78%; B (Not admissible, due to the fact it could potentially steer the courtâ€™s attention towards nonessential, irrelevant topics.): 22%
column7: I thought the hearsay was most likely because the co-passenger statement was of direct relevance to the charge.
column10: After research: A (Excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay and does not qualify for any exceptions.): 64%; B (Not admissible, due to the fact it could potentially steer the courtâ€™s attention towards nonessential, irrelevant topics.): 36%
column12:
This is a difficult one because I think the testimony could be admissible (assuming the question refers to the testimony of the co-passenger if they presented during the court trial rather than that of the law enforcement officer or LEO). 

If the LEO's testimony is under question, I began by reading about hearsay. Cornell University's Legal Information Institute has a nice introductory page about hearsay and it is generally inadmissible because the credibility of the witness cannot be established in the court (if they did give testimony in court, it is not hearsay). There are exceptions to hearsay but none of them appear to apply outside of a possible "excited utterance". If the court deems the co-passenger's statement as such, then it is an exception to hearsay and would be admissible. Other exceptions include statements against self (not relevant because the co-passenger is not the defendant), and matter of record (the statement is not an official record of the type referred to). Even if there is no exception, judges may rule hearsay evidence as admissible. 

I then investigated relevance and read a paper from Indiana University's Maurer School of Law that said relevance comes with two tests (rule 401). The first is that it must prove or disprove a fact and the statement appears to be probative towards the defendants being intoxicated. The second is that the fact must be a consequence in determining the action and the defendant's intoxication while driving appears to be relevant here. From this, I concluded that B (not admissible because it's nonessential and irrelevant) does not apply because it appears to directly confirm the actual charge made by the prosecution. 

I'm still baffled as to why either of these answers is likely because I don't think they are. In my opinion, if the co-passenger is willing to testify, then the issue of hearsay falls away and even if not, their statement may be taken as an "excited utterance" and admissible. However, I think the most likely grounds of exclusion is A, that of hearsay because I don't see B as relevant.

column6: Before research: A (la .mark. cu zmanei loâ€™e tcati la .djein.): 58%; B (la .mark. cu nelmau la .djein. loâ€™e tcati): 42%
column7: A just felt better to me. No real justification.
column10: After research: A (la .mark. cu zmanei loâ€™e tcati la .djein.): 34%; B (la .mark. cu nelmau la .djein. loâ€™e tcati): 66%
column12:
This was interesting. I examined the sentences and noticed two main differences: A used zmanei whereas B used nalmau; and after that, the word order changed. I could see that "la .mark" referred to "Mark" in the English sentence just as "la .djein" referred to Jane so they appeared straightforward. I searched for word order in Lojban to see if that gave me a clue as to the better translation. The document I found (Wikipedia) said that word order is free so there was no clue as to whether A or B was the best translation. I

My next step was to translate zmanei and nelmau. Zmanei was easy to discover and had multiple agreeing translations (preference of a person for one item over another) which is in the ball park of the translation and probably understandable. It was, however, not perfect. Problems began when I tried to translate nelmau and got nothing other than some words in email signatures on a mailing list of Lojban enthusiasts. This did not help and only found one source. Even my regular sources of Lojban words dried up. I was tempted to abandon here because perhaps nelmau was not a word and A ("zmanei") would win by default. The only clue I had was a Lojban -> Occitan translator that used Nelmau but I don't understand Occitan. I copied the Occitan translation and translated it, in turn, into English and nelmau did indeed appear to relate to preference. One step closer but nowhere near enough. 

The translator I prefer (vlasisku.lojban.org) had nothing for nelmau but it was being used by some people. Aftr trying it again, I noticed that despite vlasisku saying it found nothing, it linked to two other words: "nelci" and "zmadu". Connecting those two could result in "nelmau" (NELci zMAdU) and searched for translations of those words. They key decider was that "nelci" referred to preference but in a slightly different way to Zmanei. Zmanei felt like one person saying they preferred this item over this item - it's close but not quite. With Nelmau, it was more of a fondness/has a taste for and zmadu referred to is more in a type of property. This felt (though I was not confident) that it was the correct answer by stating that Mark had a taste for tea that exceeded the taste for tea that Jane had. Because of this, I chose B as my final answer.

column6: Before research: A (lo se tavla be miâ€™o cu vajni sai ro miâ€™o): 55%; B (lo se casnu be miâ€™o cu vajni sai ro miâ€™o): 45%
column7: Tavla sounded more like "talk". Didn't think that casnu sounds like converse...
column10: After research: A (lo se tavla be miâ€™o cu vajni sai ro miâ€™o): 22%; B (lo se casnu be miâ€™o cu vajni sai ro miâ€™o): 78%
column12:
I checked both sentences and found that the only difference was one word: A had tavla and B had casnu. I searched for an interpretation of both to see what they meant and both related to speech so there was no superficially obvious correct translation. I examined the translations of each word individually and found that tavla was translated mostly as "talk" but in a fairly context-free sense. I talk, I talked, I was talking. It could imply a conversation but also imply a monologue. The English sentence uses "talk" in the sense of a discussion so while tavla felt like a good enough word, it wasn't the complete picture. 

Searching for translations of Casnu, on the other hand, showed it to be translated as discussion. This felt closer to the meaning of the original English sentence where the object was a conversation between the speaker and another party. Casnu felt much closer to the original sentence's meaning. After looking at some examples of both words, I again felt that casnu was a better translation and might even put a partial English -> English translation of the original sentence from "What we talked about is very important to both of us." to "What you and I discussed had elements of importance to all parties to the discussion." With this, the answer sentence with casnu (B) feels like it's a better translation that the sentence with tavla though both could be used.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 65%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 35%
column7: I was not sure whether "oppressively unfair" was a proper legal term
column10: After research: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 32%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 68%
column12:
This was a difficult question because both were plausible reasons for the buyer to win their case. I initially searched for "oppressively unfair" because this was my least favoured option. From a page at Cornell University's Legal Information Institute about unconscionability, I discovered another about "misrepresentation". Part of misrepresentation is when there is an intentional or reckless misrepresentation of fact or opinion with an intention to make a party do or not do something (in this case agree to the sale). When I searched again for the features of the case, I found lots of lawyers' websites with pages but these, although they outlined the general idea that used car dealers should disclose any information about accidents when asked, they go no further. After searching through the Federal Trade Commission website, I discovered something called the "used car rule" that states that it is a deceptive act or practice to misrepresent the mechanical condition of a used vehicle. 

Clearly, the buyer would have a good possibility of winning their case; but why? The dealer has deliberately made misleading statements and hidden evidence of the accident and that is a deceptive practice indeed, but the key point of law is that in doing so, the dealer has made the contract unconscionable and therefore oppressively unfair. My answer is therefore B.

column6: Before research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 39%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 61%
column7: I initially thought a child would have to be examined to ensure they were aware of what was happening.
column10: After research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 81%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 19%
column12:
My first search was a general investigation into whether children could be witnesses at a criminal trial. There were a few question-and-answer type sites such as Quora that offered opinions that they could and the search engine itself suggested answers. I preferred to rely upon a more authoritative source aimed at legal professionals. My first result was a library of criminal justice resources which stated that children do attend criminal courts to give evidence as witnesses and victims (the child was both but I'm presuming we're talking about the child being a witness for a homicide trial only). This article only contained an abstract and insufficient information to determine the most likely reason for the court's decision, only that they could be allowed. 

My next result was Cornell's Legal Information Institute that said children are presumed to be competent and that Rule 601 of the Federal Rules of Evidence contained information about witness competence. Examinations for competence could be undertaken but only if a party offers a written motion supported by an offer of proof of incompetence. Without this, the child witness is presumed to be competent and no examination can be done. The question does not state that such evidence exists and I assumed that it does not. This disqualifies answer B, that witness competence must be proven - it is presumed by the court. 

I searched more pages to clarify this including rule 602 of the Federal Rules of Evidence (the need for personal knowledge) which applies to all witnesses, child or adult. The presence of the child during the death of the father allows this to be presumed also. Therefore, my answer is A, that the child will be allowed because their age is no bar to offering testimony; that they have personal knowledge of the incident and qualify as a non-expert witness; and that there is no evidence offered of the witness' lack of competence to be a witness so the court presumes that the child can offer testimony.

column6: Before research: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 41%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 59%

column12:
This tricky question presented with different translations but the only different word was "cu" in the sense of singing / howling / screaming, but this word works as a separator and I didn't understand how it worked without knowing a lot more about Lojban grammar. I searched for a Lojban translator and tried the English sentence first. The output was totally different to the answers and of no use. I then translated each answer's sentence and got nothing that applied to the original sentence. I then examined parts of each answer's sentence to better understand them and still go nowhere. Eventually, I tried translating "co'a" which was described as something beginning but I also got some example sentences. This did apply to the sentence. After trying a few more pages, I then translated "cu" which is apparently a separator of some kind. 

I went back to the example sentences containing "cu cmoni" and "co'a cmoni" and found some interesting ones related to wolves. The former referred to wolves howling without anything else. The latter, however, referred to wolves beginning to howl. This applied well to the answers' sentences so I think that B is the better translation because it takes into account the part of the sentence that states the birds are starting to sing rather than just singing without further qualification.

column6: Before research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 22%; B (successful.): 78%
column7: I felt oral contracts were just as valid as written ones
column10: After research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 21%; B (successful.): 79%
column12:
My gut feel was that verbal contracts (US: oral contracts) are just as valid and enforceable as written ones. They may present more difficulty because they are more often harder to prove than written ones. However, I began my search by looking for more information about oral contracts. The first page i looked at (Cornell's Legal Information Institute) confirmed that they were indeed just as valid except that they may fail under something called the "Statute of Frauds" in each state. In the cases under this statute, contracts had to be in writing. Mention was made of contracts to secure long lease periods or for another's performance to be complete in the distant future (but the lengths of time were unspecified). I examined the linked-to page but there was no more specificity. I searched for the "us statute of frauds" and opened two pages: One from a lawyer's company and Wikipedia. The former specified that the lease period had to be less than one year for an oral contract to be valid (the agreement included a lease for 4 months), and that the agreement had to be completed within a year (the student graduated within the year). This meant the oral contract could be maintained. 
 
 Within the statute, however, is the requirement that contracts that agree to pay the debt of another need to be written. This presents difficulty because although the overall agreement does just this (the father pays the student's debt), the claim the student makes is actually for living costs. The court may decide that this debt payment means the entire agreement has to be written but they may also decide that it's separate enough not to require a written contract. 
 
 There was another point about being in the lifetime of the promisor but I anticipated this meant that the completion should be expected within the promisor's lifetime; his sudden death should not be a relevant point. 
 
 Because of these, I felt that the oral contract was valid and that a written contract was not required by law so the student would have a successful claim (answer B), as long as the student can prove the existence of the contract terms.

column12:
The two Lojban sentences in the answers were similar but differed in two ways: A used "co'a" before the word for "red" and B used "cu" instead; and B had "carna" at the end of the sentence. I began searching for translations of the longer words beginning with "carna". This definition was "turn/rotate/towards direction" which sounded approximate but felt more like a spin when the English sentence could be more precise by using "transformed" instead of "turn". I began thinking that A was still more correct. I searched for translations of "xunre", "tamca" and then "co'a" followed by "cu". Xunre meant red, tamca was tomato and co'a meant beginning or starting something. This felt like it could lead to a better translation especially when "cu" was a separator word to denote (IIRC) a predicate. 

I then tried a translator beginning with the English sentence which led nowhere useful; so I tried the two sentences which were similar but did not specify the tomato being red as a transformation (turning red) but just one day (one said "One day the flesh becomes red.", the other "The tomato turns red one day."). Neither were that good although the second (B) is the better.

I searched for more translations of "carna" and found that turn on its own is fine so I decided that B was the better translation.

column6: Before research: A (disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception.): 74%; B (dismissed, because its potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value.): 26%
column7: The driver's statement does not appear to be prejudicial but rather is hearsay
column10: After research: A (disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception.): 83%; B (dismissed, because its potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value.): 17%
column12:
My gut feel is that A is more likely because the statement of the law enforcement officer (LEO) relied heavily upon that of an anonymous bystander whose testimony cannot be examined. I began by looking at hearsay rules at Cornell's Legal Information Institute and another document which also outlined exceptions. The excited utterance exception will not apply (the LEO appeared 10 minutes after the incident), the statement was not against interest, and the statement of the bystander was not a matter of record. Answer A appeared to be valid for ruling the driver's statement as inadmissible. I then searched for prejudice to check that side and found a few pages that discussed in detail how judges have to balance prejudicial evidence against that of probative value. I cannot apply the rules here because they are more like general guidelines but I cannot see how the driver's statement could be considered not highly relevant: Indeed, it is at the core of the LEO's identification of the alleged offender.

If the driver's statement is ruled as relevant then it is not so prejudicial as to be dismissed. It does, however, appear to qualify as hearsay so I have chosen A as the answer. 

Finally, because of the adversarial nature of the relationship between police and defendant's, rule 803 covering hearsay exceptions do not regard LEO statements as being a matter of record when they are at the scene of the crime or apprehending the suspect.

column6: Before research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 37%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 63%
column7: It seemed that the patient's bowels were obstructed and may have had too much air which needed to be removed.
column10: After research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 30%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 70%
column12:
I began searching for terms I did not understand ("afebrile", "tympanitic", "dlated bowel loops"). On the latter, I encountered some pages from the NIH (StatPearls) summarised at the top of the search page that discussed "smal bowel obstruction". I then put what I thought were the key symptoms ("define dilated bowel loops afebrile  vomits bile distended, tympanitic, diffusely   dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levelstender abdomen") into the search engine and examined the results. The first was "Intestinal Pseudo-Obstruction" (again at NIH) which mentioned the symptoms and signs in the summary. This made me feel I was on the right lines. I went back to search and looked for articles about other conditions and opened a page on "Small Bowel Obstruction" (NIH again) but while some symptoms were common, others were missing - way more than with the first page. I decided to continue with both diagnoses. 

The Intestinal Pseudo-Obstruction page mentioned treatments including the naso-gastric tube for decompression (to drain away excess air from the digestive system) along with erythromycin but in no order of preference (the tube was mentioned first though). I searched for treatments of both conditions and for small bowel obstruction, neither a gastric tube or erythromycin were mentioned so I had the luxury of discounting it as the correct diagnosis. For Intestinal Pseudo-Obstruction (or Ogilvie Syndrome), the nasograstric tube was mentioned in treatment but erythromycin was only for the longer-term chronic conditions. Because of this, I believe answer B (treatment with a nasogastric tube to aid decompression) was the next step in managing this patient's condition.

column6: Before research: A (Permissible as a declaration made by a representative of an opposing party.): 70%; B (Not permissible, as it constitutes hearsay without any qualifying exception.): 30%
column7: I was fairly sure that testimony as a court record does not qualify as hearsay.
column10: After research: A (Permissible as a declaration made by a representative of an opposing party.): 81%; B (Not permissible, as it constitutes hearsay without any qualifying exception.): 19%
column12:
I first began by searching for "hearsay" and noticed on Cornell's Legal Information Institute that while it is generally disallowed, there are exceptions one of which is "matters of record". This includes prior court decisions or documents, and prior testimony of an unavailable witness to be admitted as evidence. Because of this exception, the security guard's testimony from his manslaughter trial will probably be considered a matter of record (assuming that the transcript is suitably verified as genuine to the court) and therefore an exception to the exclusion of hearsay evidence. I followed a link to a page about matters of record which included findings of fact, evidence, motions, rulings, verdicts and testimony. Hearsay is normally inadmissible because the witness cannot be examined sufficiently; but in a prior trial, they already have been examined on the matter. I further searched for verification and read about rules 803 and 804 governing exceptions to hearsay (803) and dealing with hearsay when the declarant is unavailable, and both supported the earlier information. 

Because of this, answer B is not possible: The security guard's testimony in his manslaughter trial is a matter of record and is therefore not hearsay and is admissible. This means that A is most likely the correct answer.

Digital images need to be original and verified as such, which in this case they are. 

Is infra red imaging clear enough to allow identification of persons? It is clear from a couple of answers that it can give food identication.

column7: The success or failure of the claim will depend on the law regarding verbal promise as I see no formalised agreement between father and student here
column10: After my research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 75%; B (successful.): 25%
column12:
As previous, AI is mistaken with the first statement it makes, which drastically weakens the student's case. 
The position on verbal promises varies widely from state to state, with some states refusing to even look at a verbal promise.

The so called Statute of Fraud covers 6 areas for which a written contract would be required: 
Contracts for selling real estate , 
Contracts for selling securities 
Contracts where marriage is the consideration in a contract , such as a Prenuptial or Postnuptial Agreement
Contracts that cannot be performed within one year from the date of the agreement 
Contracts in which one party agrees to pay someone else’s debt

This verbal agreement covers at least two of the points here ( Paying debt and Matrimony) so without a verbal agreement between the Father and the Student his claim is pretty much doomed to failure - but then again, assuming he gets work as a lawyer, he is going to make the $800 back pretty damned quickly! 

I thus strengthen my belief that the claim will fail to 75-25

column10: After my research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 15%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 85%
column12:
Research of DPL to confirm exactly what it is: All resources suggest that CT has superceded DPL owing to its non invasive nature and its broader fields of diagnostic value. 

Research also reveals a list of contraindications for DPL, and there are three contraindications on this list applicable in this case:
 
Availability of appropriate imaging (eg, E-FAST, CT) ( From the wording of the question this is assumed) 

Pelvic fracture

Serious obesity 

It is thus abundantly clear that CT is a much preferred option in modern medicine for this case: However there are still localities where this modern technique may not be available so the more traditional technique of DPL may have to be employed - AI assumes that CT is available, and so the answer is tempered a little to 85/15 in favour of CT scan.

column12:
On research there appears to be very limited application of any age limit for witnesses - with reference to the 6th Amendment of the US Constitution. Some states appear to have legal limits, but no list appears to be readily available. 

In all cases where there is discussion it is apparent that, especially with the youngest children as in this case, the judge and or the judge's opinion carries a great deal of weight, and there are descriptions of not only the judges receiving special training to assess the competency of juvenile witnesses, but in some cases receiving the evidence themselves in chambers in the presence of attorneys rather than in open court. 

With this the best answer - not necessarily correct- appears to be B

column12:
It was not easy to find a clear cut answer to the admissibility of evidence relating to an expert witness's character in a civil court: However it is clear that this would be administered at State Law level, and whilst the tendency was to follow Federal Law there were many differences and exceptions. 

Although this set of circumstances is fairly well down the list of those covered by examples, it does appear to be covered by a 2006 Amendment to Rule 404 which is to the effect that 'The Rule has been amended to clarify that in a civil case evidence of a person's character is never admissible to prove that the person acted in conformity with the character trait.' 

Thus I return to my position that I belive AI is mistaken here and the correct answer is in fact A, but with very limited confidence - 55/45

column7: knowing this condition does exist, early action would be wisest: Ultrasound examination 60/40
column10: After my research: A (Reassure the mother): 60%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 40%
column12:
OK - Both myself and AI totally disregarded the age of the baby - 3 weeks. At this age the ligaments are still not set, and joints are almost certainly fairly loose. 
This I have discovered is known as hip laxity: Babies showing hip laxity may not exhibit symptoms of Hip Dysplasia at later examinations. 
Additionally as the third child, the risk of hip dysplasia is reduced. 
A clear diagnosis of hip dysplasia (DDH) is probably not going to be possible for at least another three weeks or so, so my opinion changes from an immediate need to review hip development by ultrasound to a position that the parent should be reassured, and a new appointment booked for three or four weeks time for a new assessment. However, an experienced clinician may be able to observe signs of development that could give cause for concern and may feel that examination by ultrasound at this stage may be a benefit and this is allowed for in my 60/40 position in favour of parental reassurance.

column7: The Statute of frauds suggests this should be done with a written contract, and this is a black/white situation whereas establishing the woman's fitness to contract is a very much more problematical route.
column10: After my research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 55%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 45%
column12:
Of course the Statute of Frauds applies firmly to deals over $500.... now this is the agreed sum, but the value of the car is well above that.  
On the other hand the issue of the capacity of the woman to enter into the agreement is questionable. and one resource states... "People who are intoxicated by drugs or alcohol are usually not considered to lack the capacity to contract. Courts generally rule that those who are voluntarily intoxicated shouldn't be allowed to avoid their contractual obligations, but should instead have to take responsibility for the results of their self-induced altered state of mind." 
There then follow assorted riders that in certain cases the courts will take the other line. 
Was the woman's incapacity self inflicted? It is an argument.... 

Taken in conjunction the two answers together clearly diminish the buyer's case, but to select one as a stand alone on which it is more likely to fail on balance the lack of a written agreement for a major asset appears to me to be stronger ground on which to argue.... but only just! so 55/45 A

column10: After my research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 25%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 75%
column12:
it appears that in this sort of case quite a passive course of therapy is normal - presumably awaiting putrefaction or other breakdown of the offending blockage. In doing that the gaseous and liquid contents of the stomach are kept clear to help reduce the bloating of the bowel 

Although in one source I found erythromycin being used to stimulate persistalsis in the bowel, it does not appear to be a general or even common therapy. 
My initial thought  was that for a bowel blockage 'attacking' by the rectal route would be preferable, but it is clear that a steady course of therapy with minimal oral food and liquid and keeping the stomach contents clear is the way that this condition is treated. 

Happy to move to quite a strong 25/75 for B

 - Witness Unavailable 
 - Parties materially the same 
 - Witness could have been cross examined at the previous trial 
 - records are verifiable and notarized. 

My confidence that A is the correct answer is thus strengthened to 70/30 - It is clear that policy on this varies from State to State, and in some states the evidence may be inadmissible: The attorney for the estate would be aware of this. 

All applications for admission of the evidence also have to be permitted by the Judge in the case which is a further element of uncertainty.

column7: Quite a contentious question! 50/50 initial opinion
column10: After my research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 45%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 55%
column12:
And a complex area of the law this proves to be with differences between criminal and civil procedure, and also between State and Federal law! 

Looking at answer A, OK, the 5th Amendment is pleaded, but it appears that in most states pleading the 5th in a civil case can be taken to construe opinion on the question in hand, which it cannot in a criminal case ....but in MOST states...... !!!!! 

Answer B opens a very grey area on when the witness can plead the 5th - it is not a black and white matter and one that a judge's decision would be needed on: However, with increased possibilities for the inference of the silence to be assumed as in Question A above, the correctness of Answer B diminishes somewhat, and I would guess in the normal course of law in this scenario would allow the plea of the 5th but advise the witness that in a civil case the probable answer to the question can be construed as part of the case in a civil case..... in MOST states! 

So on balance B has it... Just! 55/45

column7: It appears reasonable that the affadavit supports the statement to the nurse
column10: After my research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 40%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 60%
column12:
OK - An about turn! Research shows that a Dying Statement must include a statement about the circumstances of the cause of death - In the case of the nurse this is correct, but the information given on the doctor's affadavit states only that the victim knew he was going to die, and nothing is apparently stated about the circumstances 

As the question relates to the Doctor's affadavit only, the Judge should not accept this into the case as it excludes one of the key elements to be an exception to the Hearsay rule 

"To be admissible under Rule 804(b)(2), the declarant’s statements also must concern the “cause or circumstances” of what the declarant believed to be his or her impending death. " is a typical quote from several resources that is completely overlooked in the case of the doctor's affadavit - but is clearly acceptable in relation to the statement made to the nurse 

AI has failed to differentiate between the two here, and the answer it indicates is incorrrect.

It is clear from my research that AI's response is correct, upon looking for the Rule 404 it became evident that my initial though process was incorrect. Rule 404 clearly states that "Evidence of a person’s character or character trait is not admissible to prove that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character or trait".
And it also states- "This evidence may be admissible for another purpose, such as proving motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake, or lack of accident".

It is clear that the evidence can be admitted to establish lack of mistake. Option B is correct.

To qualify as a statement made by a co-conspirator, the statement must be made during the course of the conspiracy and in aide of the conspiracy. The conspiracy does not need to be 100% proven as the AI sugggested. It can be a suspected conspiracy and the statement would still be valid. However, the dying man's confession to his wife was not made during the course of the conspiracy, nor to help the goal of the conspiracy. A declaration against interest therefore makes the most sense in the context of the case.

column12: I disagree with the AI and here's why. Yes, oral contracts can be valid but they need to prove a course of conduct wa performed. For example, if the elderly neighbour accepted the $450 and didn't give the buyer the car, that would be a clear breach of verbal contract. At best, if the neighbour refuses to sell and doesn't take the money, without a written contract, it would be extremely difficult to prove in court that the woman made the verbal agreement in the first place. As she hasn't accepted any money, she's not in breach of contract. Furthermore, though the contract could be voidable due to the woman's condition, it's more difficult to enforce this if there's no evidencce of the contract in the first place. The buyer could also lie that they didn't notice the neighbours incapacity which means it's not the best argument to approach this case from. Signing or agreeing a contract while high on medication also doesn't make the contract voidable in all cases.

column12: My research confirmed my initial hunch and the AI's assessment, however the AI was not 100% correct with its reasoning. Firstly, the Supreme Court has ruled that a defendant's silence in response to an accusation cannot be used as evidence of guilt IF the defendant has been taken iinto custody or read their Miranda rights. As soon as soeone is taken into custody and/or read their Miranda rights, the 5th amendment right to remain silent is in effect. If the statement was said before Miranda rights were read, it may be admissable. But I would also challenge this. I looked at the hearsay evidence and suspect A's statement doesn't appear to qualify. You could argue that it is a declaration against interest, but for that, defendant A would have to be absent for the trial. Declaration against interest is only plausible if the speaker cannot be present in court. Therefore it's probably that the answer is B.

column10: After my research: A (The plumbing supply corporation is obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, and the property manager is required to pay the agreed price for the 25 sets within a timeframe that can be considered reasonable following their delivery.): 25%; B (The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporationâ€™s headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.): 75%
column12: Initially, I thought the same as the AI; because the contract specifies the date of delivery, this would supercede the payment terms and reasonable industry payment terms would apply. However, as I did more research, I saw that the UCC contradicts this. To begin, the delivery location, if not disclosed in the contract, is the seller'splace of business or if he has none his residence, according to UCC section 2-308. But crucially, payment is due at the time and place at which the buyer is to receive the goods even though the place of shipment is the place of delivery. Therefore, the buyer (the property manager) must pay for the goods on delivery unless a credit note or shipment under reservation is agreed. Therefore, the answer is B.

column12: My research focused on the validity of child testimony and what conditions the prosecution needs to fulfil to have a juvenile witness. I found out that in most states in the US,  all children are presumed competent to testify, unless shown otherwise. Thst means the prosecution does not need to give evidence that the child is a competent witness; they are already assumed to be competent by law. The judge will likely question the child to ensure they can ask questions and are not too emotional traumatised by the event, but this is not on the prosecutor to provide evidence. Child victims as young as 4 years old have the right to testify about their experiences.

column10: After my research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 70%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 30%
column12: My approach to this research was two-pronged: First, what does the  Federal Rules of Evidence (FRE) Rule 608(b) state (are there any exceptions?). Second, does a false testimony in a divorce case qualify as evidence for a business lawsuit. Rule 608(b) says that extrinsic evidence can be used to cross examine an expert witneess to discredit them. However, I found many papers that stated "The general rule is that extrinsic evidence may not be produced on a collateral matter, but may be used if the subject matter is directly material to the issues." A material matter is one that directly relates to the subject of the case, whereas a collateral matter has no link. In this case, a material matter would be around financial analysis or repercussions. For example, if the expert witness had previously admiitted to financial fraud, this woould be a good use of material extrinsic evidence to discredit the witness. However, a false statement in a divorce proceeding is unlikely to be seen as material to a business matter, and therefore omitted.

column12: While investigating the differences between urethral injuries and bladder ruptures, there were many clues that suggested this man was suffering from a bladder dome injury. First, specific bladder injuries are common in car accidents where the person has a full bladder and is wearing a seatbelt. They medical staff smelled alcohol on his breath which alludes to the idea his bladder may have been full, and the opening paragraph state he was restrained when the collision happened. Next, a urethral injury without blood at the meatus is unlikely. The medical staff are also unlikely to insert a catheter if they suspect that the urethra is the issue as this would cause further injury. Then, a gross hemuria was observed. This is a telltale sign of bladder rupture. Finally, bladder rupture can happen without pelvic fractures. Car accidents are tthe most common cause for this. It's called Intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

column12: I started my research looking at what DDH is and how it is diagnosed. I found that DDH is indeed more common in female babies. Then I needed to figure out if the hip click always means hip dysplasia - or rather was it always necessary to do an ultrasound. Initially, I agreed with the AI that Xavier signed a contract and paid the first installment which denotes consideration and acceptance of the contract. However, because Zoey does not own te orchard, this would constitute misrepresentation and make the contract void or voidable. No matter how much money he's paid, he would still be entitled to recission of the contract because of the misrepresentation. However, the quitclaim deed assumes that the buyer is taking a risk. It does not promise that the grantor has ownership od the property they are selling - simply that they will transfer the deed to the grantee IF they have ownership. So I think A is the best defense, though she's unlikely to win with either defense.

column10: After my research: A (disallowed, as it falls under the category of hearsay information that does not fit within any legally accepted exception.): 70%; B (dismissed, because its potential to prejudice the case outweighs its probative value.): 30%
column12: During my research, I focused most on the ceptions to the hearsay rule. I looked into the present tense excpetion and the excited utterance exception. I think that the present tense exception would more likely apply if the statement was admitted as the statement needs to be made within seconds to up to 15minutes. The excited utterance exception could apply but would be difficult to prove that the delarant was still in shock when they made the statement. I found a source regarding whether police reports containing third party statements are admissable in court - the paper said no. When I looked into probative value and undue prejudice, the situation did not seem to fit. The prejudicial rule would dismiss the evidence if it referred to the defendant's character, prior actions or offences. I don't think the anonymous driver's statement would be conisdered prejudicial by the judge in the traditional sense. At least not outweighed by the probative value of the statement. So if the statement is going to be dismissed, I believe it's more likely to be due to the hearsay rule.

Penley, 318 N.C. 30 (1986)). Affidavits are also sworn testimony that are often admissable in court. The judge may choose not to take the nurse's statement into account but it does qualify as an exception to the hearsay rule. Therefore the judge has the authority to take it into account if they choose to - A.

The declaration is based on the idea that a person who is dying would be less likely to lie. I am fairly confident that the doctors affadavit would be admitted and the answer is A.

column12: After my research I was fairly confident that A was the correct answer. Undue influence can be used to argue against the formation of a contract and is common in will dispute cases and in elder abuse. If a person has used excessive persuasion over another leading to a contract that only benefits them this can be seen as undue influence. The influenced person would usually have a vulnerability, in this scenario the mother is dying and the daughter has threatened isolation if she does not agree to the arrangement. The influencer is also usually in a special relationship of trust and the person is dependent on the influencer, in this case the mother would have trust and dependency on the daughter. If this can be established then the contract can be voided. I also looked into insufficient consideration which I thought could have been an option because of the lower amount being offered for the property but found that courts aren't usually concerned about the consideration amount. Based on all this information A is more likely to be the correct answer.

column12: After my research I felt that there was a higher chance that A was the correct answer. The Universal Commercial Code (UCC) provides rules on goods and services and contracts can still be valid even if terms are missing. There are default rules or gap fillers when information like the payment amount and delivery location are silent. If the payment terms are missing then the price would be a reasonable price such as market price or sellers normal cost of the goods that may be mentioned in the companies catalogue. When there is no delivery date the rule would be to delivery to the sellers place of business. The contract is still enforceable and the Plumbing Company are still obligated to deliver the goods so I am fairly sure that A is correct in this scenario.

column12: First I tried to search directly whether infrared CCTV images were permissible in a US court of law to which I could not find a definitive answer. column12:
I initially searched for loss of commission on termination of employment under US law. I found three different law firms in different states two of which seemed to confirm that the company was more liable to win than the employee but it’s a complex area and made more difficult by individual federal and state laws.

Yusuf Butar, employment law advisers, stress the need for clear contracts that comprehensively address all the different nuances of commission payments.

Garrison Law in Connecticut go a lot further. They say there are three separate issues which need to be considered over payment of commissions after termination. These are:

1.	Under Connecticut law it’s not unlawful for an employer to terminate the contract of an employee to avoid paying outstanding commissions.

2.	The definition of a ‘wage’ has to be formally specified in the contract. You don’t get your commission until the client pays their bill, and if you’re not employed when the client pays their bill, you don’t get it, then the client paying their bill and your continued employment on that date are conditions precedent to the existence of a wage. For a wage to be classed as such it can be conditional on whether you’re still employed, and whether the client has paid their bill. 

3.	The third point, slightly more weighted in the employee’s favour says: The covenant of good faith and fair dealing is implied into every contract, whether it’s written or verbal — at least in Connecticut, but I think everywhere. Put simply employers can’t just use their discretion to avoid paying commissions as this would be seen as bad faith.

In the US being clear on federal and state law is vital in areas like this, where even after clarification there still seem to be inconsistencies. For example, issue 3 appears to be in direct contravention of issue 1. It’s for this reason that I lowered my marking for whether a or B was correct.

column10: fter research: A (Yes, because the release of a contractual obligation must be documented in writing): 85%; B (Yes, because there was no consideration provided for the removal of the construction companyâ€™s duty to install the pavement.): 15%
column12:
Verbal contracts in US law can be binding depending on federal and state law but there are a number of requirements and exceptions to take into account.

Any contract has to include:

1. An offer
An offer of some sort of good or service must be made by one party. 

2. Acceptance of the offer

4. A law-abiding purpose
The reason for the contract needs to be lawful and not for an illegal act.

5. Law-abiding consideration
Something of value needs to be exchanged between those involved in the agreement. Eg. a service and money

6. The terms must be certain
The terms of the agreement have to be clear and understandable. 

7. All parties must agree on their own free will

However additionally if a service or goods are being provided which have a greater value than $500 then a written contract is required.

Often verbal contracts are limited to simpler transactions of smaller value such as:

1.	Small and personal transactions: Eg. buying a second-hand item, such as a used TV from a friend. Unlikely to need a written agreement.

2.	Low value short-term or informal arrangements: When it comes to informal arrangements or short-term agreements, such as babysitting or pet-sitting.

3.	Trusted relationships: In some instances, verbal agreements can work well in relationships that have well-established trust, such as those between parents and adult children or longstanding friends.

In the example, the construction company was negligent from the outset in only relying on a verbal contract in the full knowledge the value of the services was $200,000. The construction company and the customer had a duty of care to protect the transaction with a fully documented and witnessed contract. Even if they were friends the value of the job is high enough to warrant proper documentation and contract. As such, any subsequent complications, such as reintroducing the pavement as a part of the service can’t be considered as part of the contract because the contract was wholly inadequate in the first place.

column12:
US law on the admissibility of hearsay evidence appears straightforward initially. However, there are more than 30 complex exceptions, which can alter whether evidence is acceptable or not.

In this case, the account the plaintiff gave in the hospital was a first-hand account and he clearly couldn’t attend court because he died. These are two of the requirements for acceptability. However, the plaintiff was also fully aware of his impending death because of the accident, which converted his affidavit into a ‘dying declaration’.

This sentence clearly sums up the situation: A statement from an unavailable declarant is not barred by the hearsay rules if the statement was made when the declarant believed that death was imminent and the statement concerned the cause or circumstances of the declarant’s impending death.

Originally the dying declaration ruling also stated: The former statute on dying declarations also required that the declarant must have been in actual danger at the time of the statement, and must have died as a result, but those requirements are not included in the current rule.

Overall, the affidavit appears to be admissible to the court because it was a first-hand account and he subsequently died so couldn’t appear in court. Further, the plaintiff repeatedly complained of his imminent death making his statement a dying declaration.
