Apologies I got these 2 the wrong way round on the question page
Correct split: Urethra 25% and Bladder 75%

In a high-speed collision, a direct blow to a distended bladder commonly by a seat belt can result in intraperitoneal injury. This is a serious injury with significant morbidity that often occurs with other injuries in the local area. The bladder is located in the anterior pelvis in an adult. The dome is covered by the peritoneum, and the bladder neck is fixed to the pelvis by fascia and ligaments. A gross hematuria is a typical symptom as is tenderness around the lower abdomen.

In a similar accident where the urethra is injured, the pelvis is frequently fractured at the same time. In the urethral trauma, the urethra is often severed when the pelvis fractures and needs to be reconnected. The second type of urethral trauma is called a straddle injury, such as when someone is riding a bike, slips and lands heavily on the crossbar between their legs.

The symptoms of urethral trauma don’t include a hematuria and consequently, this injury is much more likely to be to the bladder dome.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, to demonstrate the defendantâ€™s inclination to engage in such criminal activity.): 80%; B (Yes, to establish the lack of mistake.): 20%

column10: After research: A (Yes, to demonstrate the defendantâ€™s inclination to engage in such criminal activity.): 80%; B (Yes, to establish the lack of mistake.): 20% - Incorrect see notes below

I accidentally hit the done button creating another copy of the ‘before research’
so 'after research' should read 50:50.

When considering whether to allow a prior conviction into evidence, judges must decide if the conviction's value in helping the jury assess the defendant's truthfulness outweighs its potential for prejudice, where the defendant’s reputation suffers.

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b), evidence of other acts can be introduced by the prosecution to prove a defendant’s “motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, or absence of mistake or accident.”  This type of evidence is only admissible if the State shows:

(1) that it seeks to introduce the evidence not to raise an improper inference as to the defendant’s character but for some proper purpose.

(2) that there is sufficient evidence to establish that the defendant committed the independent offense

(3) that there is a sufficient connection or similarity between the independent offense and the crime charged so that proof of the former tends to prove the latter.” Amica v. State, 704 S.E.2d 831 (Ga.App. 2010).

Similar transaction evidence can be one of the largest hurdles facing a criminal defendant.  Although the judge tells the jury that all this evidence about the other crime cannot be used to determine the guilt for the crime that the defendant is on trial for, that is not a reality. Evidence of prior crimes will almost always create some bias in the minds of jurors.

To establish a violation of Fraud and False Statements section 7206(1) such as falsifying accounts, the court must establish the following four elements occurred beyond a reasonable doubt:

1.	 Making and subscribing a return, statement, or other document which was false in material matters.

2.	 The return, statement, or other document contained a written declaration that was made under the penalties of perjury.

3.	The defendant did not believe the return, statement, or other document to be true and correct as to every material matter.

4.	The defendant falsely subscribed to the return, statement, or other document wilfully, with the specific intent to break the law.

So, previous similar accusations or convictions can be admitted to the court as evidence however the evidence is subjective in that it can’t help but raise suspicions in the mind of the judge and jury.

Initially, I thought the likelihood was that the defendant was guilty because previous evidence of a similar crime was being submitted to court. However, on reflection without hearing the defendants defence about how the submission was faulty it is impossible to conclude anything but 50:50 between A and B.

column12:
In the US, the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) governs commercial agreements like contracts for the sale of goods and services. Some states made modifications to certain UCC requirements, so state statutes and common law concerning commercial contracts vary among states, so a careful analysis of the state law governing the contract is vital.

In the example, the location of delivery and the terms of payment are both silent or not included.

According to UCC requirements if the location delivery isn’t specified then the delivery should be made to the buyer's head office. Under the terms of payment when not specified in the contract the default UCC regulation states that payment should be made on the same day as delivery.

Ideally, contracts which are for substantially more than $500, such as this one, should be governed by a clear and full contract between buyer and seller.

On the basis of these two factors B is the correct answer.

Performance on a contract means doing what you're obligated to do under the contract. In the case of contracts for the sale of goods, the basic obligation is that the seller delivers the goods and the buyer pays for the goods.

UCC article 2 goes further and provides specific rules relating to shipments and deliveries of goods, as well as to payment. Additionally, under Article 2, you'll find the following rules:

•	a rule that certain risks and burdens can be divided between the seller and buyer
•	a rule that a valid contract doesn't necessarily need to include a price term 
•	a rule regarding whether and how an order for goods can be delivered in several lots 
•	a set of rules regarding warranties.

However, then I tried www.stars21.com and that translated the full sentence to ‘I see you can hit a snake.’ As this was the closest I had found, I then tried translating the first two words of the Lojban into English. This produced:

Za’a translated to ‘apparently’

Ga’a translated to ‘absolutely’

I thought this might be useful, so I decided to test the same translator with another sentence, and I input ‘as you saw.’ However, this was translated as ‘tai lo na do viska.’ Which undermined the credibility of the two word translations above. 

In the end, driven more by guesswork than logic, I thought the translation of ga’a as absolutely had more of a definitive ring as the expression ‘as you saw’ So I loaded my decision on the side of B but only slightly to demonstrate it wasn’t conclusive.

column6: Before research: A (Undue influence.): 60%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 40%
column7: The daughter certainly seemed to be applying undue influence in several ways to her mum but not understanding Insufficient consideration I could only lean a bit in A's direction.
column10: After research: A (Undue influence.): 77%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 23%
column12:
Undue influence is a growing problem in the US and many other countries where vulnerable family members at the end of life are coerced into decisions they ordinarily may not have made. Two definitions of undue influence include:

Undue influence occurs when a fiduciary or confidential relationship exists in which one person substitutes his own will for that of the influenced person’s will. 

In 2014, California law was amended to address this problem “excessive persuasion that causes another person to act or refrain from acting by overcoming that person’s free will and results in inequity.” 

The effect of undue influence needs to include these four elements:

•	Vulnerability of the victim
•	Apparent authority of the influencer
•	Actions or tactics used by the influencer
•	Equity of the result - who is to gain or lose


Insufficient consideration in dealing with family estates uses similar principles as applied in contract law in the US. It can be summarised as: ‘That is, one party provides something of value to the other party to induce a promise from the other party or to induce performance from the other party.’ The accusation of insufficient consideration comes about when one party argues that the value that it provided the other party is greater than the value it was provided in return.  Therefore, the consideration was inadequate.

Comparing the evidence of undue influence and insufficient consideration to the example of the daughter and mother the former is much more clear. For example, the vulnerability of the mother is apparent as she is receiving end of life care. Secondly, the daughter promoted herself as the more responsible of the two children so she did have more authority but only in her mind. Thirdly the tactics the daughter used to coerce her mother were underhand. She threatened to stop visiting if her mother didn’t accede. Lastly, the equity was unfair. The mother wanted both children to have equal shares of the estate and the daughter’s proposition would have altered this considerably.

The evidence for insufficient consideration is less clear although the equity of the new family estate result would prove grounds for insufficient consideration. There was surprisingly little online information about insufficient consideration in the context of family estates.

column6: Before research: A (Undue influence.): 60%; B (Insufficient consideration.): 40%
column7: With reduced brachial and radial pulses on the left side I thought it unlikely the systolic pressures on each side would be equal.
column10: After research: A (The systolic blood pressure measurements in the right and left arms are likely to be equal): 25%; B (Inserting a stent in the left subclavian artery may be beneficial): 75%
column12:
It wouldn’t be unusual for a 65-year-old chronic smoker to develop vascular disease.
The reduced brachial and radial pulses on the left side suggest there is a blockage in the subclavian artery on that side while the right-hand side is okay. Similarly, a bruit above the left clavicle could also be an indicator demonstrating the turbulence of blood flow in the artery caused by a partial blockage.

The different types of subclavian artery disease include the following symptoms:

1.	A lower blood pressure reading in one arm compared to the other.
2.	Discoloration in your arm or hands.
3.	Numbness, tingling, weakness or pain in your arm.
4.	Swelling.
5.	Sensitivity to cold in your hands.
6.	Dizziness.
7.	Fever.
8.	Fainting

Of these, the patient is experiencing 1, 3, 6.

Option A suggests that the systolic blood pressure between left and right arms would be the same. However, the above information suggests the opposite where, the narrowing of the subclavian artery would lower the pulses in the left arm.

Option B suggests inserting a stent in the left subclavian artery. This would help to reduce the narrowing of the artery and improve blood flow. Consequently, B is much more likely to be the better option.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 50%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 50%

column10: After research: A (Yes, because the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it.): 35%; B (Yes, because the stipulation regarding the property ownerâ€™s approval of the lease transfer was outside the influence of either party.): 65%
column12:
Every state has a statute of frauds, which defines which contracts must be in writing to be enforceable. These statutes vary slightly, but the fundamental principles are similar.

Examples of contracts that parties have to put in writing to be enforceable include:

Contracts that last longer than one year
Contracts involving the sale or transfer of land
Contracts involving products sold for over $500
Contracts that require an executor of a will to repay debts
Contracts involving collateral when one party assumes the responsibility for the other party’s debt
Marriage-related contracts, like prenuptial agreements

 ‘A’ suggests that the contract being developed by the lawyer was simply a documentation of a preexisting agreement, not a prerequisite for it. However, this also means that the pre-existing agreement was an undocumented verbal agreement only. As such, the defence that a verbal contract was in place wouldn’t be enforceable under most US state’s laws, as the business value is well over $500.

In ‘B’ the property owner’s right to assign the lease to a new party is solely under the discretion of the property owner. Even though details of the property owner's decision on the assignation of the business is included in the contract both the uncle and the nephew don’t have any say in how it is assigned. So, on that basis, the nephew may have cause to sue for breach of contract. B is therefore the better course of action.

column6: Before research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 40%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 60%
column7: I didn't think A was correct so I guessed at a weak yes for B without any evidence to back it up.
column10: After research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 20%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 80%
column12:
The right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings but this doesn’t form the sole basis for invoking her right to the 5th amendment. 

A defendant in a civil or criminal prosecution who voluntarily testifies
at trial waives his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.
Unlike the ordinary witness, the accused cannot be compelled to
answer any question; but once he has taken the stand and
testified on his behalf, he may be cross-examined like an ordinary
witness. Questions which elicit an incriminating response are then no
longer barred by the Fifth Amendment privilege, for the defendant's
waiver removes the constitutionally prohibited element of compulsion.

This waiver rule has been justified on two grounds:

Firstly, a defendant should not be allowed to present his side
of his own story to the jury without cross-examination designed to discover and correct any distortion of the truth.

Additionally, when a defendant has given substantial testimony, he would find
little, if any, protection by claiming the privilege. By this time, policies
of disclosure are thought to outweigh the privilege.

Cases concerning self-incrimination apply to both civil and criminal proceedings. However, there are differences in the civil case, because the jury may be allowed to draw certain inferences from the refusal to testify, and the defendant may be barred from presenting certain evidence.

So, B is much more likely to be correct, as the woman relinquished her 5th Amendment right by choosing to testify voluntarily.

column12:
Initially, the bag of worms feeling sounds like Varicocele, which is like varicose veins in the scrotum. However, in this case, it sounds unlikely as Varicocele usually forms in the left testicle and this is in the right. Also, with Varicocele you can see them standing up but not when lying down. So, this is unlikely to be a case of Varicocele.

Testicular cancer can be painful or pain-free but as option B is suggesting a CT scan for the abdomen this might be looking for cancer which has spread from the testicle to the lymph nodes in the abdomen. I discovered this right at the end of my research after I finished recording. If it is testicular cancer it’s unusual that the mass is separate from the testicle itself, as it is usually inside the testicle.

column6: Before research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 30%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 70%
column7: A is asking only for 'sufficient ground' to believe that the child can deliver an accurate and truthful testimony whereas B is asking for 'compelling evidence'. With someone so young a higher level of admissibility is advisable.
column10: After research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 15%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 85%
column12:
Children appear in court as witnesses much more frequently, which has produced a large amount of litigation on their competence to testify. Consequently, US law on this topic is changing rapidly and still varies significantly from state to state.

For example, some states rule that children are incompetent unless they understand the nature of an oath. Likewise, some states rule that children below certain ages, usually 10, 12, or 14, are presumed incompetent unless determined otherwise however no minimum age exists for children's testimony.

To testify, a child must have certain characteristics, which include:

•	the capacity to observe
•	sufficient intelligence
•	adequate memory
•	the ability to communicate
•	awareness of the difference between truth and falsehood
•	an appreciation of the obligation to tell the truth.


Witnesses are questioned to decide their competence to testify under a voir dire examination, which is usually held to determine whether a child is competent. The trial judge has substantial discretion regarding the conduct of this examination. The burden of proof rests on the party challenging the child's capacity to testify. Attorneys should carefully prepare children for the competency examination

In this case, the child is 4 years old and has been traumatised by the attack. Developmentally, although 3- to 4-year-olds are more likely to label anything that is not true as a lie, older children can distinguish between a mistake and intentional misrepresentation. Given that many children lie spontaneously in experimental situations that have no immediate consequences for the child, it is not surprising that under coercive situations, especially if asked by a parent or authority figure to do so, children will lie. This is a compelling argument for not allowing such a young witness to testify and for the fact that very young children may be incapable of providing a coherent version of events.

That said the only testimony required from the young witness in this case is to confirm or deny that the accused who held the gun is the same man as in the court.

The difference between A & B comes down to the degree of accuracy of the child’s testimony. A demands only ‘sufficient grounds’ while B demands ‘compelling evidence’. As the witness is of such a young age B therefore has to be the better choice.

column6: Before research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 40%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 60%
column7: It doesn't appear to be inappropriate character evidence because it's demonstrating that the expert witness was prepared to give false testimony previously.
column10: The above split is correct not this pasted one: After research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 40%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 60%
column12:
A good expert witness is required to demonstrate open-handed honesty, even to the extent of admitting fallibility or possibility of error, as well as integrity.

The expert witness’s testimony concerns the financial repercussions of the cog business and the expert witness’s previous false testimony may also have concerned financial matters in the dissolution of his marriage. Consequently, the testimony can’t be regarded as inappropriate character information because his false testimony concerned the dissolution of his marriage possibly with financial implications.

It’s better if the expert witness is cross-examined so the full extent of his false testimony can be examined and its implications in this case. Consequently, B is the better option.

column12:
The symptoms experienced by the patient possibly indicate chronic venous insufficiency, but it may also be caused by a side effect of the chemotherapy.

Both of the diagnostic methods have gained credibility in treating chronic venous insufficiency.  Venous duplex scanning (VDS) is one of the most recent non-invasive techniques introduced and has rapidly gained acceptance in the diagnosis of venous thrombosis. The accuracy of VDS is such that many now accept it as the non-invasive technique of choice for diagnosing lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The increased availability, short acquisition time, and high diagnostic accuracy of MDCT have rendered 

However, CT angiography (CTA) of the lower extremities is also one of the initial imaging examinations of choice in the diagnosis of vascular injury, especially after trauma, as it is quick to apply.

Although CT angiography and duplex scans are not completely equivalent, their results are similar. From a cost perspective, duplex ultrasound scanning is likely to be substantially less costly and can lower overall radiation exposure. Consequently, B is the better option but only by a margin.

column6: Before research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 30%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 70%
column7: I wasn't sure but I thought both parties in a contract had to act in good faith and the neighbour evidently wasn't.
column10: After research: A (No, because the woman did not provide any written documentation.): 15%; B (No, because the contract was voidable due to the womanâ€™s evident incapacity.): 85%
column12:
The defence under A that the contract wasn’t written and so wasn’t enforceable isn’t correct. Goods or services being sold for more than $500.00 should have a written contract however as this car was being sold for $450.00 then a written contract isn’t necessarily required.

However, when selling a car, a Bill of Sale does protect sellers by documenting the sale and transfer of ownership to the buyer. In many states, the sale of a vehicle is not final until the buyer has obtained a new title displaying their ownership.

In terms of capacity for a contract to be legally binding, all individuals who sign must have ‘contractual capacity.’ This refers to the minimum mental capacity required to enter into an agreement. Individuals who lack the capacity to contract are presumed to not know what they're doing, and they can void, or set aside, the contract.

However, if a party is so far gone as to be unable to understand even the nature and consequences of the agreement, and the other (sober) party takes advantage of the person's condition, then the contract may be voidable by the inebriated party. In this case the neighbour knew the seller had been in hospital and knew the seller was acting strangely, as well as knowing the true value of her car.

The law recognizes three categories of individuals who lack the capacity to contract:

•	minors
•	individuals with psychological disabilities
•	intoxicated persons

If anyone from these categories enters into a contract, the agreement might be considered voidable by them. This protects the party who lacks capacity from being forced to go through with a deal that takes advantage of his or her lack of savvy.

States use different tests to determine whether a person has the mental capacity to form a contract.

There are different "cognitive" tests.

The affective test. Some states use what's called the "affective test": A contract can be voided if one party is unable to act in a reasonable manner and the other party has reason to know of the condition.

The motivational test. Courts measure capacity by the person's ability to judge whether or not to enter into the agreement. These tests can produce varying results when applied to mental conditions such as bipolar disorder.

So overall the seller is well within her rights to void the contract.

column6: Before research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 65%; B (successful.): 35%
column7: The father expressly asked the son not to marry before he graduates & the son agreed but this wasn't formalised in a written contract even though there was a verbal one.
column10: After research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 30%; B (successful.): 70%
column12:
The father proposed a deal that he would finance the student's tuition, the overdue rent of $650, the remaining rent for the academic year, and provide a monthly allowance of $200 until the student completes his legal studies, on the condition that the student doesn’t marry until he graduates.

The father agrees to pay & the son agrees (1)

‘If I do not receive a response by January 25, I will assume that you consent to this arrangement.’ The landlord, without responding to the father's letter, did not evict the student.

The landlord by default agrees to not evict son

Verbal contracts can be legally binding, but there are exceptions and verbal contracts are harder to verify and prove. Like written contracts, verbal contracts must include the elements of a valid contract to be enforceable and legally binding:

1.	Offer and acceptance – the father agrees to finance the son’s allowance and rent, and the son accepts.

2.	Consideration – they both agreed the money was provided for rent and the son’s allowance.

3.	Legality – the contract needs to be legal

4.	Capacity – the father & son must clearly understand the obligations, terms, and consequences of the contract before they sign

The agreement between the father and son was verbal and the value of the son’s claim is relatively low ($800.00) even if this is a little over the threshold limit of $500.00 in contract law. There is no indication that the son is a beneficiary of the estate or even if there was a will. Consequently, as the required elements of the contract were present even though it’s a verbal contract it should still hold, so B is the more likely correct answer.

https://la-lojban.github.io/sutysisku/lojban/#seskari=catni&sisku=krixa&bangu=en&versio=masno

And it gave translations for both words:

krixa - cries out or howls

In the context of the sentence, the first of these is the most appropriate as it indicates a passive form of crime. Therefore, B is the most likely right answer.

column6: Before research: A (Reassure the mother): 33%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 67%

column10: After research: A (Reassure the mother): 0%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 100%
column12:
Gravida means pregnancies and Para means live births. If your patient is currently pregnant; and had two previous deliveries she is G3 P2

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a problem with the way a baby's hip joint forms. Sometimes the condition starts before the baby is born, and sometimes it happens after birth, as the child grows. It can affect one hip or both. Often when the hip is manipulated it makes a popping or clicking sound.

This is because the hip does not form well. The ball part of the joint may be completely, or partly, out of the socket. Sometimes the ball part may slide in and out of the socket and often, the socket is shallow. It needs fixing or the hip joint will not grow well. Any baby can have DDH but it is more prevalent in girls.

Symptoms of DDH include:

•	The baby's hips make a popping or clicking that is heard or felt.
•	The baby's legs are not the same length.
•	One hip or leg doesn't move the same as the other side.
•	The skin folds under the buttocks or on the thighs don't line up.
•	The child has a limp when starting to walk.

An ultrasound is a common way of assessing the baby's hip joint. This works best with babies under 6 months of age because most of a baby's hip joint is still soft cartilage, which won't show up on an X-ray. X-rays are used for assessment in older patients.

There are several treatment options available which should solve the problem without lasting complications. It might be necessary to have checkups with a specialist to ensure the hip is developing correctly.

As the baby is a girl and the distinctive popping sound has been noted then option B, ultrasound screening is the best choice.

column6: Before research: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 60%; B (Double bubble sign): 40%
column7: I had an inkling lung odema would cause blue lips
column10: After research: A (Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema): 80%; B (Double bubble sign): 20%
column12:
Subcostal retractions: Indrawing of the abdomen just below the rib cage (sometimes referred to as belly breathing).

Perioral cyanosis – blue lips caused by lack of oxygen

A - Diffuse interstitial pulmonary lung disease refers to a group of lung disorders that affect the interstitium, which is the connective tissue or sac which is the support structure of the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs. Normally when you inhale, the air sacs fill with air and oxygen passes into the blood stream. When you exhale, carbon dioxide that passed from the blood into the air sacs breathed out. With interstitial lung disease, the lung becomes inflamed and stiff, preventing the air sacs from fully expanding. This limits the delivery of oxygen to the blood stream and the removal of carbon dioxide from the body, causing strained breathing – subcostal retractions and blue lips. As the disease progresses, the interstitium thickens, which further impedes lung function.

B - A double bubble sign in newborn infants can be seen on X-ray, where it has various causes. It shows as two air-filled structures in the upper abdomen and represents a gas-distended dilated stomach and duodenum, suggesting bowel obstruction. Diagnosis and treatment varies with each different type of double bubble sign.

A is the more likely outcome in this case. This is based on symptoms including:

•	Subcostal retractions – the baby is struggling to breathe because of the fluid in the lungs.

•	Perioral cyanosis and a low oxygen saturation of 86% - not enough oxygen is getting through the lungs.

•	This condition is not unusual in young infants

A double bubble sign wouldn’t present with these symptoms.

column6: Before research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 50%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 50%
column7: I had no idea between the 2 so I went 50:50
column10: After research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 85%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 15%
column12:
I tried several Lojban dictionaries and eventually found 2 that gave translations likely to fit the context.

The words at the beginning of the sentences: cfagau & cfari appeared to have the meaning of started, so I based my research on these two.

Two separate dictionaries gave the translation of

Cfagau – as cause to begin, initiates, begins

Cfari - as occur and there was a French reference to the verb initier: to begin

Consequently, I chose the former, as it carries a sense of being the agent of change, while the latter is a more passive reference to something occurring. I felt comfortable enough that a was the correct answer to rate it as 85%.

column10: After research: A (Yes, because the customerâ€™s position in the queue served as a notification to the bank of their acceptance.): 40%; B (Yes, because the bank was unable to withdraw its offer once the customer had initiated performance.): 60%
column12:
The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a plethora of state consumer protection laws exist to protect consumers from unfair or deceptive advertisers, whether in store or online. Laws vary between states and claims of ignorance will never work as a defense, so it’s the responsibility of business owners to fully understand sales promotion laws. 

However, at the same time, it is very difficult to find any categoric information on sales promotions except online promotions. It is generally agreed that any promotion needs to comply with personal and sensitive personal information state laws, as well as GDPR.

Does a retailer have the right to withdraw an offer/promotion without prior notice regardless of whether the offer has a ‘valid until’ date on it? Or is this always subject to rule 8.17.4.e of the CAP code?

I ran out of research time but found this link to https://www.asa.org.uk/advice-online/promotional-marketing-closing-dates.html

concerning closing dates for promotions. Changing the closing date can only be made in unavoidable circumstances or where the customer is going to be disadvantaged.

Hence, I moved the slider more towards the middle as I didn’t have enough specific information to make an informed decision.

column6: Before research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 70%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 30%
column7: Without enough information I could only guess 50:50%
column10: After research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 80%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 20%
column12:
Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a highly accurate test for evaluating intraperitoneal hemorrhage but is performed less frequently today due to the increased use of focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) and helical computed tomography (CT Scan). DPL plays a role in both blunt and penetrating abdominal trauma.

Both CT scanning and DPL is indicated in both blunt and a selective group of penetrating abdominal injuries. In blunt injuries, DPL has several indications but is dependent upon the patient's condition and the availability of CT scanning and focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST). DPL is useful for patients who are in shock and when FAST capability is not available. However, patients, such as the example, with low blood pressure should not be evaluated with CT scanning and DPL is also useful in patients with an unreliable abdominal exam due to altered mental status, like the patient’s concussion.

FAST exams are rapid, non-invasive, and can be repeated multiple times throughout the resuscitation period. They are more user-dependent than DPL or CT scanning. Both FAST and DPL ineffectively evaluate retroperitoneal and diaphragmatic injuries and poorly identify solid organ injuries. Abdominopelvic CT scanning still requires a hemodynamically normal patient, is costly.

So, on the basis the patient has low blood pressure and concussion, it’s best if he is assessed with DPL rather than a CT scan.

column10: After research: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 15%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 85%

I tried to recover the clip, but it seems it wasn’t saved. Not sure what to do? Do you want me to make another video of the research I carried out?

This case presents the question of whether the use of a thermal-imaging device aimed at a private home from a public street to detect relative amounts of heat within the home constitutes a “search” within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.

Police were investigating suspected indoor marijuana growing, which typically requires high-intensity lamps. To determine whether the amount of heat emanating from the petitioner’s home was consistent with the use of such lamps, police used a thermal imager to scan the property.

However, they fell foul of the Fourth Amendment which provides that “the right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated.” “At the very core” of the Fourth Amendment “stands the right of a man to retreat into his own home and there be free from unreasonable governmental intrusion.”

In the example, the business owner is protecting his property from illegal intruders using thermal imaging cameras. As the cameras are on his land and so long as they don’t point to any private properties beyond the boundary of his business premises then he is entitled to make infrared recordings for security purposes.

Consequently, B is the more accurate answer as a is referring to the infringement of personal liberty on private land.

column6: Before research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 30%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 70%
column7: I initially thought with the extent of the burns that intravenous fluids would be a priority
column10: After research: A (Insertion of an endotracheal tube): 60%; B (Administration of intravenous fluids): 40%
column12:
A circumferential burn is present when the entire circumference of a body part, such as the neck is burned. This has serious consequences as the inelastic burned skin has the potential to constrict the underlying tissues and airways, especially with fluid retention. As the burn surrounds the neck there is a possibility the burned skin might contract sufficiently to restrict the airways.

Low blood pressure and a high pulse rate can be a sign of shock which would be expected in 43% burns.

Extensive burns invariably result in severe changes in heart and organ function known as burn shock. Shock is an abnormal physiologic state in which fluid transport in tissue is insufficient for oxygen and nutrient delivery and cellular waste removal. Consequently, the blood becomes thicker. The consequences of a severe burn are profound and result in complex metabolic changes that can adversely affect every organ system

Stabilisation of burn victims in terms of priority includes stabilising respiration, fluid resuscitation, cardiovascular stabilization, pain control, and local management of burn wounds.

Although constriction of the neck can quickly lead to asphyxiation this priority has to be balanced with the threat of major fluid loss. Inserting an endotracheal tube (A) and then quickly counteracting fluid loss (B) are the best courses of action.

column6: Before research: A (CT scan): 75%; B (Observation and follow up in 14 days): 25%
column7: Ear problems can quickly turn dangerous, so a wait of 14 days didn't seem practical
column10: After research: A (CT scan): 90%; B (Observation and follow up in 14 days): 10%
column12:
Otitis media is another name for a middle-ear infection. It means an infection behind your eardrum. This kind of ear infection can happen after any condition that keeps fluid from draining from the middle ear. Connected to the middle ear is your eustachian tube, which drains fluid into the back of your throat and ventilates the middle ear space. An infection can cause the eustachian tube to swell and block fluid from draining or allow negative pressure to build up. These conditions include allergies, a cold, a sore throat, or a respiratory infection. Middle-ear infections are common in children, but they can also happen in adults.

Infections can affect the middle ear in several ways. They are:

1.        Acute otitis media. This middle-ear infection occurs suddenly. It causes swelling and redness. Fluid and mucus become trapped inside the ear. You can have a fever and ear pain.

2.        Otitis media with effusion. Fluid (effusion) and mucus build up in the middle ear after the infection goes away. You may feel like your middle ear is full. This can continue for months and may affect your hearing.

3.        Chronic otitis media with effusion. Fluid (effusion) remains in the middle ear for a long time. Or it builds up again and again, even though there is no infection. This type of middle-ear infection may be hard to treat. It may also affect your hearing.

As the fluid builds up in the middle ear, viruses or bacteria can grow, causing an infection in the middle ear. Children have narrower and shorter eustachian tubes than adults, making them more prone to ear infections.

The 6-year-old still has a temperature even after anti-biotics, which may be caused by the otitis media flaring up again or another middle ear complication such as:

•        Polyps of the middle ear

•        Destruction of bones in the middle ear

•        Cholesteatoma

Observation and 14 day follow up is too long as the condition might deteriorate, so A is the best option where a CT scan may highlight any complications including the small bones in the ear.

column10: After research: A (prevail, due to the fact that Xavier deliberately negotiated and procured a quitclaim deed from Zoey in anticipation of securing the apple orchard.): 65%; B (emerge victorious, as Xavier, by offering the initial $1,500 payment, is estopped from renouncing the validity of his contractual agreement with Zoey.): 35%
column12:
A quitclaim deed releases a person’s interest in a property without stating the nature of the person’s interest or rights, and with no warranties of that person’s interest or rights in the property.

A quitclaim deed makes no assurance that the grantor actually has an ownership interest in a property; it merely states that if the grantor does, they release those ownership rights.
Quitclaim deeds are typically used to transfer property in non-sale situations, such as transfers of property between family members.

To create a binding contract with Xavier to sell the land to him she needs to have ownership. In the probate is proven that Zane was indeed the owner. Even though a quitclaim deed had been arranged Zoe, as the grantor, doesn’t have ownership of the land so the quitclaim is irrelevant in this context. As such all they created between them was a void contract as such all they created was a void contract because Zoey didn’t disclose the material fact that she wasn’t the legal owner of the land. A void contract never starts to become a working contract, it is void from the outset.

Consequently, if she decided to take Xavier to court it would be very unlikely that she could win because the contract with Xavier was void as she didn’t own the property.

After thinking about this question more at the end I can see I made an error. Initially, I thought the deceased individual wouldn’t be available to testify because he died but of course I should have been considering the security guard instead. He wasn’t unavailable, he just chose not to attend the civil trial because he was appealing his manslaughter charge. Hence, his testimony transcript wouldn’t have been admissible as it didn’t qualify on the first condition.

So, my after research slider readings should have been opposite ie. A 20% and B 80%

Although qualified as hearsay and therefore consequently inadmissible, testimony (any transcript purchased from a court reporter or downloaded from CM/ECF or PACER is a certified copy) at a former trial may still be admitted into evidence in a subsequent proceeding so long as four conditions are met: 

1.	The witness must be unavailable to testify. A witness is unavailable if he is dead; out of the jurisdiction; insane, sick, or unable to testify; kept away by connivance, collusion, or consent of the other party; or cannot be found after a diligent search.
In the example, the security guard

2.	The second is that the parties be substantially the same – in the example the parties were essentially the same.

3.	The third is that, the two proceedings must involve substantially the same issues – one was a criminal trial and one a civil trial but essentially the same.

4.	Finally, the party against whom the evidence is offered must have had the opportunity to have cross-examined the witness at the earlier proceeding. He need not have done so; he merely had to have had the opportunity to do so. Although it’s not stated presumably there was an opportunity to cross-examine the witness previously.

It must be said this area of law is complex and there are exceptions to the general rule, further complicated by individual state law interpretations. In some states, testimony given at a criminal trial cannot be used against the criminal defendant in a civil lawsuit involving the same incident, even though the witness is dead or otherwise unavailable because courts in these states have concluded that the parties and the issues in the criminal and civil case were not substantially similar.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, as it constitutes a declaration against interest.): 60%; B (Yes, as it is considered a statement made by a co-conspirator.): 40%
column7: I wasn't aware of the legal implications but logic suggested the wife's testimony would be a declaration against interest.
column10: After research: A (Yes, as it constitutes a declaration against interest.): 70%; B (Yes, as it is considered a statement made by a co-conspirator.): 30%
column12:
Hearsay is defined as:

A party offers evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted in the statement.
Hearsay evidence is typically considered unreliable because it has not been made under oath or subjected to cross-examination. However, there are exceptions where hearsay can be admitted.

Co-Conspirator Exception

The co-conspirator exception reads:

A statement that meets the following conditions is not hearsay:

A statement by a co-conspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy.  However, its application has been controversial in some cases, as the exception can allow for the admission of statements that might otherwise be considered unreliable.

To admit a co-conspirator’s statement under this rule, such as the wife in this case, the following criteria must be met:

Existence of a Conspiracy
The court must find that there was a conspiracy involving the declarant and the party against whom the statement is offered. This does not mean that the conspiracy must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt, but there must be sufficient evidence to demonstrate its existence. However, although the friend’s wife heard her husband say, "I received payment to start the fire.", the wife made no statement to corroborate her involvement in the fire.

Statement Made During the Course of the Conspiracy
The statement must have been made while the conspiracy was ongoing. Statements made after the conspiracy has ended may not be admissible under this rule.

Statement Made in Furtherance of the Conspiracy
The statement must be made to help achieve the goals of the conspiracy. Casual remarks about the conspiracy may not qualify.

Under US law, a declaration against interest is an exception to the rule on hearsay in which a person's statement may be used, where generally the content of the statement is so prejudicial to the person making it that they would not have made the statement unless they believed the statement was true. If a driver in an automobile accident boasts publicly that they were speeding at the time, it may represent a legal admission of liability.

In the example, the plaintiff made his statement not only to his wife but in front of the nurse too, although there is no mention of the nurse being called as a witness.

Consequently, the wife's testimony can be admitted, despite the plaintiff's objection, as it constitutes a declaration against interest. A carries more weight.

column6: Before research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 40%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 60%

column12:
The patient didn’t have a fever, so it was unlikely that he had an infection. 

He was vomiting bile and had a raised white blood cell count (WBC), along with a very tender abdomen. The raised WBC could signify him fighting an infection but without a raised temperature this is unlikely. Raised WBC can also be caused by physical stress and as the abdominal X ray reveals dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels this may be the more likely reason. If this patient has an obstructed bowel then relieving the pressure with a nasogastric tube decompression might be the best solution. Consequently, I suggested 70% for B. However, there seemed to be other possibilities too but it’s a complex medical area to summarise in 20 mins.

column6: Before research: A (Excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay and does not qualify for any exceptions.): 60%; B (Not admissible, due to the fact it could potentially steer the courtâ€™s attention towards nonessential, irrelevant topics.): 40%
column7: I didn't have a strong conviction that the evidence would come under hearsay but stronger than answer B.
column10: After research: A (Excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay and does not qualify for any exceptions.): 50%; B (Not admissible, due to the fact it could potentially steer the courtâ€™s attention towards nonessential, irrelevant topics.): 50%
column12:
Hearsay law varies from state to state & this needs to be taken into account.

Hearsay is generally inadmissible in legal proceedings because of concerns about its reliability and its potential to introduce unreliable or fabricated evidence into any case. Hearsay testimony involves statements made outside of the courtroom which are not subject to cross-examination, so it can lack the accuracy and truthfulness evident in courtroom testimony.

Exceptions which allow hearsay evidence to be accepted in courtroom testimony:

Unavailable Declarants
If a witness testifies about a statement made by someone who is unavailable to testify, such as a victim who died, their hearsay statement could be admitted under the exception for statements made by unavailable declarants.

Excited Utterances
One exception to the hearsay rule is the admission of excited utterances. These are spontaneous statements made by a person under the influence of a startling event. In injury cases, such statements could include the immediate verbal reactions of a victim describing the event and their injuries. The lack of time for reflection allows for these utterances to be considered reliable and potentially admissible as evidence. In the example, the passenger made the statement about drinking alcohol previously almost as ‘thinking outloud’. It was a spontaneous reaction to the accident and as he was available to testify it could be accepted as an excited utterance.

Present Sense Impressions
Statements that describe an event or condition while the declarant is perceiving it, or immediately thereafter, fall under the present sense impression exception. For instance, in an injury case, a statement made by a witness about the condition of the accident scene or the injured party right after the accident can be deemed admissible as a present sense impression. That is because the impression is perceived and recounted in real-time without significant opportunity for fabrication.

The statement made by the passenger comes under the heading of a hearsay exception of excited utterance. The passenger made the statement still under the stress of
nervous excitement after the accident and it was not the product of studied reflection and possible fabrication. The passenger was available to attend court but excited utterance hearsay is admissible irrespective of whether the witness can or cannot attend court.

Consequently, choice  A doesn’t seem likely as the excited utterance is acceptable as court testimony & with B the statement only confirms that excess alcohol was a contributing factor but that this was unlikely to lead the court towards nonessential, irrelevant topics. So, my only option was to leave the slider at 50:50%.

column6: Before research: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 60%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 40%
column7: The dealer described the vehicle as 'excellent' which he knew not to be the case.
column10: After research: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 85%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 15%
column12:
If a car dealership sold you a car previously in an accident or with structural damage, frame damage, or other substantial damage without disclosing it to you, then you may have a claim under California law and many other states too. 

In many states dealerships that sell used cars need to disclose facts about cars to prospective customers but especially when:

1.	the dealer has exclusive knowledge of material facts about the car’s condition or history that are not reasonably discoverable by you

2.	the dealer has made some representations about the history of the car which would be misleading if the dealership did not disclose material facts about the full history

3.	the dealership has actively concealed material facts about the car’s condition or history from you

4.	the dealership has lied to you about the car’s condition

Dealers can substantially improve their margins by acquiring damaged and repaired used vehicles that have only been in an accident recently. They then sell it on quickly without disclosing the damage to you and before the damage can be logged on the databases of CarFax or AutoCheck, the vehicle history reporting companies. Likewise, a certified quality assurance certificate should detail any previous damage to the car. The customer in this case wasn’t alerted to the previous damage. Additionally, the dealer didn’t disclose information under each of the above headings from 1-4.

Although generally cars sold with a certified quality assurance certificate shouldn’t have any previous history of damage some do get sold. So, it is always the buyer's responsibility to thoroughly check out any claims that have been made.

The case for A is much stronger than B because of the evidence of the seller withholding information about the previous damage and his ‘overselling’ of an average car using words like ‘excellent’ and ‘rigorous inspection process’. In B the accusation of ‘oppressively unfair’ is a much more subjective accusation when compared to the clear-cut accusations of A.

column6: Before research: A (Angiography of the lower extremities): 60%; B (Initiate oral antibiotics): 40%
column7: There are no symptoms of infection so an angiogram is likely to produce more information.
column10: After research: A (Angiography of the lower extremities): 96%; B (Initiate oral antibiotics): 4%
column12:
The patient is showing numerous symptoms of peripheral artery disease (PAD). This is
an accumulation of plaque (fats and cholesterol) in the arteries in the legs or arms. This makes it harder for your blood to carry oxygen and nutrients to the tissues in those areas. PAD is a long-term disease, but you can improve it by exercising, eating less fat and giving up tobacco products.

PAD symptoms can include:

Leg pain when walking – the patient’s calf pain typically occurs after walking for about 10 minutes. This muscle pain in the legs begins with exercise and ends with rest. The typical symptom of PAD is called claudication, a medical term for pain in your leg that starts with walking or exercise and goes away with rest. The pain occurs because your leg muscles aren’t getting enough oxygen.

Muscle pain or cramping in the arms or legs, often in the calf – the patient has occasional calf pain.

Coldness in the lower leg or foot, especially when compared with the other side.

Leg numbness or weakness – the patient has reduced sensation to light touch in both feet.

No pulse or a weak pulse in the legs or feet – the patient has an ankle brachial index (ABI) is 0.3 on the right and 0.7 on the left. This suggests severe PAD in the right foot. Someone with severe PAD could have an ABI between 0.3-0.5. Critical cases have ABI ratios of 0.3 or less.

The patient has high levels of cholesterol, and being diabetic puts him at increased risk of developing PAD, because diabetes worsens high cholesterol levels, a common cause of PAD.

The patient has a history of tobacco use. Tobacco leads to atherosclerosis, the principal cause of PAD This is where plaque narrows arteries, leading to a reduction in blood flow to the limbs.

If plaque or a blood clot narrows or blocks your arteries, blood can’t get through to nourish organs and other tissues. This causes damage ― and eventually death (gangrene) ― to the tissues below the blockage. This happens most often in your toes and feet.

PAD also increases the risk of getting a nonhealing sore or ulcer on your legs or feet, like the patient. In cases of severe PAD, these sores can turn into areas of dead tissue (gangrene) that make it necessary to remove your foot or leg. Ulcers or gangrene are one of the last stages of PAD meaning urgent treatment is required or amputation of the limb might be necessary.

column12:
Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, Rule 801 defines what statements are considered hearsay, while Rule 802 establishes the general rule that hearsay is not admissible. Most state courts also follow these rules, but not all.

Rule 801 defines hearsay as, “…evidence based not on a witness's personal knowledge but on another's statement not made under oath.”

In the example, the police officer was approached by an anonymous, unidentified driver who said he witnessed the accident involving a cerulean sports car, which he followed to a fast food car park. After speaking with the driver, the officer then saw the same driver in a cerulean sports car in the same fast food car park.

The officer’s statement is out-of-court and it would be subject to a hearsay objection, where the testimony would be stricken or excluded altogether.

The officer’s statement is an oral assertion made out-of-court by a witness who had had time to reflect on the accident, rather than offering a spontaneous account.

If the person who approached the officer had important facts to disclose, why did he remain unidentified? Surely the officer would take his details. The fact that the witness was driving the same style and colour of car as the one he is suggesting was involved in the accident weakens his statement.

The above reasons make it much more likely that the statement would be disallowed as hearsay because it didn’t fall within any of the standard exceptions.

column12:
When a confession is made among other defendants while being questioned the evidence is only held against the person who confessed.  Any such statement won’t be admitted to adversely affect other co-defendants who are accused of the same crime.

Just because a suspect chooses not to answer questions, does not automatically mean that an adverse inference can be drawn. However, if they later put forward an account or explanation (not previously put forward) then an adverse inference provision is triggered.

An adverse inference can be drawn if a suspect is silent during questioning under caution before charge but then subsequently relies on a relevant fact in court, which they could reasonably have been expected to mention when interviewed by police.

An adverse inference may only be drawn where questions have been put to the suspect. Therefore, this section does not apply to a suspect who refused to leave his cell to be interviewed. However, the position would be different if the police had asked questions in the cell.

The admissibility of confessions of a co-defendant is a derivative of the
hearsay rules. These dictate that only if the confessor repeats his accusatory statement in court, and is consequently subject to cross-examination, then it becomes permissible in court and can be used against his accomplice. 

If the co-defendant chooses to acknowledge the confession, rather than remain silent then the statement becomes his own statement of facts rather than evidence or statement of his accomplice. This acknowledgement of confession can be by voluntary affirmance or by silence as an admission of acquiescence. Exposed to such circumstances an innocent person would either make a denial.

The Bruton rule was adopted when one defendant’s confession not only reveals that defendant’s guilt but also, by implication, powerfully incriminates another co-defendant. This leads to a situation where a judge’s limiting instruction to the jury becomes insufficient. Human nature dictates the jury would disregard the instruction and not necessarily come to a truthful conclusion.

In the example, answer A, suggests the confession is admissible. However, the confession was made during questioning and as such is classed as hearsay. Answer B alleges the confession isn’t admissible where the co-defendant is perfectly within his right to remain silent during questioning, so long as he doesn’t rely on evidence he may have withheld later during the trial. Consequently, answer B is the better of the two options.

column12:
According to the Federal Rule of Evidence (FRE), Rule 609, past convictions may be admitted to impeach the defendant but only under the following conditions:

•	The crime was punishable by death or a prison sentence of greater than 1 year

•	The crime involved fraud or dishonesty

The crime must typically be either a felony or specific misdemeanor offences involving dishonesty, such as fraud. 

The admissibility of such evidence is rigorously controlled, where judges must decide if the previous conviction's value in helping the jury assess the defendant's truthfulness outweighs its potential for prejudice. Evidence of a prior conviction carries a substantial possibility that jurors will presume the defendant has a propensity to commit similar crimes or is a bad person.

Additional protective measures include:

1.	Judges in some states cannot admit evidence about prior convictions unless the defence has already offered evidence to establish the defendant’s credibility.

2.	Prosecutors are usually limited to using evidence of actual convictions alone. They can't question defendants about pending charges or arrests that haven’t resulted in convictions. However, they can question testifying defendants about convictions that are currently on appeal or those where a sentence hasn't yet been imposed.

When assessing prior convictions courts typically consider the following factors:

•	the type of crime

•	whether the crime indicates that the defendant is untruthful

•	how much time has passed since the conviction (convictions that happened 10 years or longer ago are often inadmissible)

•	the length of imprisonment

•	the defendant's age at conviction

•	whether the defendant's credibility is central to the current case

•	the importance of the defendant's testimony in the current case 

•	the defendant's conduct since the prior conviction

As the evidence can be very prejudicial judges won’t usually consider evidence of prior convictions for the same or a similar crime as the one the defendant now faces. As an alternative, courts in many states won't admit very similar prior convictions if the prosecution can find a different prior conviction to impeach the defendant.
Occasionally, however, prior convictions can be used to substantiate the relevance of whether punitive damages are appropriate. 

The court explained that the prior convictions were relevant in that they tended to show that the defendant had not learned his lesson from his two prior convictions.

The evidence of other crimes is appraised using the Cofield Factors to test the eligibility of acceptance of evidence. The following factors are considered: 

•	The evidence of the other crime must be admissible as relevant to a material issue

•	It must be similar in kind and reasonably close in time to the offence charged

•	The evidence of the other crime must be clear and convincing

•	The probative value of the evidence must not be outweighed by its apparent prejudice

Courts need to apply the tests on a case-by-case basis to objectively assess evidence admissibility. 

In the example, the defendant’s prior conviction is an authenticated record although there is no mention of how long ago the offence occurred. Under normal circumstances, the evidence wouldn’t be admissible because the prior conviction was too like the one being tried. Lastly, under the Federal Rule of Evidence Rule 609 certain misdemeanour offences can be included, specifically when they carry a prison sentence of greater than 1 year. In the example, the defendant was let off leniently but could have served a two-year sentence in a state penitentiary, which would be a strong case for the admissibility of the evidence of her prior conviction. Consequently, A is the better option.

column12:
At-will employment refers to a working relationship where either the employer or the employee has the right to terminate employment at any time, with or without cause, and with or without notice or warning. Unlike an employee hired under a contract, at-will employment allows for flexibility for both parties should the working arrangement not work out at any time.

Exceptions to employment-at-will working conditions vary by state but may include:

Contracts: A written employment contract or collective bargaining agreement signed by the employer and the employee or union may outline employment over a specific period or allow termination only for cause, such as poor employee performance, misconduct, or budgetary reasons. Employers who use employment contracts are responsible for upholding and enforcing the terms within the contract.

Public policy: Under the public policy exception to employment-at-will, an employee is wrongfully discharged when a termination is for reasons against the state's policy. For example, in most states, an employer cannot terminate an employee to avoid paying pension rights.

Good faith and fair dealing: An implied duty of good faith and fair dealing assumes that each party should interact fairly and honestly concerning the employment relationship. Examples of bad faith terminations include an employer firing an older employee to avoid paying retirement benefits or terminating a salesperson before they are paid commission after closing a sale.

Implied contracts: Implied contracts of employment can occur when an employee may expect long-term, lifetime, or permanent employment based on an employer's statement(s), an employer's practice, or language in the employee handbook. Employers can protect themselves by using precise language on written materials stating that their policies and procedures do not represent a binding agreement or contract. Employers can also clearly communicate that they can modify policies and procedures at any time.

Under the exceptions to at-will employment the example employer could be accused of sidelining the employee with a gift for life and then reneging on the agreement 6 mths later blaming difficult trading conditions. This wouldn’t be seen favourably under ‘good faith and fair dealing’, ‘public policy’ and ‘implied contracts’. Especially when the employee had given 20 years good service. 

It could be suggested that the employer’s behaviour was cynical when he terminated the employee with a temporary gift to avoid his pension responsibilities. The employee may even have a claim under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). ERISA prohibits the discharge of employees to prevent vesting of pension rights and governs how pension plans are to be administered by private employers. Consequently, option A is the more likely option to prevail.

column12:
The Empty Can Test, also known as the Jobe or Supraspinatus test, is used to assess for lesions of the rotator cuff, specifically the supraspinatus muscle and supraspinatus tendon.

With the supraspinatus isolation test/empty can test or Jobe test, the supraspinatus muscle can be isolated by having the patient rotate the upper extremity so that the thumbs are pointing to the floor and resistance is applied with the arms in 30° of forward flexion and 90° of abduction. This simulates the emptying of a can. Testing the arm with the thumb in 'thumbs up' (full can position) is best for maximal contraction of the supraspinatus muscle.

The resistance provided by the examiner enables them to assess for weakness or pain. Either response would represent a positive test, which would indicate a tear of the supraspinatus muscle or tendon, or a neuropathy of the suprascapular nerve.

While the Empty Can Test is a useful diagnostic tool it has limitations for isolated supraspinatus pathology, as many shoulder muscles are simultaneously stimulated.

How do you test for infraspinatus?

The patient is asked to externally rotate both forearms against the examiner's resistance. The test is positive when there is weakness or pain in external rotation. Infraspinatus tears are usually painless so external rotation weakness strongly suggests infraspinatus tear.

When comparing the individual tests for the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles the description in the example is much more likely to involve the supraspinatus muscle, hence B is the better answer.

column12:
A contract implied in fact consists of obligations arising from a mutual agreement expressed not through words but implied through actions. To support a contract implied in fact, facts and circumstances surrounding the actions must show a mutual intent to contract, based on the behaviour of the respective parties. For example, if a customer enters a hair salon, sits in a chair, and asks for a haircut, which the hairdresser then provides, then by asking for the haircut, the customer has implicitly agreed to pay.

In the supplied example, the client leaves a written note expressly asking the lawyer: ‘Could you please verify if this agreement of purchase for my yacht is in line with local legislation?’
Consequently, the lawyer understands an implied-in-fact contract is being formed, as both parties' promises are inferred from their intentional conduct and he knows or at least has reason to know the other party will interpret the conduct as assent or an agreement.

To establish the existence of an implied in fact contract, it is necessary to show:

An unambiguous offer - the client’s question

Unambiguous acceptance – the lawyer provided a written answer to the question

Mutual intent to be bound – their mutual behaviour implies their intent to be bound

Consideration – as client and lawyer they have already shown consideration in drawing up the will. This second contract involves the lawyer’s consideration in providing his knowledge and the client’s consideration in paying for it. The payment terms are implied as the client knows the lawyer will expect to be paid for his work.

Although the client never agreed to engage the attorney directly she implied it by her question for the lawyer to verify the agreement.

That the boat sale never took place is irrelevant. The contract between them only concerned the lawyer verifying the terms of the agreement, not the sale of the boat.

Consequently, A is the better answer, as the behaviour of the two parties created a contract implied in fact. Answer B doesn’t lead to a disadvantage to the lawyer.

Now the next question was to understand if a retired employee can sue their ex-employer during recession, where the pension investments do not give returns enough to pay the pension. I learnt that the answer to this depends on the type of pension plan, such as the contribution, if private or state pension. I thought in my head that, the employee in this question is receiving private pension. During this research, I found out that there were essentially two types of private pension:defined contribution and defined benefit pension. In this case, I understood that the employee would receive defined benefit pension since there was no mention of his contribution to pension. Defined benefit contribution employee can sue their employer in court for fiduciary violations when unable to pay the pension. Hence, option A is 100 % correct.

column12: While unsure of the legal meaning of Undue influence and insufficient considerations, my thought process was to understand how the two were different in US law. In contract law, undue influence is considered when a party excessively persuades another party to enter into a contract. By law, in case of undue influence the persuading party holds some authoritative influence and missues vulnerability.  While in case of insufficient considerations or inadequate considerations the value of the property is not fair where the minds did not meet (agree) or unaware. In the current case, the daughter had undue influence over her mother while she persuaded the mother to sell the house to value far lower than its market value. It cannot be conisdered inadequate consideration because the mother being aware of the market value, did not bargain the house price with the daughter,rather accepted her terms. It is still not clear to me yet what are the features such as state of mind, vulnerabilities influence inadequate considerations. The mother here was old and with the fear of being lonely was under undue influence of the daughter while selling the property, these fit well wil option A.

column12: From my research, I learnt that mi in lojban refers to the speaker and those who are listening. In the mi series, mi'o is used when the speaker includes only the listener but no one else and in case of mi'a includes the speaker and others but excludes the listener. Now, to understand this better in the context of the current scenario 'let's watch the sunset', the speaker is including the listener when he makes this statement and anyone hearing this would not be included. So essentially lojban speaker would use mi'o as in Option A. If the speaker were to use 'mi'a', the statement in english would be 'we will watch the sunset', where the speaker is speaking to a third party while he is referring to 'we' and essentially not include those part of 'we'.

column12: The patient's symptom of non-healing foot ulcer with diabetes suggested peripheral neuropathy from my online search. Patient's lifestyle history of smoking, hypertension, hyperlipid and Ankleâ€“brachial index test result, values less than 1 and 0.5, is indicative of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and very severe PAD, respectively. While treating with antibiotics is important to treat the ulcer, if not would lead to gangrene and amputation. However, after 'bedside' Ankleâ€“brachial index test, the next best step in severe PAD diagnosis would be vascular imaging with methods such as that in option A and followed by a revascularization surgery option. Before revascularization, the next step would be to treat ulcer with broad spectrum antibiotics if the wound looked very infectious or gangrene like. In the current case, the ulcer does not look infected as there is no indication of pus or the body temperature of the patient is not elevated (my search did not indicate fever a common symptom in diabetic foot ulcer patients), treatment with oral antibiotics might not be needed. Although, I am not sure if the physician would prescribe oral antibiotics, wait for few weeks and then consider angiography, since it is an invasive procedure. Therefore I think there is 10% chance that the option B is correct.

column12: My first thought while researching this question was to learn more about tax return falsifying frauds and how it is usually proved in court against a genuine mistake or ignorance. While looking up for this, I came across U.S. Code § 7206, which along with other conditions considers falsifying tax return a felony and can be convicted in court. While researching the interpretation of § 7206 code in online blogs, I learnt that prosecution under § 7206(1) does not need to show intent to evade tax and circumstantial evidence to show willfulness of falsification was sufficient. In the current question, the defendant's previous similar schemes of falsifying tax return can be used as an evidence to prove that the mistake was done willingly, as in option B. However, I am only 76%  sure that the option B is right, since another reliable blog suggested that the intent to falsify (option A) should also be proved along with the proof that the defendant affirmatively attempted to evade the tax (option B). Therefore, I believe in the current scenario, first proving that the defendant evaded the tax willingly and was not a mistake is the right answer.

I then looked up the definition of 'inadequate considerations in contract' that I learnt from the previous question. The guardian here could contest the agreement as inadquate since the woman was not in the right state of mind as she was on prescription painkiller and the 'meeting of mind' did not take place during the agreement. The woman had a surgical procedure previous night of the contract and was on painkiller, which could have been prescribed an opiod since surgical procedure are too painful. Opiods or other strong painkillers alter the state of mind and the party lacks the mental capacity to enter any agreement. The law considers any contract made under influence of drugs voidable, i.e., one party can contest the agreement. Therefore option B is 100% likely right that the neighbour will not succeed as the contract is voidable.

column12: My first thought when I read the question was to learn about invoice issuing law to understand why the employee did not send an invoice to the client after delivering the supercomputer on 1st of March! Essentially, in good sales, the invoice can be issued as soon as the product is delivered to the customer, so the employee could have issued one on 1st of March. According to the employement contract, the forfeiture provision clearly states that the employee could only earn the commision if he sent the invoice while he was employed suggesting that the company is not liable to pay him commission in this case as the invoice was sent after his termination. The employee can sue and triumph if he can prove that the invoice could have been issued to the customer while he was employed and the possible reasons for delay could be slower processing of invoice from company's account team or failure from the company to give him enough notice period to complete the task etc. As I write this explanation, I realise that I could have researched if a back dated invoice could have been sent to the customer, so that the employee could argue that the invoice was sent before his termination. It is unclear to me with the limited information what would be the outcome, option A or option B. However, I believe option A may is the right answer.
