column10: After research: A (Yes, as it constitutes a declaration against interest.): 60%; B (Yes, as it is considered a statement made by a co-conspirator.): 40%
column12: Researching the definition of declaration of interest in US law, I understood that it is an exception to hearsay when the statement made is strong enough to prove a case where the person making the statement would not have said if they were not involved. Hearsay is something that is said outside court and need not always be admissible as an evidence. In the current case, the statement of the wife can be a hearsay, harmless banter between a couple. However, according to Rule 804 (b)(3), the statement is an exception to hearsay because the husband is (1) dead (2) involved in the conspiracy (3) making this statement is against his benefit (4) proves the conspiracy. His statement can also be admissible as co-conspirator by rule 801 i.e., option A. For 801 rule to be applied, the statement must have been made while the conspiracy was ongoing and the statement must be made to help achieve the goals of the conspiracy. The statement was made after the fire burnt the yacht but not before claiming the insurance, so I am not sure if one could say that the conspiracy is ongiong. I believe, in this current case, Rule 804 (b)(3), declaration of interest is applicable i.e., option A is 60% likely right.

column12: From my research on previous questions in this project, I learnt about rule 803, 804 and 807 in the US law that outlines the exceptions for hearsay that is admissible in court. With regards to the current case, the exception that applies is Rule 804 (b)(2) Statement Under the Belief of Imminent Death. According to this rule, to accept the hearsay evidence, the statement has to satisfy two criterea (1) the person making the statement, i.e., the dead victim should declare that the death is imminent (2) the circumstance or cause of the imminent death. The current case satisfies the criterea one, however, will it satisfy the second criterea is debatable according to me. Although, the doctor affidavit only includes the statement from the victim that his death is imminent, this affidavit is presented to court as a supporting evidence to the pedistrain's statement made to the nurse where he describes the circumstance of death i.e., the accident resulting in injuries. Therefore I argue that the circumstance of his death is implied in the affidavit and option A is 90% likely right. I might be 10% likely wrong and the circumstance had to be explicit in the affidavit.

column12: While researching about using criminal court transcript in civil case in US law, I learnt that according to the rule 801(d)(D) agent or servant statement, the evidence can be presented as an exception to hearsay given that (i) it concerns a matter within the scope of the agency (ii) while employed. In the absence of witness testifying in the civil case, the transcript from the criminal case can be used as an exception to hearsay if same issues is between the same parties or someone having a similar interest, and the party against whom the evidence is offered had the opportunity to cross examine the witness who gave the testimony. So in the current case, since the security officer testifies that he acted as an agent of his employer i.e., 801(d)(D) and his testimony in criminal and civil cout is of the same manslaughter case invloving the same victim & defendant. Therefore the transcript is admissible as an exception to hearsay against the opponent party. So option A is 90% likely right. However, I have 10% doubt about this option being correct because the security officer is not a witness rather the defandant, so would these exception hold true or does it make a distinction between witness and defendant or is the director of the security officer the defendant here.

column10: After research: A (Permissible as evidence, on the grounds that a confession from one participant in a crime is legally admissible against the other participant.): 75%; B (Impermissible as evidence, given the situation, there was no duty or obligation for accused B to respond to the accusations.): 25%
column12: My first thought was to understand what was Miranda right; it is essentially the right to silence and the right to invoke fifth amendment (that I learnt a little bit in detail in the previous questions). By law, the police officer before taking the accused to police custody or while taking statement in police custody had to say the Miranda rights and make the accused aware of their right to not answer police questioning. Anything said after the police officer reads this right is used an evidence in court. The accused can wavier the right (i.e., give away this right) by explicity answering the questions or implicitly, by keeping silent while questioning. To consider that the accused has enforced his Miranda right, he has to invoke this by saying that he understands and wishes to be silent otherwise the police officer can consider that the accused has implicitly waviered his right. In the current situation, accused B did not invoke his Miranda right and therefore has waviered the right implicitly by being silent. When the accused A is making the confession, accused B should have denied the accusations, therefore, his silence here can be conisdered that he agrees to accused A that he comitted the crime. Therefore I believe, option A is 75% likely right. However, towards the end of my 20 minute timer, I realized the above reasoning probably wasn't just enough, I should have researched further about using the evidence of co-accused and if falls under any exceptions of hearsay.

column12: The patient with high respiratory rate is in respiratory distress due to smoke inhalation, specially carbon monoxide, during fire rescue operation. The difficulty in breathing makes it necessary to intubate the person by inserting endotracheal tube and provide additional oxgyen. Anxiety during resuce operation could have caused occasional premature ventricular contractions, which probably is not harmful here. The patient here is hemodynamically stable i.e., the heart rate and blood pressure is within the normal range. The patient also has severe skin burns. Although, fluid resusciation with administraion of intravenous fluid is the initial management for severe burns, this can lead to edema, exacerbation of laryngeal swelling and increasing the difficulty of tracheal intubation. Therefore next best treatment is intubation by inserting endotracheal tube. So option A is 100% correct.

column12: My research indicated the contract in the current case falls under supply of goods agreement in US law. According to this law, as per the contract, the supplier has to deliver the goods to the buyer at the specified date in the contract and provide an payment invoice after the delivery of goods. If there are any unexpected delays in the supply, this must be accounted prior in the contract, if not the seller has to deliver the goods on the agreed date. If no price is agreed in the contract, then the price last quoted by the buyer should be paid by the buyer within certain time after receieving the invoice (usually 45 days if the invoice was receieved at the end of the month). So option A is 100 % likely right, the buyer has to deliver within 1st of March and provide an invoice for the price of 25 plumbing materials, which the property manager cannot negotiate but pay within a given time.

column10: After research: A (unacceptable and cannot be admitted into evidence, asserting that the use of infrared imaging infringes upon a defendantâ€™s constitutional right to face their accusers and witnesses.): 50%; B (permissible and can be admitted into evidence, allowing the jury to draw their own conclusions by comparing the accused defendant and the individual captured in the infrared photograph.): 50%
column12: I first confirmed from my online search that an infrared image of the defendant can be admissible as an evidence in court. Now the question remains if this photo evidence of a person committing a crime violates the confrontational clause or not. The sixth amendment's confrontation clause in the US law suggests that a defendant has the right to confront the witness and the accuser in the court and cross-examine them about their allegations of the defendant's crime. In the current scenario, the witness is a survelliance camera, which cannot be cross-examined, therefore, can infringe the defendant's confrontation right. However, if an expert personnel from survelliance camera company or other experts can testify in the court as to how the camera obtains the images and the validity of the image taken, then the image from the survelliance camera can be used as an evidence against the defendant. A case study publication demonstrated that Portland Police Bureau proscecuted an accused using an infrared imagery as forensic evidence along with opininon from an expert. So I believe that Option B  is 50% likely right and choose this as the right answer. However, following the 2009 Melendez decision based on camera evidence in California Supreme court, there were appeals to not allow these evidences on the grounds that it violates the confrontational clause. At the same time, traffic cameras provide tickets to the violating vehicles rather than the person driving for the same reason.

column6: Before research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 50%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 50%
column10: After research: A (Granted, assuming there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law.): 90%; B (Allowed, but only if the prosecuting attorney initially presents compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witnessâ€™s capacity to provide a reliable testimony, despite his young age and the emotional trauma he has endured.): 10%
column12: I first looked up what are the rules in US law that defines the conditions for using child victim's testimony in the court. The '18 U.S. Code § 3509 - Child victims’ and child witnesses’ rights' outlines the condition for admitting child victim or witness testimony in court. This law suggests that every child victim is competent to be a witness and the court cannot rule out the statement made by the child just based on the age. The section C of this code mentions that a competency examination of the child may be necessary if the defendant's lawer or the court deems the child incompetent for reason it provides proof. However, any child that speaks clearly and can recall the incident is competent until otherwise prooved. I also tried to research online, in vain, the legal meaning of 'granted' and 'allowed' in US law to understand why the two were used differently in the options. In current scenario, there is no mention of child's incompetancy and the child being four year old is capable of clearly recalling the incident. Therefore option A is 90% likely correct. I still have 10% doubts if the competancy test is necessary, since the child is in trauma and agony after loss of a parent.

column6: Before research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 50%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 50%
column10: After research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 25%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 75%
column12: Between option A and option B, the two different lojban words are cfagau and cfari, respectively. While researching online, I learnt that both meant to initiate or start. It was confusing to choose which would rightly fit in the translation. I next decided to check if either of the word was a lujvo and based on their rafsi, if I could find a difference between the two. Cfagau is a lujvo of two words 'cfa' and 'gau', which means initiate and do, respectively. Cfagau probably then meant an act of initiating something. cfari is not a lujvo, it is rafsi and in the current context it is an independent word, since rafsi cannot be used on their own. Although, both the words still meant the same after this search, it was confusing again to chose the right one. I next looked up when one would use a lujvo while there exits an equivalent word. And rightly so, lujvo cannot be used if there exits a word which essentially means the same; creating a redundant lujvo would confuse a computer. I also learnt that there exits ergativity in lojban which seperates 'agentive form' from 'non-agentive form'. I absolutely did not understand this usage in lojban and did not pursue looking further. In the current question, cfagau was against the lujvo rule. So cfari was enough to mean 'start' in 'who started the fire?' So based on this I chose option B is 75% likely right, I have 25% doubts of this being correct because there might be some useful information in the Ergativity rule.

column10: After research: A (prevail, due to the fact that Xavier deliberately negotiated and procured a quitclaim deed from Zoey in anticipation of securing the apple orchard.): 25%; B (emerge victorious, as Xavier, by offering the initial $1,500 payment, is estopped from renouncing the validity of his contractual agreement with Zoey.): 75%
column12: To answer this question, I first tried to understand quitclaim deed in the US law. Quitclaim deed is a transfor of ownership of the property from a grantor (Zoey) to a grantee (Xavier) without any promises of transfer if the grantor loses the ownership of the property. Quitclaim deed can be ony challenged by grantee if there was fraud, undue influence, grantor lack of mental capacity or forgery. In the current situation there is no such reasons to challenge since Xavier is fully aware of the situation and has made the first payment as an agreement to this contract. Many of the law blogs mention that a lawer cannot help much in quitclaim deed disputes. Therefore, I understand that Xavier has to pay the remaining amount and believe that 75% likely that Zoey will be victorious i.e., option B. I have 25% doubts because I could not figure the difference between the law jargons victorious and prevail, as prevail essentially means that Zoey has all the reasons and support to win.

column12: I first wanted to understand the usage of 'disallowed' and 'dismissed' in both the options and to decide if knowing the difference would help me chose the right answer. After some research, I still could not figure out the exact difference between the two and did not look further as I realized it was not important since both the options essentially meant that the officers testimony is useless. I next looked up the rule that states the dismissal of testimony due to potential prejudice to the case than its probative value. I came across the Rule 403 in the US law that an evidence can be excluded if prejudice outweighs its probabtive value if the prejuidice is unfair, confuses the jury or causes undue delay. In the current situation, I believe the officer's statement against the defendant can confuse the jury since the evidence only creates an unfair bias against the defentant in juries minds and does not prove that the defendant was causing accident to the claimant. From my experience answering previous questions in this project, I vaguely recalled that the officer's statement does not fall under any hearsay exceptions and option A could be also be right. Although I could not find any exceptions to the hearsay after researching briefly online, at this point I was conviced that the option B was 75% likely right. I convinced myself that if I researched further I would most likely find an exception to the hearsay in rule 801,802 or 804 of the US law.

column6: Before research: A (Venous duplex scan): 50%; B (Lower extremity CT angiogram): 50%
column10: After research: A (Venous duplex scan): 100%; B (Lower extremity CT angiogram): 0%
column12: I first looked up what 2+ posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses on both the leg meant in medical terms. While doing so, I learnt that the pulse in posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries located in the leg is fainter than normal, which meant the blood flow to the leg is reduced. This physical examination is usually used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD can also cause swelling in the leg due to fluid build up as noted in the patient. Although, I could not find the choice of test to confirm PAD, using the options as the keywords, I looked up when one would use Venous duplex scan versus a CT angiogram (CTA). Venous duplex scan, also known as duplex sonography, is the preffered, non-invasive and pre-interventional method for scanning PAD. While reading about PAD, it was mentioned that the legs usually turn cold and in the current case the patient has warm legs. I had my doubts if the patient here had PAD or something else. So when I researched again for one swollen and warm leg: the search indicated deep venous thrombosis, blood-clot in one leg. Even in this situation venous sonography is a better option for diagnosis that CTA. So option A is 100% likely right in both the situations.

column12: I first reminded myself the rule 403 in the US law that I learnt while answering previous questions: exceptions in admissing evidences if probative value of evidence is substantially outweighed by the dangers of unfair prejuidice against the defendant or confuses the juries or delays the decision.Based on this research, I understood that option B essentially suggests that the statement made by the co-passenger soon after the accident is not admissible because the statement causes unjust predudice against the drunk driver and causes unnecessary delay in the court. The statement made by the co-passenger does not qualify as hearsay because it qualifies for the exception 'present sense impression', where the statement was made soon after the accident and is truly spontaneous. So option A is 100% incorrect in this case. Although, I could not find from my research, if the statement made by the drunk co-passenger is not admissible as hearsay, since the co-passenger is not in the right state of mind. Ignoring that the co-passenger is drunk, I believe option B is 100% likely right and falls under rule 403 of the US law.

column12: The bruit heard above left clavicle indicates a condition known as carotid bruit where the carotid artery is narrowed due to palque formation. The reduced  brachial and radial pulses on the left arm is indicative of perpherial artery disease (PAD) that I learnt from previous question. I could not validate if option A is true in this condition,however, I reason that the reduced brachial and radial pulses indicate the blood flow is the left arm is affected and the blood pressure may not be the same in both the arms, so option A is incorrect. In case of carotid bruit, if the narrowing of the carotid is more than 70%, surgical options can be considered where a stent can be placed in clavian artery, so option B is 100% likely correct.

column6: Before research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 50%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 50%
column10: After research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 0%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 100%
column12: I first looked up the US law pertaining to character evidence to understand what can be conisdered as inappropriate character evidence, as mentioned in option A. Rule 404 of US law states that character evidence is not a proof to show that a person in the given case acted according to the character evidence. However, character evidence of witness is permitable and further detailed in rule 607, 608, 609. Under rule 608 (b), court may, under cross-examination allow an extrinsic character evidence of unthruthfulness,  if the evidence is probabtive of untruthfulness of the witness or of another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about. The latter essentially translates to option B, where the character evidence of the claimant's witness is admissible in court if the respondent in cross-examination can bring another witness who can testify the character of claimant's witness. So option B is 100% likely right.

column6: Before research: A (Urethra): 50%; B (Bladder dome): 50%
column10: After research: A (Urethra): 0%; B (Bladder dome): 100%
column12: After learning that foley's catheter is the catheter used for draining urine and hematuria is the blood in the urine due to spleen or liver or kidney damage. In the current case presence of fluid in the peritoneum is termed hemoperitonem and can be caused by bladder rupture or urthera rupture during the accident since spleen and liver are not damaged. The chances of urethra rupture is only 1% and the chances of bladder rupture are rather higher. In both the situation, the rupture is usually caused by an external object or a broken pelvis or spontaneous rupture of the bladder dome. Since the pelvis is not broken in the case, and no signs of external object mentioned, the bladder should have undergone spontaneous rupture. During urine filling, the bladder dome expands and stretches,any suden acceleration or deceleration force can spontaneously rupture the dome and the fluid can fill the peritoneum space. So in the present situation it is 100% likely that the bladder dome has ruptured.

column12: One of the two words in option A and option B,  za'a and ga'a, respectively, should translate essentially to 'as you saw' in English. Za'a in lojban means some kind of relationship observed by the observer, which is evidential or an opinion formed after seeing the event. On the other hand, ga'a in lojban means as seen by the observer, there is no opinion involved. In the current translation, 'As you saw, the snake bit me', the speaker is indicating that the observer witnessed the snake biting. To me it, it sounds like the observer noticed the event or in other words it is evident from the event observer witnessed that the snake bit the speaker. So, I think za'a is a better translation than ga'a. This is yet very confusing to me, my online research did not yield enough information to further resolve the difference between the two options.

column12: First, I researched what do subcostal retractions and moderate perioral cyanosis indicate in a newborn. In neonates, it indicates a general respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), which can be due to many reasons. Transient Tachypnea is one such RDS observed in newborn which can cause all the symptoms observed in the current case. This is a non-surgical and common mild condition due to wet lungs. A chest radiograph of this condition can find pulmonary interstitial edema. None of the medical blogs and journals I researched did not indicate Double bubble sign in RDS. A quick research on this symptom indicated intestinal disorder with symptoms that was not observed in the current case. Therefore option B is totally unrelated to the current case and option A is 100% likely correct.
